baby I've seen this kind of situation in real life, and I must say, kuhang kuha.I'm telling you'll that THIS IS HAPPENING IN REALITY, and even worse, and this the reason why abortion should be legal, and hindi porket legal eh lahat pwede na, may mga proseso yan, like a selection only WHO should get abortion legally?, A counseling before abortion yk something like that, there's always a solution to this kind of problem at kaya lang naman nagiging problema ang isang bagay kasi hindi sha nasosolusyunan ng tama.im a Christian and yes, it is very wrong to get abortion by the law of God but Im also an advocate of 'her body, her choice' and caring for what a woman body's go through and the more na hinihigpitan ang mga ganitong bagay mas lalong nagiging delikado hindi lang yung proseso pati na rin ang buhay ng babae kaya accessible help, health care and education for abortion is a MUST.Wag nating hayaan na pumunta pa sila sa quiapo para sa mga delikadong herbal medicine na yan.

uncomfortably real representation of how ph society views abortion. the interconnection of everything: the state of public institutions (sports centers , hospitals, schools,) access to medical care, religion and values and kaya niyo na yan ilista we watched the same filmand how all of these are much more cruel to young women like sunshine, like myself. it was such a hard watch because every scene features a place so familiar. i grew up here in manila and it's always been the same‚Äîmabaho, maingay, malagkit. i couldn't help but cynically laugh each time i see something messed up bc idk just until when this would go on.minus .5 kasi maling side ng quiapo binabaan nia kung galing shang harrison emz

i absolutely love how nuanced this is. how it took into consideration filipino contexts in discussing such a sensitive topic. i love the cinematography, absolutely stunning. captured the vibe of living in the busy and harmful streets of manila.discussed this with my gf but i find the heavy incorporation of religion in this quite integral to the story. while westerners may be able to discuss about abortion more openly, filipinos whose lives revolve around religion, are not at all the same. we were taught at an early age that religion is the absolute law, and we must follow every rule made in the name of religion. and so, the guilt sunshine carries throughout the film is heavier than ever, because not only was she dealing with the judgment of others, she was also dealing with the judgment of God, ‚ÄúThe Father.‚Äù And, surprisingly enough, I find the presence of the child important. At first, she bothered me a bit, how she accused shine of being a murderer, stopped shine from her attempts at abortion. She‚Äôs the superego, the guilt that follows shine everywhere. But also, she‚Äôs a part of sunshine, hence her line ‚ÄúPangarap ko ang pangarap niya.‚Äù (non verbatim) and so, she too, wishes to see sunshine succeed. Her running to sunshine after her final performance and saying ‚Äúgets ko na‚Äù was her way of easing shine‚Äôs guilt. After all, as people love to give life to everyone‚Äôs unborn child, then I guess this once, I too, shall make use of that. Viewing sunshine‚Äôs life through the eyes of her ‚Äúunborn child‚Äù must have been painful, yet every child I know has questioned (at least once) how good of a life their mother would‚Äôve had, had they never been born. And just like every living child, the kid too, understood how much gymnastics meant to shine. And she was willing to trade the loss of her life for sunshine‚Äôs happiness, because she will always be a part of sunshine.

late review, but the tears that i have shed were an overwhelming amount ‚Äî tears for the women who felt so alone, with a cruel world that seems to surround them from all sides, forcing to navigate these hardships on their own while combating bigotry, misogyny, and prejudice in modern society. yung scene kung saan humingi ng tulong si rhed bustamante kay sunshine hanggang sa hospital, iyak ako nang iyak, na parang naghilamos ako. konting-konti lang yung nakakagets pero karamihan hindi, kasi nasa bansa tayo na traditionalist, maka-diyos (thus sunshine‚Äôs plea for forgiveness, that familiar catholic guilt), at mapili pa sa morality. kaya kahit anong galaw mo bilang isang babae, feeling mo ang daming mata nakatutok sayo, ang bilis nila manghusga at sila pa yung gumagawa ng mga desisyon mo, binubuo pa yung buhay mo kahit hindi mo pa nga naaabot o nakakabuo ng pangarap mo. mahirap maging babae sa pilipinas, and the film portrays the harsh reality so honestly. ‚Äúdrown out the noise‚Äù a line that rises above judgement, criticism, and societal pressure. sana mapaunlad ang sistema natin sa healthcare at para sa kababaihan, at sana mas marami sa atin ang maka-gets.

Sunshine affected me deeply. The film explored women‚Äôs autonomy with so much honesty, and the characters‚Äô struggles and victories felt incredibly real. I loved how it showed the layered challenges that come with unwanted pregnancies and the emotional, physical, and social weight women carry. The story treated its themes with grace and intelligence, and I truly believe it deserves a wide audience.One of the most powerful elements came from Sunshine‚Äôs relationship with her sister. Watching the difficulty of her sister‚Äôs life, especially the reality of raising a child, shaped her own decision. It felt like she saw her future in that picture, a future filled with sacrifices and dreams placed on hold. That glimpse alone said so much about choice, survival, and the pressure placed on women.The film also opened an entire landscape of conversations. Misogyny, women‚Äôs choices, abortion, body autonomy, laws, healthcare, and the quiet burdens carried by women in this country. These are everyday truths, yet they rarely reach the screen with this level of sincerity. I crave more stories with this courage, stories that explore mature themes with depth and curiosity. This film touched many important ideas and left me eager for even richer layers. Symbolism filled the entire narrative, and I loved how each detail carried emotional weight. I could spend an entire afternoon unpacking everything.One scene stays with me the most. The motel sequence. The stillness, the rumble of the train, her actions, and the aftermath created a breathtaking moment. That scene captured the danger of doing something unfamiliar to one‚Äôs body and the immense pressure created by law and religion. It felt intense, raw, and beautifully crafted.And the presence of the kid as her guilty conscience completed the emotional arc in such a striking way. It felt like a final haunting reminder of everything she carried.

What I love the most of this film is the face-on paradoxes that unfortunately reflects the reality. You see a doctor, who is supposed to save lives regardless, ignore a teenager because she took pills. You see the main character fully knowing the consequences of her actions but most people around her thinks she should do this or that. And you see pro-life always insisting that the aborted children could be someone great, but never giving a glance to those‚Ä¶

this is a film that shows several harsh realities that many young women face every day. it tackles sensitive yet crucial issues such as unplanned pregnancy, illegal abortion, sexual assault committed by a family member, the heavy influence of religion on decision-making, and how one snap can completely shatter a young person‚Äôs future. these themes are not exaggerated; they are painful and real. ‚ÄúMahirap maging babae, mas lalo na babae sa Pilipinas.‚Äùthe film drop a reality line about women especially here in the philippines. this resonates the lived experiences of countless young women who grew up navigating a society that often blames them first before offering help.the movie also embodied the noises‚Äîthe noise of judgment from society, the noise of broken dreams, and the noise coming from people who desperately need help but have nowhere to turn. it speaks out that the loudest sound isn‚Äôt the chaos of Manila‚Äôs streets, but the silent cries of countless helpless women. the film exposes the flaws in our cultural, social, and institutional systems, making it easy to see where we are lacking the most.the scene showing the overcrowded OB department in a public hospital was somehow alarming. it‚Äôs chaotic, understaffed, and overcrowded‚Äîyet this reflects reality. it reveals how instead of creating long-term solutions, government tend to simply acknowledge the issue or, worse, disregard it. the systems remain weak and unresponsive.beyond all of these social issues, the film also shows how dreams can easily collapse under the weight of societal pressure. this makes the film more than just a film‚Äîit becomes a moviefied reflection of the everyday struggles of filipino youth, especially young women who are forced to grow up too fast.overall, the movie sunshine is a wake-up call. it‚Äôs a call for empathy, understanding, and meaningful change.

Hindi ako magaling sa pag kritiko ng mga bagay-bagay, lalo na sa mga pelikula. Pero sinusubukan ko. Ang pelikulang "Sunshine" idinirekta ni Antoinette Jadaone sobrang danas at isyu sa bansang Pilipinas. Ang ganda ng set sa manila, ang raw, rinig at ramdam mo ang init, sikip, usok, baho, at gulo. Noong tatapatin pa lang niya yung nakabuntis sa kanya itong salita agad ang pumasok sa isip kong sasabihin ng lalaki e,"Sigurado ka bang sa akin 'yan?" Ito talaga ang una mong maririnig sa isang lalaki kapag sinabi ng isang babae na "buntis ako". Walang hiyang linya 'yan imbes na pagsuporta kay Sunshine pagdududa ang ibibigay para ikaila yung responsibilidad, lalaki nga. hahahahaha, sorry kung may pagka discriminate sa parteng ito pero iyan ang reyalidad. Sunod naman yung batang si Anika, noong una hindi ko gets bakit bigla siyang susulpot at mawawala. Para sa akin para siyang inner child ni Sunshine kung susuriin yung pelikula sa bandang dulo nang tinuloy ni Sunshine na gamitin yung nabiling gamot sa Ale sa quiapo, basta fast-forward sa tricycle, makikita na yung legs ni Anika ay may dugo rin which is sign na ganon ang epekto ng nabili niyang gamot o pag abort, hindi ko ma explain pero gets na yan, at kung paano huminga si Sunshine ganoon din siya noong isinusugod na siya sa hospital. Tapos parang noong una hindi pa gets ni Anika yung mga desisyon ni Sunshine sa kagustuhang magpa abort pero yung sa huli nakita niya kung paano mahal at gusto ni Sunshine yung pangrap niya kaya I love the part na sinabi niya na "gets ko na" ika niya nga. Tapos if you think yung pagintindi ay hindi nanggaling sa iba kundi sa sarili niya diba????? So, ito na nga dahil binanggit ko na ang quiapo, gusto ko rin yung scene na matapos niyang malaman na buntis siya dumiretso agad siya sa simbahan para mag dasal. why? kasi may guilt siya part niya sana gets niyo ako, staka super religious o predominant catholic itong bansa natin, sana gets hahahaha...tapos diba yung binilhan ni Sunshine ng pangpa abort parang katabi o malapit sa simbahan parang na pinipilit ng relihiyon at batas ang mga babae sa isang krisis, ngunit ang parehong lugar din ang kanilang takbuhan para maghanap ng bawal na solusyon. Sobrang konserbatibong bansa. At sunod ulit yung pag bili niya ng illegal na pangpa abort, no choice e, walang health care sa mga katulad niyang may ganoong problem. diba? ang lala ng sistema, walang program na pwedeng lapitan right away. Kasi ano ang unang nangyayari o ginagawa ng mga tao pag ang isang babae ay buntis, ang gagawin ng ibang tao manghusga ngunit hindi naman handang magbigay ng practical na tulong. Kaya ang katuwang lang ng babae ay sino? Sarili, dignidad, at pangrap. Kaya, gets ko si Sunshine sa mga desisyon niya, it's a relief for her kung gagawin niya yung illegal. At huli, sobrang galing ni Maris Racal, hanga ako, dalang-dala niya talaga yung bigat ng karakter. Mata-mata acting at yung pag perform niya galing. Huli na talaga, gustong-gusto ko ang mura ng batang si Anika, galing! HAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA

Wonderful movie with an exceptional meaning thay I think coming from a very conservative country is very important to talk about. It is not the most visually stunning movie but it had some incredible shots. It is a well-made film and the heart of it is what really made it an even better one. I love it when movies really present a story that challenges their audience to think about and start a conversation for. It is so enticing and deeply original in a way that it tried to tackle a story that is morally frowned upon in the Philippines so having a brave set of creative to present is just impressive. The performances of the entire cast is truly memorable and that scene from Maris and Jennica will be an important one that would heal so many hearts. It is an important story to talk about and I am glad that they did with so much care for the people who might get involved with it while teaching thise that needs to understand it better.

‚Äúnaiintindihan mo naman ako 'di ba?‚Äùsa pamamagitan ng pelikulang ‚Äòto, sana nga talagang may nakaintindi na minsan‚Äîsa likod ng simbahan, sa gilid ng mga inukit na mga santong binibenta‚Äîdoon matatagpuan ang ‚Äúmilagro‚Äù na abot-kamay para sa mga babaeng hinubaran ng karapatan sa sariling katawan, pinagkaitan ng tulong pang-mediko, nilayuan pa ng ibang tao‚Äôt pati mga kaibigan.o kung hindi talaga kaya na tunay na maunawaan ang rason ni sunshine, kung hindi sapat ‚Äòyung ‚Äùayoko maging nanay‚Äù na katwiran, sana kahit man lang maunawaan at kaawaan ang sitwasyon na dinaranas ng mahigit ilang libong babae sa bansa. buhay ‚Äòto ng iba ngayon. may pabulong na bumibili ng pamparegla at umiinom ng kung ano-ano ngayong gabi. sana isipin natin sila. inabuso ka na nga ng isa, tatapakan ka pa ng lahat. aba‚Äôy kung ‚Äòdi ka lang din naman talaga marunong magbigay ng simpatya, ewan ko na lang talaga! kaya sana.. sana naintindihan si sunshine. sana.

gets na gets kita, sunshine. this film shows how every women struggles due to pregnancy; and how abortion is only the solution they'd think of‚Äî to save their dream, for them to have a better future for themselves.i'm just so amazed how every scene on this movie portrays how filipinos act towards women who gets pregnant at the very young age‚Äî and how religious people have always something to say on that. putangina rin kasi napakita rito kung paano na 'yong lalaki, kayang makatakas sa responsibilidad pero 'yong babae, buhat-buhat lahat ng bigat at problema na mayroon sa mundo. it's just so frustrating yet painful to watch, and i despise that this scenario can happen to everyone in real life.if a woman doesn't want a child, then so be it.

Sunshine itu film yang keliatannya lembut, tapi makin lama ditonton makin kerasa nyentil. Ceritanya ngikutin seorang remaja yang harus menghadapi tekanan dari lingkungan, keluarga, sampai norma sosial yang bikin hidupnya seolah bukan miliknya sendiri. Film ini juga pake simbol dan momen hening buat nunjukkin betapa sempitnya ruang gerak yang dia punya.Yang aku suka, filmnya nggak pernah maksa penonton buat mikir searah. Banyak hal dibiarkan ambigu, tapi justru itu yang bikin interpretasinya hidup. Kita diajak ngikutin proses dia ngambil kembali kendali atas tubuh dan masa depannya, pelan-pelan, tanpa drama berlebihan. Aku merasa ada satu titik di mana semuanya terasa klik. Bukan karena dijelasin, tapi karena apa ya bisa pahamlah gitu dari caranya bersikap dan bertindak.Akhirnya juga bukan yang gimana-gimana, tapi ya kerasa personal dan melegakan. Intinya sih, ini sebuah film tentang betapa susahnya perempuan punya pilihan di tempat yang konservatif, dan gimana tetap bisa berdiri di atas kaki sendiri meski nggak ada yang dukung.

How much inequality have we imposed on them in different ways and names.Where she just keeps hitting her stomach with bare hand hoping it‚Äôd kill the baby or the approach of bringing in surrealism (or mythology) to show the unborn kids‚Äô connection and interactions with their yet to give birth Mom had made it much more harder for us to come over it. üíîHypothetically speaking, ‚ÄúIf I ever get a girl child I‚Äôd call her Sunshine‚Äù ‚ù§Ô∏èComing from rural India, I guess without much realisation I had recently developed a more liking towards Asian cinemas. It makes me feel more connected and more personal. Not just with the main characters but each and every moving and non-moving, told and untold, shown and hidden subjects in every single frame.

What is worse than living in a country that has outdated laws/systems/infrastructure? Having no one to share your suffering with.Sunshine only gained clarity when she felt supported by her older sister - that at the end of the day, she gets to have control and the final say to whatever her decision is. Giving agency to the people whose decisions will only affect them anyway sounds so simple since you can apply it to almost anything, but once abortion is mentioned, suddenly some people want to control the decisions of other people.Religion is obviously at the forefront of this topic. People forget that their religion is based on faith, not objective truth. It is still crazy to me that we live in an age where you could educate yourself, yet some of us still blindly choose to follow a random book that was written by a random person thousands of years ago.Kudos to Jadaone and team for making this important and (unfortunately) still relevant film.

All I can say is that this film is undeniably brave‚Äîbrave enough to tackle a timely and controversial issue within a country shaped by religious beliefs, societal judgment, and limited access to healthcare. For Sunshine, the act of making a decision carries extraordinary weight, as she becomes fully aware of the consequences that she will have to faceI appreciate that the filmmakers not only showed how Sunshine arrived at her decision, but also place emphasis on why she makes it. The narrative thoughtfully explores the influences, pressures, and circumstances that frame her choices, allowing the audience to understand her on a deeper level.The film effectively captures the bleak realities and unfiltered rawness of Manila, which it is easy for me to say ‚Äúgets ko na‚Äù‚Äîto agree with certain moments and empathize with Sunshine‚Äôs actions, precisely because the film enables us to feel the gravity of her experiences.This work is a feat for Filipino cinema. I hope more Filipino filmmakers continue to produce films that spark meaningful conversation and illuminate social realities capable of influencing society. Kudos to the cast, director, producers, and entire crew for this compelling piece of storytelling.

The cinematography, the composition, the colours, and the character were all absolutely stunning. This was obviously handled with so much care and love, as it should be, you can tell that the director has a clear vision of exactly what she wants the film to feel and look like which was executed flawlessly. I will never know what it‚Äôs like to be a woman with child but this film made me feel all the conflicted, complicated, and crushing emotions of what it‚Äôs like to make that oh so difficult decision. Yes it‚Äôs incredibly sad yet she has to make the choice that‚Äôs best for her even though it literally breaks every inch of her soul. It accurately portrays Filipino society‚Äôs perception around abortion and how religion and gender roles play an integral part in the whole ordeal when it absolutely should not. It should be between the woman and her doctor alone, the outsiders opinion only makes this life altering decision so much harder than it already is. It‚Äôs so wonderfully nuanced and so so beautiful, thank you for keeping Filipino cinema alive Sunshine. I also loved that her kid had a rainbow shirt on which comes after a sunshine.

Hindi lang tungkol sa kung ano ang pinipili mo, kundi kung bakit mo kailangang pumili.The film reminds us that while we argue about what's right and wrong, may mga taong bitbit ang bigat ng mundong hindi natin kailanman mararamdaman. And those people have to make decisions that sometimes are not acceptable to norms or beliefs. But Maris Racal delivers a story of a girl na hindi humihingi ng sympathy kundi karapatan. Karapatan na mamili. Karapatan na magpatuloy. Karapatan na mangarap. For me, it's not just a simple talk tungkol sa abortion; it‚Äôs about access, fairness, and acknowledging na hindi tayo pare-pareho ng laban.We don‚Äôt have to personally want what Sunshine wants. Pero we must understand why she has to fight for it. Kung bakit may mga oportunidad na dapat bukas para sa lahat kahit na hindi natin ito kailangan. Kung hindi mo gets kung bakit may kailangang pumili, maybe you are privileged enough na hindi mo pa kailangan mamili.And that‚Äôs exactly why we must always choose compassion.

‚ÄúPangarap ko din mga pangarap mo, Sunshine‚ÄùThis movie was so beautifully written, directed and acted. Grabe, hands down kay maris kasi ramdam na ramdam mo yung emosyon niya and struggle throughout the whole movie. This literally depicts women around the philippines‚Äî-no matter what economic class they may be‚Äî when it comes to teenage pregnancy. Whether or not we care to admit it, no teenage pregnancy is planned and the toll that has on a developing woman will never ever ne experienced by ANY man. So miggy, pakyu.Pero grabe, you can feel the internal battle Sunshine was going through and I think that every single woman who has a dream, a goal in life perhaps, if situated the same, would go through the same lengths. Maybe not through all of that extent, but this is such an eye opening movie to those who still feel like abortion in the philippines is taboo. You would literally rather have all these women dying instead of getting and giving them the right medical treatment? These are children, btw. Yes, they did adult things but bear in mind that there is no such thing as a consenting child in the eyes of the law.Oh Antoinette Jadona, the woman that you are. Thanks for showing us a movie that says na we can choose ourselves. We can decide our future and no amount of guilt trip‚Äîwhether it be from the church or from any ball-lacking man‚Äîcan stop us from persuing that.

It‚Äôs always ‚Äúlabag yan sa batas ng Diyos‚Äù but never ‚Äúnaiintindihan mo ba ako?‚Äù This film carefully define failures of this country. Ang ironic lang for me na kalat sa labas ng Quiapo ang bentahan ng mga gamot pampalaglag, habang ang sistema natin ay patuloy na tutol sa ganitong paraan. Goosebumps when my friends and I noticed the sign sa jeep saying ‚ÄúGift of God‚Äù, we came up with only one assumption of what that sign is trying to tell the viewers. Simply, babies are a blessing. And that‚Äôs what they‚Äôll always say whenever abortion comes up in a conversation.The symbolism of the Kid who has been following Sunshine all throughout the film. My first assumption was‚Äî she was the conscience of the latter. Obviously, lumalabas siya every time na may gagawin si Sunshine sa pagbubuntis niya. Siya ang constant reminder na lahat nang gagawin niya ay mali. Second, it was Sunshine‚Äôs younger version. Trying to tell her something. Pero bandang dulo ng film it was revealed na it was the baby. I would like to believe na malaki ang naging parte niya sa naging desisyon ni Sunshine. Because Sunshine was the happiest when she‚Äôs doing what she love. Walang karapatan ang kahit sino man sa magiging desisyon ng babae para sa katawan niya.Super dami kong pang gustong sabihin sa film na ‚Äòto kasi super pleased ako sa mga details and symbolisms. Right, decision din to watch it with my friends hahaha. Ayun lang! Maris Racal is a really really remarkable artist. And also, Direk Antoinette Jadaone always timely and relevant ng mga films. Super galing!

i have so many thoughts about this movie so i might just make edits. also i only got to watch it now kasi kakarelease lang sa netflix first i just wanted to applaud the use of background noises. i think im so used to movies relying on ‚Äònoise cancellation‚Äô that the background sounds were so instantly noticeable for me, and i understood it as something integral to the plot na ‚Äòsunshine‚Äôs story is just one sound among many‚Äô, and thinking about how noisy these public spaces are (quiapo, avenida) parang ang liit tignan ng buhay ni sunshine tuloy. and it‚Äôs so real that society tends to overlook the lives of these women where they‚Äôre commonly diminished into statistics or cautionary talesi can even argue that in some instances, like sunshine praying outside the quiapo church or secretly talking to the pamparegla seller, is a ‚Äòbackground noise‚Äô in itself. naingayan ako sa mga scenes na yun to the point where the dialogue was just blending with the background noise. it really says a lot about how these stories are just among us, and it‚Äôs so devastating to think that something as serious as this matter (something hindering of one‚Äôs ambitions and with the capacity of changing the direction of one‚Äôs life) blends so well with noise we consider every-day and mundanesecond, this movie really touched my pathos ü§ì given my positionality as a woman. the scrolling on reddit, silently looking for online communities or help..ugh i understood the frustration of being a woman in a catholic country so well. i obviously have never been pregnant, but when im at the BIOLOGICAL age for it, ang scary to think na we don‚Äôt have that option at all, na our bodily autonomies are immediately disregarded by others just because of personal beliefs. ang daming instances when i was watching na iniisip ko nalang ‚Äòwhat if that were me?‚Äô SYEMPRE WAG NAMAN SANA PERO that‚Äôs the point diba? for the movie to put us in the shoes of sunshine and make us FEEL that we don‚Äôt want to be in her shoes. that way we‚Äôll think of challenging the system that we currently have but i really love how despite the circumstances, sunshine was still adamant about being true to her autonomy and GANUN talaga dapat. i heard the ending was supposed to be different, but im so glad they changed it to this

got surpised when the film ended, a ‚Äúhala tapos na?‚Äù na-bitin moment. but maybe it felt that way because there‚Äôs no complete ending to the struggle of sunshine. whether she chose herself or her kid, habang buhay niyang dadalhin ito because people will shame her regardless.i hope the world becomes a little bit kinder to women like sunshine.
good intention but extremely bad execution

this wouldve been a 1.5 if it weren‚Äôt for the importance of this movie and its effectiveness regardless of cinematic quality. idc if characters make bad/weird decisions, just make it have a glimpse of logical reasoning (which includes logical illogicality) i would support it. an absurd amount of suspension of belief is required for this movie which doesn‚Äôt make sense to me in a movie where most of the situations are so grounded in reality anyway. It tries to do too much for its own good. The sequence of events make no sense, relationships with people have no emotional weight aside from Sunshine and her sister, ang gulo. The whole Ariana thing suddenly having a That‚Äôs so Raven moment. Giving a stranger you just met 5 minutes ago 1K. Calling your unborn kid with no name ‚Äúbata‚Äù. Wait Sunshine can see others‚Äô unborn children too? Just sloppy rough writing overall. If there rest of the movie were like the last 10 minutes (the confrontation with the dad is the highlight of this movie for me) maybe this would‚Äôve been great!EDIT: okay so nagka That‚Äôs so Raven moment sya kasi nafeel nya sa katawan ng nanay nya ok gets ko na

some bits I especially liked: - sunshine praying just outside the church, feeling unworthy to enter for what she's about to do- her sister helping her stretch her shoulders, trying to motivate her by saying "SEA games" "olympics" and so on, accidentally doing what is opposite her intention and instead adding a burden to sunshine's shoulders. - the focus on rape-incest cases. it happens so much in our country but its been kept under wraps for way too long. im glad a film that has gained this much traction helped put it, and the many ways that it's the mothers and maternal figures that facilitate such violations of their own children has been put to light. i felt conflicted watching what is supposed to be these imaginary consciousnesses of unborn children running about and acting as, what i initially thought to be, a device for invoking guilt in these young and unwilling kids and anger in its audience. but perhaps they were an avenue for the world to understand that while they have a future too, so does sunshine. so does the thirteen year old. what are these pastors and doctors planning for /their/ future? anyways im glad the movie stuck by its pro-abortion stances and did not pull back any punches. women's and children's healthcare has been on a serious decline in this country. its high time we see changes that put women as priority not some hypothetical individual.

gets ko nakuhang-kuha ng pelikulang ‚Äòto ang puso at kaluluwa ko. it is not like typical tear-jerker indie films out there pero yung mga linyahan ng characters at yung buong mensahe ng pelikula, talagang makatotohanan at tagos kung tagos.ang sakit sa damdamin na ito talaga ang reality ng maraming kababaihan at kabataan dito sa Pilipinas at nakakapoot isipin na hanggang ngayon, wala pa rin silang sapat na proteksyon para sa ganitong sitwasyon, kaya sobrang nakakaputangina lang talaga ng mga lalaking puro sarap lang ang nasa isip pero walang puso at paninindigan, pati na rin ng gobyerno at ng mga relihiyong tumutuligsa sa sex education at safe abortion. isang malaking pakyu para sa inyong lahat! hands down din kay miss maris racal. hinding-hindi maipagkakaila na magaling talaga siyang artista. makikita mo talaga sa kanya yung passion at dedication niya sa pag-arte sa pelikulang ‚Äòto, lalo na sa part na nagsumikap talaga siyang matutuhan ang gymnastics para maisabuhay ang character ni Sunshine.anyway, ayoko nang pahabain ‚Äòto.... para sa mga Sunshine at Mary Grace, at sa lahat ng mga babaeng nakararanas ng iba pang kalupitan ng tunay na mundo, hindi kayo nag-iisa dahil kasama niyo ako sa laban niyo. hindi natin sila bati, pangit silang lahat! at para naman sa mga Miggy at Tito Bobot, pakyu! sana mabaog kayong lahat.

many people misunderstood this film once it came out on streaming. it's not about romanticizing abortion, it's about being given a choice and respecting it. Sunshine gave us a look into what a pregnancy scare entails for a girl in the Philippines---the accessibility of options, the healthcare system, the spiritual nuances, and everything else in between. the writing is so beautiful and raw. i thought the metaphor was so on the nose but the tie-up was so satisfying that i didnt even mind it. the hype is justified (and possibly underrated).thank you, Sunshine, for opening up a much-needed conversation about teen pregnancy and abortion in the country.

I had the chance to watch this at JAFF 2025. The plot twist is simple, but the message is powerful. The film highlights issues of sexual harassment and sexual violence involving minors. At JAFF, the director shared a little about how sexual issues are still considered taboo in the Philippines, and how the film also touches on the topic of abortion.Listening to the director speak at JAFF about the impact of this film, several discussions regarding cases of sexual harassment and violence in the Philippines have begun to open up, even if only slightly. According to him, this film has helped pave the way for filmmakers there to create similar works, which are still relatively rare.

Gets kita Sunshine, gets ka namin.Grabe, napakahusay. I didn‚Äôt expect how emotional this film would make me feel ‚Äî to the point that it got me all teary-eyed. "Sunshine" is one of those films that stirs something inside: It makes you see, it makes you feel, it makes you realize, and it makes you understand.Itong "Sunshine" ay hindi lang basta-bastang pelikula gaya ng iba, dahil sa malalim at mabigat nitong mensahe. Sunshine, the girl with big dreams who got pregnant too early. Mary Grace, a child neglected by her own Mother, and was raped and impregnated by her Uncle ‚Äî these characters aren‚Äôt purely fictional; they reflect real-life problems that many have faced. Iilan lamang ang sitwasyon nina Sunshine at Mary Grace sa maraming dahilan kung bakit sang-ayon ako sa Abortion o Pro-choice.Abortion isn‚Äôt murder; it‚Äôs healthcare ‚Äî this is a strong and profound message in the film. "Sunshine" is a film that goes beyond entertainment; it also functions as an eye-opener. I hope na mas marami pa ang manood ng movie na ‚Äòto. Para ma-realize nila kung gaano kahalaga na i-legalize ang aborsyon sa bansa. Kasi, sa totoo lang, napakaraming problema na puwedeng ma-solve kapag na-legalize na ang aborsyon (e.g., poverty, suicide cases, unemployment, uneducated people, etc.).Ang solid talaga nito, pati ‚Äòyung mga bwisit na chismosa at religious people na nagpapaka-saint kuhang-kuha. But joke aside, nakakainis talaga ‚Äòyung mga nagmamagaling na ‚Äòyan, ta‚Äôs gagamitin pa ang Bible para i-justify ang pagiging ignorante nila. Like please, can‚Äôt they learn to set aside their religious beliefs and think about what truly matters?! They disagree, solely because the bible says it‚Äôs a sin. But what about those who have (and will) suffer? All they care about is that the baby gets delivered, but what comes after that? They don‚Äôt care. They really know how to be a pain in the ass.

mahal na mahal kita Sunshine!!! bigla kong na-gets yung sinabi ng mama ko na tumatak talaga sa‚Äôkin. she once told me, during a fight, na sana hindi niya na lang ako binuhay. i know it‚Äôs an inappropriate thing to say to your child, pero now i kinda understand where it came from.hindi ko siya kayang i-hate. alam ko na she was once a ‚ÄúSunshine‚Äù too na punong-puno ng pangarap, at nawala ang lahat ng ‚Äôyon nung nabuntis siya sa‚Äôkin. maybe we can use the quote ‚Äúrejection is redirection,‚Äù pero masakit isipin na she could‚Äôve done better. i can‚Äôt blame her for having the what-ifs of her past. hindi niya kasalanan na she grew up in a conservative, religious country. systemic talaga ang lahat. alam ko na mahal na mahala ako ng nanay ko pero hindi ko rin siya masisi kung may regret pa rin siya about the dreams she never got to chase.this movie helped me understand her side a bit more, and somehow, it helped me forgive her for saying that thing.sana maging legal na ang abortion sa Pilipinas. at sana mas maraming kababaihan ang maging katulad ni Sunshine na patuloy na pipiliin ang sarili at pangarap.

PS: Pro-choice also means being Pro-life. Argue with the wall.

Gets kita.Wala pang kalahating oras nang ipakita ang eksena kung saan humingi ng tawad si Sunshine sa harap ng simbahan‚ÄîTagos. Ramdam agad ang emosyon at ang mensahe. Sabay na nakakalungkot at nakakagalit kung iyong iisipin na sa bawat tagpi ng eksena ay ipinapamukha ng pelikulang ito ang tunay na representasyon at kalagayan ng mga kababaihin patungkol sa aborsyon at 'reproductive health' sa Pilpinas: mahirap at nakakasuka. Importante ang bawat sulok ng pelikulang ito lalung lalo na ang pananalamin sa estado at kasuluksulukan ng Quiapo. Sa bawat busina at usok ng mga jeep, sa bawat ingay ng mga tao, sa bawat lakad ng mga kababaihan na may sabay na bitbit na pangarap at problema, hinding hindi maikukumpara kung gaano kasalimuot ang kanilang mga nararanasan. Kaya kung napanood mo ito at hindi ka pa sumasang-ayon, naway isipin mo ang mahabaging desisyon na bitbit ni Sunshine (hindi man ito aayon sa kultura at relihiyon ng ating bansa), sapagkat ito ay mahalagang proposal na dapat isaalang-alang ng nakararami.

Hindi ko alam kung bakit ang hirap nitong intindihin para sa iba.This movie doesn‚Äôt just show the reality of unplanned pregnancy, it exposes why good quality and ACCESSIBLE healthcare is crucial and why fucking abortion needs to be legalized. ‚ÄúNaiintindihan mo bako?‚Äù‚ÄúGets ko na.‚ÄùGets ko na/naiintindihan ko are the words na lagi kong sinasabi sa mama ko but in so many different situations, the child and sunshine‚Äôs similarity to us is that, laging nabibring up sa usapan naming mag-ina yung mga what ifs ko for her as her daughter, what she could‚Äôve been if she chose herself years ago. Hindi ko naiintindihan, are the words na lagi kong sagot kada ang response niya sakin ay ‚Äúkasi ikaw ang buhay ko‚Äù, kasi ang kapalit nun sakin ay yung mga responsibilidad na maging mas matalino, mas magaling, na hindi option ang pumalpak, especially when it comes to decisions.Sabi ko, hindi ko naiintindihan kasi sayang. Lahat ng kung ano ako ngayon, lahat ng mga narating ko ngayon, dapat siya na yun, o mas higit pa kung nilakasan niya lang loob niya. Ika nga, in this world we can‚Äôt always get all that we want, kaya sa kabila ng bawa‚Äôt hindi ko maintindihan, siya ring may katapat na naiintindihan ko. Gets ko na, hindi pala na sayang, dahil siya din naman ang lahat ng kung ano ako ngayon, dahil dun palang sa pinili niya ako para maging anak niya, kahit pa na may kapalit iyong mga responsibilidad hindi lang para sakin kundi para din sa kaniya, dun palang sa araw na yun, isang matapang na pagpasya din ang ginawa niya para piliin na kaming dalawa ang magkakampi sa bawat laban na haharapin namin. Gets ko na, na hindi lang sakin to mahirap, na masyado ring mahirap itong mundong ito para sa kaniya, kaya‚Äôt ano pa‚Äôt para dumagdag pa ako sa mga kalaban niya.I feel like most daughters shares this same sentiments and dreams for their mothers of wanting them to choose themselves even if it means not having the chance to be born in this world, and that‚Äôs what makes me love this movie. It comforted me to have the perception of making that dream come true for my own mom. It showed the depth of the understanding between the mother and their child especially their daughters. Just when we thought it‚Äôs already deep, it could get more deeper.Gets ko na. Sabi ng anak ni sunshine sa kaniya, whom I still and highly believe na kakampi niya (bukod sa ate niya) on every step of her way dahil lahat ng pangarap na meron sila, lahat ng bawat sumunod na tagumpay ay para padin sa kanilang dalawa.

My debut here on letterboxd inkigayo (chareng) and I wanted it to be about Sunshine because this is my movie of the YEAR! As a man na lumaki sa very conservative and religious na family, I‚Äôve always been socially aware. I am pro abortion but I never really know kung gaano kalalim yung pinaglalaban natin, well atleast not until I saw this film.Bilang lalaki na manonood, I can only empathize & be compassionate towards sunshine because I feel like nobody can understand her better than women themselves. Highlight ng film for me is yung scene ni Maris sa motel, besides feeling a sense of dread, it also fills me with anger dahil babae pa din talaga ang sasalo sa lahat ng hirap. Anong ginawa ng nakabuntis? binigyan lang ng pera si sunshine, that‚Äôs it. Si sunshine yung naghirap, nasaktan, at napahiya. Kaya ang galing ng pelikula kasi nakuha niya gaano pa rin ka pabor ang mundo sa mga kalalakihan.Ang ganda ng casting, sobrang buhay nila na pwede ko lang silang makita sa labas ng bahay namin. Favorite performance ko ay si Maris at Jennica, hayop sa galing! (Grabe yung iyak ko sa kwarto scene nila) Ganda ng cinematography, editing, at music. Sa AWKP ko lang nakilala si Direk Tonet and I was NOT familiar with her game! Basta ang ganda at mabuhay pa ang mga gantong klaseng pelikula ‚úäüèº

not every woman wants to be a mother.so, so, soooo refreshing to see an ambitious woman choose her own dreams over society‚Äôs forced motherhood. sabi nga ni bata (or Annika), ‚Äúpangarap ko ang pangarap niya.‚Äù i really hope this film opens up better laws for reproductive and maternal health. sobrang nakakairita lang talaga na kung sino pa yung mga OB-GYN, sila pa yung mga taong madiin sa pananampalataya. motherhood is already troubling in itself, teenage pregnancy faced with a hateful doctor? that‚Äôs fucking worse.this is an incredible film that gave space for abortion and illegal abortions to be discussed in the philippines. it‚Äôll definitely leave a bad taste in conservative filipinos‚Äô mouths, but that‚Äôs the point. teenage mothers live their lives in discomfort everyday, so showing their realities and humanizing them is more than enough to make people realize that their own personhood should always come first before an embryo. hugs with consent to every girl or woman who‚Äôs going through a similar struggle. nawa‚Äôy mahanap niyo ang lakas na kinakailangan ninyo para malagpasan ang mga problema niyo. i just hope you all remember that what‚Äôs best for you, will also be what‚Äôs best for the child. and if what‚Äôs best is not having the child, then that‚Äôs the painful reality and you shouldn‚Äôt be ashamed for putting your wellbeing first. in the end, the best sign of motherhood is to never enter it in the first place. you can‚Äôt pour love into another cup if your own cup is empty. so, forge your own path and dance to your own beat‚Äîyou will always be the master of your own ship. kudos, sunshine! congratulations on your gold.

Worth the year long wait, brilliant film and really cements Antoinette Jadaone as an Auteur of Philippine Cinema. I think what I found so strikingly sad about this is that, fourteen years removed from the Philippines (more than half of my life!); I try to tread carefully when I talk about Manila, the people and their struggles. I don't think that my incredibly sheltered memory of the place would hold as much cultural weight than that of a local, and yet fourteen years later Manila is still...Manila. And if I am brought to tears by this, I wonder about the grief carried by generations of young women failed by a dated system. In all her films, what Jadaone ultimately wants, or rather demands for her female protagonists, is Space. Space to exist safely and choose freely.To break women out of crowded public maternity wards with shared beds, obsolete facilities, abject doctors (with their religious biases), and to bring them into the clearing of their dreams, the main-stage gymnasium, the Olympics.

‚ÄúAyoko maging nanay. Hindi ko ipapanganak ‚Äòto dahil hindi ako ready maging nanay.‚Äù / English: I don‚Äôt want to be a mother. I won‚Äôt give birth to this child because I‚Äôm not ready to become a mother.Abortion is illegal in the Philippines, heck even being pro-choice here is looked down upon. Yet, motherhood is an expected life trajectory for many Filipino women, that is if you marry at the ‚Äúright age‚Äù and have more than 1 child at the ‚Äúright time‚Äù. So what choice do women have if they are pregnant under different circumstances? For a country that claims to be collectivist (pakikipagkapwa tao mindset ang dapat pinapairal, etc.), how can this principle become a universal behavior for most when its own government continues to throw its own citizens under the bus? Every dire problem that needs to be addressed can be traced back to how fucked Filipinos are by their government. Whatever rhetoric the Spaniards spread about Filipinos being ‚Äúlazy‚Äù is still used today by the rich and powerful, their basis why the Philippines continues to be poor. Galit na galit ako sa nagtitinda ng mga pekeng ‚Äúgamot‚Äù para sa pagpapalaglag ng bata, the review she showed Sunshine that it was effective could possibly be fake, pero narealize ko na nagbebenta sila ng pekeng solusyon para sa maka ahon sa buhay (not justification of this behavior). This government continues to fail people in every aspect of life, you‚Äôd realize why the crime is so high. But is it such a crime to not want a baby? (It is not).How can Filipinos truly care for the children (whether born or unborn) when elected officials undermine reproductive health in this country, primarily women‚Äôs health. The Reproductive Health Law faced a long legislative battle just to get passed, and it still took two years for the law to be fully accessible for the public. When your prospects are so thin, people will do anything to get what they want, even if it costs their life. That is a hard pill to swallow for a lot of Filipinos. At the end of the day, Filipinos are treated as just mere statistics in politics.

Sunshine (2024) looks soft, warm, almost gentle on the surface. the colors cradle you, the scenes feel tender, and at first, you think it is comforting. but beneath all of that warmth carries a weight that is impossible to ignore. it is about abortion in the Philippines, where it is illegal, and labeled as ‚Äúblasphemous,‚Äù ‚Äúdisgraceful,‚Äù and judged above the lives it affects. the film does not shy away from showing how cruel reality can be. people, even doctors, prioritize morality over humanity, ignoring the pain, the fear, and the uncertainty of the woman at the center. it shows a woman whose future and potential clash with society‚Äôs judgment.the unknown girl who follows Sunshine feels like a younger version of herself. she is the part of Sunshine that believes abortion is wrong, the part that cannot yet grasp the weight of a life lived on someone else‚Äôs terms. and yet, by the end, she mutters, ‚Äúgets ko na.‚Äù she sees that Sunshine‚Äôs life is not a simple question of right and wrong. she feels the burden Sunshine carries, the life she cannot give without losing herself. she recognizes how much was left for Sunshine to live, how much potential to burn bright, and how pregnancy would have dimmed it. she senses the life that should have belonged to Sunshine alone.the realization does not absolve, it recognizes the choices forced upon someone who should have been free to live her life on her own terms. that recognition shatters you more than any argument, any moral lesson ever could.watching this film, you feel everything at once. the warmth of the colors, the softness of the scenes, the love in small gestures, and then the ache, the rage, the grief that lingers because the world can be cruel, unfair, unfeeling. Sunshine is about life that is too heavy for the judgment of others. it is about the potential snuffed out when morality is chosen over empathy. it is about understanding, even when the world cannot. it is gentle, devastating, and necessary. it will stay with you long after the credits roll.Sunshine is soft to watch, hard to forget, and brutally honest about the ways society fails those who need understanding the most.it will make you feel what it is to live, to choose, to survive, and to understand when understanding is all that remains.

Jadaone‚Äôs works, so I was so excited for this one considering all the positive reviews and attention it got all over social media. However, seeing it now, I believe this is one of her weakest works yet.Okay maganda AT FIRST, and I love Maris Racal‚Äôs acting, as well as Jennica Garcia‚Äôs and the kids‚Äô. I‚Äôll give you that. But this also felt all over the place and inconsistent. From the first 10 minutes alone, I could get the premise of the film and I was curious to see where they would take it dahil magandang storyline nga naman ito. Pero jusko, simpleng storyline na nga lang, andaming nangyayari at andaming dagdag masyado na characters at subplot‚Ä¶especially for a film entitled ‚ÄúSunshine.‚Äù It just comes off unnecessary.Mapapasabi ka nalang, yun na yon?

Sobrang nakakaiyak and worth it to watch. Gets ko na, Sunshine. Also, tangina ni Miggy at kuhang kuha niya inis ko kasi karamihan ng lalaki talaga hindi pinapanugatan mga anak nila tapos parang wala lang, tuloy lang ang buhay. Palibhasa kasi, hindi sila yung manganganak at hindi mawawalan ng pangarap.

Though it‚Äôs a Filipino film, the issues it brings up feel very close to home for my country‚Äîwe‚Äôre part of the same Southeast Asian family, after all. The story is poignant and deeply relatable, especially the short subplot about Mary. I couldn‚Äôt stop thinking about all the other ‚ÄúMarys‚Äù out there who are sexually abused by their own relatives, trapped in a vicious cycle with no real options. Let alone healing the trauma‚Äîthey don‚Äôt even know where to begin.And then there‚Äôs Sunshine. True to her name, she becomes the light in the darkness, taking responsibility for what happened even though she never wanted to become a mother yet.

‚Äúkasalanan sa mata ng diyos‚Äùis abortion a sin? people will answer this differently because morality in the philippines is rarely personal. it is inherited by religion, tradition, and the weight of everyone watching. for many, the word ‚Äúabortion‚Äù automatically activates the label of sin, as if life were a simple moral equation and suffering didn‚Äôt count as part of the formula. for others, it is a decision carved out of fear, pressure, and survival, made in the middle of circumstances that no outsider fully understands. kung ginahasa ka, kasalanan pa rin ba ang pagpapalaglag sa bata? if your answer is yes, then your moral compass is calibrated more by dogma than empathy, and your worldview is as rigid as the doctrine you inherited without questioning.conservatism in the philippines is not subtle. it is soaked into daily life, in families, in pulpits, reinforced by laws that pretend neutrality but are shaped by centuries of religious influence. sa bansa natin, halos lahat ng desisyon ng babae ay may kasamang mata ng lipunan na handang humusga, tama? abortion becomes more than a medical choice; it becomes a cultural crime, a symbol that people weaponize even when they know nothing about the life behind the decision. the environment itself‚Äîmanila‚Äôs density, poverty, inequality, survivalism‚Äîcreates conditions where choices are never purely ‚Äúmoral.‚Äù what do you expect from a city where half the population is just trying to get through the day?when you strip away the labels, the question of sin becomes less religious and more philosophical. sin implies intent, malice, or moral wrongdoing. abortion, for many, is none of these. if you‚Äôd ask me i‚Äôd say that, it is not an act of cruelty. it is a response to reality, a calculated survival decision shaped by pressure that most people never experience. kung hindi mo kailanman naramdaman ang desperasyon ng isang taong walang mapuntahan, anong karapatan mong magsabing mali ang pinili niya? reducing abortion to ‚Äúsin‚Äù ignores everything: economic instability, trauma, lack of support systems, inaccessible healthcare, fear of judgment, and the sheer brutality of living in a country that demands endurance but offers nothing in return.the real discussion is not about moral purity but about environment. what context shaped the choice? what access to resources existed? what physical, emotional, and social risks will the woman face? people prefer judgment over understanding because judgment feels easier. introspection requires effort, and compassion requires complexity‚Äîtwo things society often avoids.if morality is measured by harm done, abortion may not be a sin at all. it may be a reflection of a society that fails its people so deeply that they must make decisions the world refuses to understand. sa totoo lang, mas madali para sa lipunan na manisi kaysa kumilala ng sistematikong pagkukulang. we condemn individuals because it distracts us from confronting the bigger failure‚Äîthe environment that gave them no safe path.the real sin might not be in the act of abortion but in the society that makes someone carry the weight alone. a society that romanticizes suffering, worships conformity, and punishes anyone who chooses survival over tradition. a society that has the audacity to moralize while refusing to provide support, empathy, or alternatives.

"Do you understand me?""I get it"Jadaone's Sunshine portrays the raw, harrowing, and excruciating journey of a young gymnast who found out that she is pregnant, just months before Olympics qualifiers. The emotional turmoil that sends her into a downward spiral ghastly encapsulates the prevalent issue of teenage and accidental pregnancies in the Philippines and how public's notions that are grounded from bigotry, conservatism, and outdated values can negatively imbue the minds of these helpless women.The fragments of Sunshine's psyche of children also deepened the already thematically layered piece where it now provides the protagonist a whole new outlook whether she should carry on with the pregnancy or terminate it. What I really love about it is the film stays grounded to its footing and steadily focuses on putting the audience in Sunshine's lens. The last act with the kid is a top-notch and probably the most heartwarming scene in the whole film.Maris Racal's impeccable performance also puts the cherry on top where the in-depth introspect of a young woman that is going down the rabbit hole won't be solidified without her. Overall, Sunshine may just bring a new sunshine in the modern era of Philippine cinema.

This movie really captured the whole idea of ‚Äúwhat if my parents chased their dreams instead of having me?‚Äù The film shows how teenage pregnancy and child sexual abuse really happen not just because of irresponsible boyfriends who don‚Äôt use protection, but also because it can come from anyone and i mean ANYONE. your own dad, uncle, cousin, friend, or partner.Its eye-opening how teen pregnancy has become so normalized in the phillipines of ages 13 to 18. And to my mom who had dreams too, until she found out she was pregnant with me, she was torn a real 50/50 on whether to keep me or not. She chose to keep me and eventually married my dad.Sometimes I can‚Äôt help wondering what her life could‚Äôve been if she pursued her own dreams. Honestly, I‚Äôd want her to be happy, even if that meant I wouldn‚Äôt exist. The movie‚Äôs meaning and message really hit me deeply.ü•π

Sunshine is a feat for Philippine cinema. It tackles a topic most are scared to produce and it was written WELL. Yes, without the poverty porn or political porn most films of ours subtexts. There are characters that are REAL. Not written to tell unjustly-unrelated issues but to support the story itself. And so, characters that are in poverty aren‚Äôt written to convey another message, rather to stand with what the film is about in the first place. This film is easily the one of the best written films of all time in our history. Not only does it tell a beautiful picture of a character undergoing such a life-turning ‚Äúaccident‚Äù but how it tells it psychologically, and powerfully. It never let go of what it portrays nor does it settle for a scene that would bring in viewers, it‚Äôs written SO realistically that you‚Äôd forget it‚Äôs a movie. A quick one to point out is Sunshine texting her bestfriend, at the time she needs support the most, even if she‚Äôs disappointed for losing contact with her, she still texts out of fear, and that‚Äôs something i‚Äôm sure plenty of people have done. Those text messages are so real, raw and incredibly well-written too. The whole story is an absolute masterclass of writing a film straightforwardly without losing the essence of what it is. It‚Äôs a display of perfect world-building, from the story of her boyfriend, the realistic response from him to the story of the tindera, who without building a relationship, completely makes sense of the film. Even built a subtext of a no nonsense coach that adds to fear, support, motive and regret of the main character.I can tell you all about the beautiful writing but this would be too long. Let‚Äôs get to the cinematography. Well, it‚Äôs good. Definitely better than most films, it‚Äôs quite obvious that certain camera works and shots aren‚Äôt just to finish the scene but is chosen to look good while portraying a scene nicely. There‚Äôs a lot of cues that whispers visually, like how she prays with bars infront of her, evoking the feeling of our character not FEELING or BEING welcome inside the church. Shot-selections like those sre essential and quite reliable to make a scene impactful so i‚Äôm incredibly proud they excerted better effort to make this film the best it could possibly be. Wouldn‚Äôt say it‚Äôs a strong suit, but this fil is definitely visually well-made.I‚Äôve always seen Maris Racal as a great actress before this, now she‚Äôs PHENOMENAL one and is one of the best in the industry right now. The talent to portray talent and skill alone, is something most actors/actresses not only have the chance to audition for BUT absolutely nails from the first to the last second of the film. There‚Äôs a Piolo Pascual jumpscare here, Elijah Canlas KILLS it AGAIN AND AGAIN AND AGAIN.Sunshine is great, it‚Äôs amazingly told through emotions and a bit of a psychologically present engagement to allow interpretations of viewers be as wide as it can.

tangina sobrang ganda. sobrang natural at totoo ng film na to. sobrang tagos puso ang bawat pag arte ni maris racal na tipong pakiramdam mo ay hindi na sya umaacting. i've become emotional while watching this, especially the last part kung saan tinabihan siya ng ate niya at sinabi niyang palagi syang nasa side niya. i hope every person has that one person na palagi nilang kakampi no matter how hard and complicated the situation is. and also kudos to direk antoinette and for the cinematography, sobrang ganda.i'm afraid this is someone's situation rn. i just hope na this became an eye opener for some, na abortion is not bad‚Äî they just have to open their minds and lend an ear to listen. talagang kulang ang pag aaral ng mga pilipino tungkol sa topic na katulad ng aborsyon. sana balang araw ay maging legal ito upang hindi na malagay sa alanganin ang maraming buhay dahil sa maling kaparaanan (ps. this is really happening). maraming kababaihan ang hindi pa handang maging ina sa maraming rason. at marami ring kababaihan ang hindi ninais maging ina. as a person who has religious trauma, sobrang nakakagalit yung mga taong narrow-minded, walang ginawa kundi manghusga, mang guilt trip at ikonekta ang diyos sa bawat salitang ginagamit nila, binabanggit nila lagi ang diyos para i-justify lahat, para maging rasyonable.

Sunshine is one of those rare Filipino films that refuses to look away. Instead of sugarcoating or romanticizing the world its characters inhabit, it confronts the audience with the uncomfortable truths we collectively sidestep‚Äîthe toxic mindsets we inherit, the social issues we normalize, and the moral rigidity we mistake for virtue.What makes the film remarkable is its honesty. It acknowledges how deeply ingrained complacency is in our culture, how we often witness injustice, misogyny, or dysfunction and simply shrug, labeling it as ‚Äúganun talaga.‚Äù Sunshine exposes that mentality for what it is: a quiet violence that enables suffering. The film does not preach; it simply presents the weight of these realities with clarity and emotional intelligence, letting the audience feel the consequences of silence and inaction.Its commentary on anti-abortion attitudes is especially bold for Philippine cinema. Rather than reducing the debate to dogma or melodrama, the film shows how anti-abortion rhetoric becomes a peril for women; not just physically, but emotionally, socially, and economically. It reveals how denying reproductive autonomy restricts their futures, limits their ambitions, and punishes them for choices men are rarely held accountable for. Sunshine portrays this with nuance: the internal conflict, the fear of judgment, the systemic lack of support, and the complete absence of safe options. The film understands that this isn‚Äôt just a ‚Äúmoral issue‚Äù‚Äîit‚Äôs a structural one, tied to poverty, misogyny, and societal expectations about what women owe to the world.Ultimately, Sunshine is more than a movie; it‚Äôs a critique of the culture that raised us. It forces us to ask why we maintain harmful traditions, why morality is weaponized against women, and why we accept inequality as a norm. Its power lies in its refusal to let the audience remain comfortable, and in reminding us that the first step toward progress is learning to confront what we‚Äôve been taught to ignore.

Films like this make me realize how great the potential of the PH film industry is when it comes to storytelling, creativity, and taking risks. Sunshine proves exactly that. Ang tapang ng pelikulang ‚Äòto, not just in the execution, but sa choice of subject matter. Makamasa, madaling kapitan, and at the same time, a real eye-opener. From start to finish, ramdam mo yung puso at bigat ng kuwento, and yet ang linis ng pagkakadala.Maris Racal shines in a way that‚Äôs both raw and controlled; she gives a performance that stays with you long after the credits roll. Jennica Garcia is equally powerful, grabe yung presence niya, every scene hits (we all need a family member like her!!). Together, they carry the emotional core of the film so well na hindi mo mapigilang maapektuhan like ALL I CAN SAY IS I REALLY LOVE WOMEN SM.But above all, very important yung conversation na binubuksan ng Sunshine. Abortion is a difficult, nuanced topic‚Äîone that should be openly discussed not just within families, but within our society and government. And I firmly believe na choosing yourself first, your success, your safety, your future matters just as much. AND, women should be able to decide for themselves: their body, their rules. This isn't a simple issue, and the film treats it with the depth and humanity it deserves.Sunshine is indeed a courageous and a necessary film that everyone should watch!!

More didactic than her previous films, but this is still a great ‚Äúsocial issues‚Äù drama (albeit one with some magical realist touches), with a moving central performance. In terms of ‚Äúabortion movies,‚Äù it really does a great job of making its case. For a teenage gymnast, carrying a baby to term really does completely remove that path as a possibility for her life‚Äîthat dream just gets immediately destroyed, in a way that (obviously) won‚Äôt happen for the baby‚Äôs father, and it‚Äôs why it‚Äôs so essential to this film‚Äôs success that Jadaone so skillfully captures the tactile and practical *reality* of Sunshine‚Äôs body in the gymnastic scenes: that body, with its graceful and athletic movements, that she has spent her entire life molding for this sole purpose of Olympic gold, and it will go away, permanently, if she doesn‚Äôt have an abortion. I also think Jadaone does a good job of avoiding deck-stacking. Yes, the pro-life nurse who castigates Sunshine is portrayed as a witch, but the saleswoman who gives her the abortifacients is also shown to be a greedy haggler herself. And while the two male figures pressuring her to have the baby (her boyfriend and her boyfriend‚Äôs father) both make specious and insincere cases, it is again to Jadaone‚Äôs credit that she cast two dynamic male performers for these roles (Elijah Canlas and Pio Pascual‚Äîwhom I didn‚Äôt recognize in a straight-up ‚ÄúDad‚Äù role, after decades playing the heart-throb!)‚Ä¶this is one of those reviews where in the process of writing it I‚Äôve realized I liked the movie a lot more than I thought I did while the credits were rolling. Jadaone, she‚Äôll do that to you!

One of the biggest factors holding back the Philippines from being as progressive as our neighboring countries like China and Japan is our deep entanglement with religion‚ÄîChristianity, in particular. As much as faith shapes our culture, it also becomes a hindrance to national progress when religious beliefs are imposed on matters that should prioritize the welfare and rights of all citizens. Imagine how much better our society could be if we allowed personal freedoms and evidence-based policies to guide our decisions, instead of insisting on religious doctrine as the standard for everyone.The movie portrayed this reality so powerfully. It addressed so many issues in one narrative‚Äîhow women are often the ones who suffer the most under a misogynistic system, how men can easily walk away from responsibilities while women cannot, and how horrifying it is that young girls, even minors, can be raped and then forced to bear a child. These are the consequences of a society that refuses to give women full autonomy over their own bodies.I truly hope more people come to realize the importance of allowing women to make decisions for themselves by legalizing abortion. Every woman deserves the right to choose what happens to her own body.Despite the heaviness of the story, I‚Äôm glad that Sunshine still managed to pursue the dream she longed for, proving that resilience can still bloom even in the harshest circumstances.

I may be on the unpopular side of this: I want to love this so badly but for some reason, I can't help to mull-on & pinpoint some details lacked for me and thought it needed more revising story-wise. I am not hating on this. In fact, I actually like several parts of the movie. I think it's fair to say (and undeniably so) that this is an important and a refreshing story on what's the take of abortion & body autonomy here in the Philippines and I do appreciate this movie for that. (I added the half star plus because it still is an important movie)I want to love this movie (but only like it) because I thought it obviously have such a great potential to be "a great movie" on most aspects. What holds me back is the writing, story-wise.It started really strong and direct to the point which I really liked. By the next part, we'd see a little girl who follows Sunshine. At first it seems to me that it could be her inner child or her unborn future child so it confused me a bit (most especially on the part where Sunshine was rushed to the hospital, we'd see a blood on her crotch area as well). This device they used provided a bit of comic relief in the movie which I thought is cute and actually can be an effective way to delve deeper sentimentally because its so personal. However, I came to learn (through online reading) that she is indeed her unborn future child (bc of Ariana disappearing). To be honest, I couldn't finalize my thoughts on this whether I like it or not because with that in mind, the mix message does confuse some a bit on whether or not it's a "pro-life" but I guess that could also be the point that it is complicated. Afterall, Sunshine did kept coming back to the church scenes and this can represent a lot of women who faces/d the same situation. I just thought the movie might have to clarify in telling that message.I also much prefer her being Sunshine's inner child (which could be a "tangible" reminder on what the whole movie is all about, Sunshine taking control of her own life and the dream of being a national athlete ever since she's a child). But the line "Gets ko na" have such a great impact on people because of its "casualness" but its the words that has a really heavy weight on it that I thought is effective to pull people's heartstrings in. Another aspect of the movie that kinda lacked for me which is, I think a big part of it: I want to see how much Sunshine wants it by seeing her own training to be a gymnast. What does she do every day as a training athlete? How does she balance everything in her life-- being a sister/aunt/student/friend/a woman in general while also being a training athlete? What do you to do train as a gymnast? How heavy does it weigh on her that she's truly doing every thing she can to be in olympics and be a great gymnast, what does it look like? I wished she saw that a bit (even just in a montage) before or during the moment she found out she got pregnant. I want to see her really work hard and see how much blood, sweat, and tears and really feel and see that "goddamn it i want this so bad" and not just tell it. I guess what I want to say is that I want more training scenes too because I am also interested in watching gymnasts do their thing haha.I also thought that by the 3/4 part of the movie where we do meet Ariana is kinda took a different turn for the movie. I am not sure if it is necessary that we meet another kid (Ariana, not Mary Grace) and that maybe without that, they could still end up getting the same storyline/result (though don't get me wrong, I did like Ariana, i think she's fab). It also didn't do much impact on Sunshine's decision but rather it does prove how fucked up it is that this happen in reality and how shitty it is again that we don't have much (legal and safe, known) access to women's sexual and reproductive health services, let alone being a woman/person who's forced into something they aren't ready to be/never wanted be in the first place.More so, the visuals and cinematography, can't deny that it is beautiful, that's a given. Acting is amazing, no notes no doubt.A little predictable on emphasizing on the Manila landscape and scenery although it is still beautiful to look at (especially considering to people haven't been to Manila/Philippines, at least they'd get the gist of it even though its not all picturesque all the time). I especially appreciate the movie getting in deep and showing the grim & messy ways of taking different methods of abortion. I thought its very important to see how harrowing and fucking hard/harsh/unfair/dangerous it is that women have to/had no choice to do experiences like these. I only wished that they showed the method of when Sunshine made an appointment for that Doctor Helena because maybe it could also show that abortion could also have safe and harmless way that would make people feel less wary and scared of it and maybe even talk about it.With all that, in conclusion I think I do like this movie. It is an important movie to exists especially at our modern times, it's long overdue that we finally talk about this here in our country. I hope we keep talking about it because it is necessary for us we want to keep fighting for women's rights. I don't love it but I do like it and I appreciate it for what it did.

i liked the narrative and character of Sunshine. a well-performing gymnast who carried it all alone, refusing to give up her passion over being a childbearer. but there's something more to see, something to observe about ‚Äî the country's system is rotten. beggars crossing your struggles only to be fed. the extreme language of Filipino people to express rage. busy and wasted streets to feel unsafe yet realistically implied. hospitals rejecting patients instead of living out the work ethic of saving lives. being a bad influence for expressing what you really feel. religion as a coping mechanism. plans of abortion kept clandestinely to hide against the law. and the most of it all, choosing to smile as a way to focus on doing what you love. additionally, showcasing Sunshine's child manifestation was wild. it was her conscience at the same time ‚Äî guilt tripping the heck out of her.curses to the legal system. curses to insensitive and lustful men.curses to irresponsible parents.ang gwapo ni Piolo Pascual.

this is what the filipino people need to see more often. it might be obscure for some, but it is timely and important. teenage mothers are often judged for carrying a child; whether they keep it or not, judgement will still eye on them. the guilt of their conscience will still haunt and hunt them. but we never get to see their point of view, we only see them for the mistakes they have done. where is that energy when it comes to boys who choose to abandon the outcome of their bad decisions? nowhere. i love how this film doesn‚Äôt just show us the story of a teenage girl who got pregnant while chasing her dreams‚Äîit is a story of all the girls and women who are forced to carry a baggage they never asked for. we saw their hardships and struggles. it also shows us how flawed our system is and how hypocritical some religious people are. this should be a wake up call. the little girl (annika) doesn‚Äôt just represent sunshine‚Äôs unborn child‚Äîshe also represents us. we only see abortion and choosing oneself as something wrong and sinful because we are too blinded by what was merely taught to us. we never get to see or feel what others feel. and once we do, we will understand them. that is when we will realize. let‚Äôs be more like the little girl, let‚Äôs try to understand more.i also love that they chose manila as the setting of this film. it might not be important but i think it is. manila is messy, scary, and it will kill you. but once you overcome it, you‚Äôll see its beauty.lastly, sorry pero super bothered talaga ko sa part na nasa lope de vega na sila tapos ang layo pa ng hospital na pinuntahan nila e mas malapit naman ang metro, san lazaro, or jose reyes. üòûüôèüèº bothered lang ako pero gets ko naman kung bakit, so wala na lang yon, di siya mahalaga. hahaha

Source: www.reeladvice.net/2025/12/sunshine-2024-movie-review.htmlAntoinette Jadaone‚Äôs Sunshine has been one of our most anticipated local releases of the year and it does not disappoint. Emotionally charged and socially resonant, the film tackles teen pregnancy and the realities of limited reproductive rights in the Philippines with honesty and empathy. While it may not offer clear-cut moral answers, Sunshine succeeds in revealing the real and painful stakes of becoming a young mother tackling equally both sides of the moral coin.National gymnast Sunshine (Maris Racal) has always dreamed of competing in the Olympics. With qualifiers fast approaching, she pushes her body to its limits until she suddenly faints during training. What she assumes is exhaustion from her intense regimen and strict diet turns out to be something far more life-altering: she is pregnant. At only 19 and with her lifelong dream on the line, Sunshine faces a bitter decision: keep the child and lose her final chance at the Olympics, or pursue an illegal abortion and grapple with the moral and emotional fallout.As expected, Sunshine doesn‚Äôt shy away from tough conversations. Its central dilemma is painfully relatable, regardless of where you stand on the right to choose in a predominantly Catholic country. Maris Racal is a revelation, delivering a nuanced and deeply human performance as a young athlete forced to confront consequences that will shape the rest of her life. And while we won‚Äôt spoil where the story ultimately lands, the film takes a definitive stance without betraying the complexity of its subject matter. It was a balancing act handled with notable care.What elevates Sunshine further is how vividly it captures the societal pressures and chaotic realities of Philippine society when it comes to the right to choose. The judgment, the ironies, the lack of support systems, everything feels painfully authentic and grounded. Where the film stumbles slightly is in its more fantastical elements. Though the intent behind these sequences is clear, they often feel out of place and not fully integrated into the narrative, appearing more convenient than cohesive. Still, Sunshine is a compelling and important watch and not only for Maris Racal‚Äôs standout performance but for its bold and compassionate exploration of an issue that remains deeply relevant in modern Philippine society. It‚Äôs a film that provokes and ultimately shines.

Gets na gets kita, Sunshine. Nakakapanlumong isipin na bilang isang babae, ultimo katawan mo, hindi mo masasabing may full autonomy ka to do whatever you want with it and with your life. Kapag naman gusto mong kumawala sa idinidikta sayo ng relihiyon at ng konserbatibo nating lipunan, parang hindi tama na hindi ka kainin ng konsensya mo; dapat pa yatang lumuhod ka sa harapan nila kahit para sa ikabubuti mo naman ang magiging desisyon mo‚Äîparang mali pa sa mata nila na unahin mo ang sarili mo. Kailanman ay hindi magiging pro-women ang kahit anumang sistema dito sa Pilipinas kung patuloy na babahiran ng relihiyon ang mga batas na ipinapatupad. Dahil dito, imbes na bumuo tayo ng isang lipunan kung saan walang babae ang kinakailangang dumaan sa butas ng karayom para magkaroon ng access sa isang serbisyo na DAPAT ay parte ng healthcare system natin, we continue to condition women into shaming themselves. Walang Sunshine, o kahit sinumang babae, ang dapat na isakripisyo ang kanyang mga pangarap.

this feels very similar to brocka in that it portrays manila as a city full of hardship and loneliness that can leave you so disillusioned and alienated; and where hope and humanity exist on the fringes of it. it's a working-class story with working-class sentiments that fully takes on its own identity because jadaone is able to portray such familar elements in a way that feel completely isolating; the interiors of jeepneys, tricycles, shabby motels, clinics ‚Äî everything feels so alien. which, i guess, offers many people unfamiliar with what these woman go through a much-needed perspective on the importance of dignity and bodily autonomy and how violent, horrible men try to take that away from many women.i think it's also worth noting that religion and patriarchy play such a prominent role here in oppression; jadaone laser-focused on placing religious beliefs and preconceived notions about abortion in the spotlight, all the more affected by teenage pregnancy and how religion has kind of shaped the way many filipinos treat abortion as something so taboo and inhuman that they completely forget how it affects the mother. and it's brought to life by a really incredible maris racal; shaped by all the adversity ‚Äî the kind of performance that requires you to bare your soul to the audience, to beg them to see the humanity behind the people suffering from religious oppression, and why access to abortion services ‚Äî even in a heavily catholic country ‚Äî is of utmost importance.

‚ÄúGets ko.‚ÄùThis is the first time na medyo mag-essay ako here because just‚Ä¶ wow. Usually, when I watch films, madaldal ako with side comments here and there. Pero habang nanonood ako ng Sunshine, tahimik lang ako. Walang imik. Kasi it didn‚Äôt feel like I was watching a script come to life, it felt like I was actually watching Sunshine. Not Sunshine as the protagonist of a movie or a character that Maris plays, but Sunshine as a real person‚Äîher, as someone like me. A young girl struggling with the kind of belief system that we have in our country. Bilang babae, nakakatakot na malagay sa sitwasyon na mapapahamak lahat ng pinaghirapan mo, lahat ng pinagtrabahuhan mo buong buhay mo, lahat ng mga pangarap mo. Lahat tayo may karapatan mamili ng kapalaran natin. Kaya gets ko, Sunshine. Gets na gets ko. Hindi dapat tayo inihahalintulad sa demonyo o pinipilit na humingi ng kapatawaran sa kahit sino dahil lang gumawa tayo ng isang desisyon na para sa sarili natin. Hindi para sa pamilya o sa kaibigan, para sa atin.Would I say na the Philippines is ready for these kinds of films? I don‚Äôt know, pero parati akong naniniwala na hindi kailangang maging handa ang isang tao o bagay sa lahat ng oras. I think a more important question is: do we need these kinds of films? Then my answer would be yes. We do.
