Women in the Philippines continue to grapple with deeply rooted issues such as teenage pregnancy which is made even more complex by the country‚Äôs predominantly Catholic identity. The moral codes and expectations instilled in us from childhood often determine whether society views abortion as a sinful act or a necessary choice, and this cultural tension becomes the silent force shaping many young women‚Äôs lives.In the film, Maris Racal embodies this struggle with striking emotional clarity. She carries the weight of a decision that no young woman should have to make alone: the impossible choice between holding on to her dream of becoming an Olympian or confronting the life-altering reality of an unexpected pregnancy. Her performance is powerful not because it dramatizes the dilemma, but because it mirrors the experiences of countless Filipinas whose voices are often dismissed or shamed into silence.What elevates the film is how it frames her situation not as a moral failure, but as a human story: one shaped by fear, hope, societal pressure, and the search for agency. Through Racal‚Äôs nuanced portrayal, the narrative exposes the cultural contradictions we live with: a society that celebrates the achievements of young women yet imposes rigid expectations on their bodies and choices. The film invites the audience to move beyond judgment and recognize the quiet courage required to stand at the crossroads of identity, aspiration, and responsibility.In grounding a personal crisis within the broader context of Philippine social norms, the film becomes more than a character study; it becomes a commentary on how we, as a society, often fail to extend empathy to young women navigating impossible circumstances. And in that sense, Maris does not just act the role; she embodies a truth many are too uncomfortable to confront.

ABORTION IS KILLING!! THEN JERK OFF AND DON'T FUCK WOMEN!!What makes Sunshine haunt me is how real it feels ‚Äî not just as a story of a gymnast‚Äôs dream, but as a raw, painful portrait of what it means to be young, afraid, and fighting when everything seems stacked against you. The moment the truth sinks in ‚Äî that this girl, brimming with hope and ambition, is now carrying a life she never asked for ‚Äî the world she built starts cracking. Maris Racal gives a performance that doesn‚Äôt feel like acting ‚Äî even when she‚Äôs silent, you feel every tremor of fear, every doubt, every moment she prays for a different ending. The film doesn‚Äôt paint shades of grey ‚Äî it throws you into a world where choices are dangerous, and every door seems closed.And the way the city closes in around her ‚Äî tight alleys, cold clinics, judgmental stares, desperation disguised as quiet ‚Äî Sunshine doesn‚Äôt just tell a story. It burrows underneath your skin and refuses to leave. This film isn‚Äôt easy or comfortable, but it‚Äôs needed ‚Äî for the stories it refuses to sanitize, for the voices it pulls from the shadows, and for the courage it asks from us to look. If you think you know pain, you might not until you watch Sunshine.

stream-of-consciousness review (i‚Äôll edit it later): her younger self got mad at her for losing her friend (which i presume was rhed‚Äôs baby) cause her younger self‚Äôs view on abortion was that it‚Äôs morally wrong. the scene where she made peace with her younger self felt like the magic piece that ties this excellent film together. i love how introspective and culturally true this film is. although scene-setting would have made it better like showing sunshine‚Äôs house from the outside, where she lives - more sceneries that show her life.the actress playing her sister gave the best performance in this film. the subtle moves, the eyes, the persona. the abortion topic, of course, is a daring one to talk about for a film by a filipino to be watched by filipinos. abortion is completely illegal and prohibited here, with penalties for those who perform or obtain one. the film successfully tackled a sensitive subject in good taste. i also saw the religious lady doctor character as a commentary on the non existent secularism in the country. that lady confronted with the sister was satisfying to watch.

Finally had a chance to watch this, i was meant to watch this when it was showing at the cinemas but so busy until recently saw news that it was gonna come out on Netflix so i was elated. Haha.I like it so much, i love the cast in this film, and i love seeing this kind of quality in Filipino movies which is super rare these days. The story is about a young woman who has a dream that she pursued her whole life and suddenly she becomes pregnant which risks this dream, and now she has to weigh everything carefully because either which choice she pick will be life-changing. The whole movie revolves around that and we get to be introduced to the characters and the environment around her that is essential and will influence the choice she will make. Here we get to see a real picture even though the story is fictional, as filipinos you could almost grasp the realness out of this film and say, this is the REALITY but we don't have to embrace it, WE HAVE TO CHANGE IT. As a man, I always believed that i am no position to speak about what women should and shouldn't do about their bodies, but will absolutely support the concept of abortion. When we speak about abortion in a country that is like the Philippines, that is so centered on religion, abortion becomes a taboo, illegal and unethical. We also see these professionals, government leaders that support this kind of ideology that abortion is bad blah blah blah. This film is a great commentary and an eye opener to what young women and women in general what they go through, and that abortion should become an option for all women in our society. I will just make it clear that i think this film is not pro abortion or anti life, without directly stating it, the film focuses on making better decisions, the importance of protection, sex is more common than we think which is ironic in the Philippines that is so religious but that‚Äôs ok, this country just needs proper education and thats it. PS. If you are going to argue with me about me being ok about abortion or use of protection, I‚Äôm going to tell you this, how dare you bring a life in this world, in this country that cant do anything about poverty, cant do anything about corrupt politicians, cant vote right, doesn't have an accessible healthcare and on top of that, if you‚Äôre a man, stfu, and if you‚Äôre a woman, who is not ready, physically, mentally and financially, Ari and that young girl doesn‚Äôt deserve to live like that, on the streets or getting abused. But if you are, financially stable, mentally stable and physically stable with a nice and healthy environment to grow a living thing then go fucking crazy.

In spite of her past controversies, Maris Racal's performance in this film is the very reason why she remains in the spotlight. Her acting as Sunshine is spectacular. The story requires someone who is capable of letting the viewers feel the heaviness of her pain, the agony, and the hope of standing up for yourself and for what you want, and she made us feel all of that. And though I may not completely agree with everything that's pointed out here, I really admire Jadaone's attempt and bravery at addressing such a taboo topic, not just in the Philippines but the rest of the world. Being prayerful and always going to church do not give us the right to see ourselves as being more morally upright than others. When you put all of that aside, Sunshine is just a teenager who regretfully made a mistake and who made a decision for herself, stood up for what she wanted, and spared the child from the resentment of a mom from being robbed of her own dreams, and of leading her to what could possibly be a miserable life.She knows she could be ridiculed for that decision, but she lived according to her own terms anyway. And we know that in the end, she is happy, and that's all that matters.
You‚Äôd know toxic pinoy kasama mo if they were rooting against Sunshine the whole time.
This movie reminds us that whether u choose the dream or the child, a woman always carries a profound loss.
Pesan moral: pake pengaman

ang hirap maging babae parang pasan mo ang mundo.ilang minuto pa lang sa pelikula, ramdam mo na kaagad, pinakita na ni direk tonet. una, yung kawalan ng akses sa impormasyong pangkalusugan. karamihan ng babae, katulad ni sunshine, umaasa lang sa sabi-sabi. libo-libong babae ang kumakapit sa peligro ng pagpapalaglag: ilegal na gamot, hilot, o pribadong clinic.pangalawa, babae rin ang makatutulong sa kapwa babae ngunit babae rin ang pwedeng magtulak sayo sa kapahamakan. parehong biktima at minsan instrumento ng isang macho-pyudal na lipunan. maraming eksena ang nagpapakita ng pagtutulungan: si aling nagtitinda ng pampalaglag, buena mano kahit gabi na, may tawad pa dahil alam niyang gipit ka. si ate sa motel, kahit anong sungit, kukuha pa rin ng tulong dahil duguan ka. pero sa kabila ng tulong, nariyan ang mga babaeng nakakulong pa rin sa lumang paniniwala: si doktorang victim-blamer at relihiyosa, yung nanay na nagpapadala sa lalaki niyang kapatid kapalit ng kaligtasan ng kanyang babaeng anak. sa lipunang matagal nang pinagsasamantalahan ang kababaihan, nakakalungkot isipin na nasanay na tayo sa ganitong galaw.maganda ang sunshine, pero higit pa doon, kailangan itong mapanood ng bawat babae‚Äîbata man, teenager, o nakatatanda. dito pa lang makikita na may kailangang baguhin sa sistema; hindi tayo dapat masanay sa ganitong kalagayan.sunshine, pangalan mo pa lang, alam mong isa itong pelikula na magpapaalala na lilipas din ang pagpasan ng mundo. para sa lahat ng babae, sabi nga ni sunshine, "laban lang tayo. kapit lang tayo." sa dulo, malinaw ang mensahe: hindi babae ang dapat magbago, kundi ang sistemang matagal nang mali ang takbo.

Ang hirap maging babaeng puno ng pangarap. The film Sunshine (2024) resonated with me because it honestly depicts how unforgiving reality can be. It shows how quickly people judge young women, often before they even have a chance to breathe or ask for help. The film also makes painfully clear how the lack of reproductive rights pushes women toward risky, sometimes dangerous choices. You can almost feel Sunshine being boxed in on all sides, not because she did anything wrong, but because society refuses to give her real options.Women in the Philippines face judgment, limited choices, and immense pressure around pregnancy. And the film makes a point I strongly agree with: no government or religious institution should dictate what a woman does with her body. Those decisions belong to the person living that reality, not to people watching from a distance.Sunshine made the right choice. Sobrang taboo sa Pilipinas ang usapang abortion, pero at least the child didn‚Äôt grow up feeling guilty or resenting their mother for what might have happened if they hadn‚Äôt been born. It‚Äôs better for a child to know they were truly wanted, rather than feeling like the product of someone else‚Äôs dilemma. Constantly being told they‚Äôre a blessing can‚Äôt replace the sense of being genuinely chosen.Sana ma-gets ng lahat si Sunshine.

SOBRA SOBRANG GANDA NG PELIKULA NI DIREK TONETsa sobrang ganda i had to watched it 2 times. hindi ko alam ma fefeel ko after kong unang panuodin ito, sobrang lungkot at bigat dahil alam kong hindi lang ito basta pelikula kundi realidad ng bawat babae, bawat tao, at bawat batang muntik makita ang mundo.i love the jeepney scene, It was a really heavy scene, I think it was me interpreting na iniisip na ni sunshine na 'bakit??, bakit saakin pa? baka hindi na ako makasama sa olympics na ito- bakit?' maybe there was this question of confusion na kahit siya hindi niya masagot.. na kahit saan siya dalhin ni kuya manong at ibaba dala dala parin niya talaga ito (yung bata)I loved how this film not only focuses on abortion rights, but also shows many of the real problems in the Philippines.Napakita talaga kung gaano ka‚Äìfucked up ang sistema ng mga hospital dito‚Äîkulang sa pasilidad, nagsisiksikan, at ang daming pwedeng mamatay dahil sa ganitong sistema. Sobrang nakakagalit isipin na sa hospital ka pa dapat may chance mabuhay, pero doon ka pa pwedeng bawian.It also shows the messed-up beliefs of people who think it‚Äôs ‚Äúeasy‚Äù to raise a child. Yung mga nagsasabing ‚Äútakot mo sa una lang ‚Äòyan‚Äù at ‚Äúbiyaya ‚Äòyan ng Panginoon.‚Äù I‚Äôm not against their beliefs‚Äîthey‚Äôre entitled to them‚Äîbut I find it toxic. Paano mo kayang sabihin sa isang tao na ‚Äúbiyaya‚Äù ito kung galing sa karumaldumal at walang kamalay-malay na kasalanan ng ibang tao? Paano mo sasabihing tanggapin niya na lang ito?I think not everything can be called a blessing. And I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs fair to say ‚Äúbinigay ito ng Diyos‚Äù kahit mali ang pinanggalingan. When I watched it for the second time, ang dami ko talagang na-notice. Naging malaking tanong sa‚Äôkin kung *paano* at *saan* narealize ni Sunshine ang lahat.At first, akala ko si Annika (yung batang babae) was her inner child someone who guides her, the version of herself who dreamed of becoming an Olympian but never got the chance.Yung part sa ilalim ng tulay, nung lumabas na si Ariana ‚Äî doon ko talaga na-connect. I think Sunshine realized it too. Habang hinahanap niya si Sunshine, hindi siya mapakali. Naging question ko rin talaga kung paano kilala ni Sunshine si Ariana if kakakita niya lang dito? Diba??!And what Ariana said made sense. May part sa movie na sinabi niya na ayaw niyang bumalik sa bahay dahil wala namang may pakialam sa kanya. sabi ni Sunshine doon ‚ÄúHindi, naguguluhan lang siya.‚Äù i think she was referring to marygrace.The conversation between Ariana and Annika (the little girl) really altered my brain.The way they pictured the life they could‚Äôve had in a world they will never get to be part of sobrang bigat..And that line, ‚ÄúPangarap ko kung anong pangarap ni Sunshine,‚Äù grabe.sobrang naiyak ako sa part ng ate niya at si sunshine, grave sobrang galing talaga ni direk tonet. tinanggap at inintindi niya ito ng buong buo mabuhay talaga ang pelikulang ito.Lastly! finally!(ang sobrang daming yap)the last part, yung ‚Äúgets ko na.‚Äù Those words explained everything.It felt like Sunshine was saying,‚ÄúI hope naiintindihan mo kung bakit ko ‚Äòto ginagawa.‚ÄùAnd i know that‚Äôs exactly how she felt.Maybe the girl can‚Äôt have the world.But no‚Äîactually, she did.Because she gave Sunshine the world she always wanted, even if she couldn‚Äôt have it herself. "Pangarap ko kung anong pangarap niya"That ‚Äúgets ko na‚Äù part really hit me.Sobrang bigat. And right after that line,there was a cut showing Sunshine in this moment of relief and it says so much kahit na walang description kahit walang explanation.i love this film na gustong kong yakapin si sunshine at hawakan ang kamay niya at sabihing "hindi mo ito kasalanan"

i have a lot to say about this movie but if i were to describe it in one sentence, it would be: ang hirap maging babae, at mas mahirap maging babae sa pilipinas. i can tell that this story is well-written. it is my first time watching a filipino movie so realistic and women-focused. this movie depicted the struggles of being a woman‚Äînot just sexually, but in all aspects. women are expected to be perfect‚Äîcapable of carrying the weight, not expected to make any mistakes despite everything hateful is being thrown at us. we are expected to meet and be the standard even if it is out of our capabilities. dahil? babae tayo. at kung ‚Äòdi man natin maabot ‚Äòyon, isa tayong kahihiyan. dahil nga, mga babae tayo. kalaban natin ang relihiyon, gobyerno, at bansa na mapang-husga. ika nga ni coach, drown out the noise. but that is not the case. even if you force yourself to be apathetic, you‚Äôll still hear the the voices of the people. mga kabataan nga naman ngayon, hindi na makapag-pigilbawal ‚Äòyan sa batas ng Diyoshindi ko ma-a-admit kaibigan mo dahil illegal ‚Äòyonkung buntis ka, i‚Äôll have to kick you out of my rosteranother thing i loved about this movie is that it was shot in manila and covereed many social issues‚Äîmaking it even more relatable to us filipino. especially when it comes to poverty, dito talaga natin masasabi na mahirap maging mahirap. the film showed the reality of life for those without privilege‚Äîstruggling to find a tricycle, not having enough money for basic needs, and doing everything we can just to earn a little. even parents are driven to the point of selling their own children.some men, on the other hand, can run away from everything. nakabuntis? kasalanan pa rin natin ‚Äòyang mga babae! kesyo hindi tayo nananamit nang maayos, kesyo tayo raw ang may mali kahit sila naman ang tumakbo sa responsibilidad. here, i saw how cowardly some men can be‚Äîafraid to take responsibility for their wrongdoings, and always ready to cling to anyone who will shield them from consequences.lastly, i love how the kids represented their inner child‚Äîsunshine‚Äôs bata symbolizing her dream of becoming an olympian, while menggay‚Äôs bata represented the lgbtq community and her longing to get revenge on those who wronged her. each represented their dreams, no matter how impossible they seemed in their circumstances. each represented their dreams, clinging to whatever little piece of themselves the world hasn‚Äôt taken away.

Whenever Sunshine waves around her colorful ribbon while flowing and gliding through the mat, it's not just a flawless routine at stake. It's the little bit of life growing inside her.Maris Racal anxiously walks through the streets and markets of Quiapo, looking for a way out in the form of illegal drugs hidden beside statues of Mama Mary. Sunshine knows what she wants ‚Äîto be on the Olympic stage, but the world around her from the kid who knocked her up, to the saleslady who's "helping" her, to her sister who also got pregnant, may have different opinions.Sunshine stops by the church, pleading for clarity but also possibly for forgiveness and absolution. But a ghost in the form a kid that calls her a "murderer" haunts her the most, popping in and out like a conscience. She was nervously waiting to see what Sunshine would finally decide, and so was I.Pelikulang Pinoy üáµüá≠

"gets ko na"that line literally sent me into the abyss. going into the film, i was so confused about the little girl following sunshine. i thought she was sunshine‚Äôs inner child, like a guide through the mess, reminding her who she was and what she actually wanted. but when they introduced ariana, the kid that ‚Äúbata‚Äù playmate during that night, everything started clicking.then the incident happened. mary grace (rhed bustamante) tried to get an abortion, and her baby died. when we saw ariana recognize mary grace, and then later, at the hospital, the nurse announced the baby didn‚Äôt make it‚Ä¶ ariana just disappeared. that‚Äôs when it hit me: ariana and bata was supposed to represent the baby, their baby. it felt ironic at first because you‚Äôre torn between ‚Äúshould i feel bad?‚Äù and ‚Äúshould i feel sad about the literal premise of the film?‚Äù but then bata said to sunshine, ‚Äúgets ko na,‚Äù and the whole film just punched my soul.maris racal is easily one of the best actresses of this generation, and sunshine proves that. the film is raw, very indie pinoy cinema vibes, and it works. it also doesn‚Äôt shy away from the heavy stuff, like how brutal the philippines can be when judging teenage pregnancy and abortion. the shame, the gossip, the pressure to ‚Äúkeep it,‚Äù the lack of safe spaces‚Ä¶ the film shows how hard it is for girls to make choices about their own bodies when everyone feels entitled to comment.i just kinda wish they explored sunshine being a public athlete more, like the public eye, the rumors, the judgment she‚Äôd face online and her community as the time goes by. the ending showing her making it to the sea games was nice, but i feel like addressing the backlash and the pressure could‚Äôve made the story even stronger.overall: great film. beautiful, painful, and honest. i love you, sunshine.

I have a lot of feelings to share about this beautiful and heartbreaking film. Truly a big eye-opener to many Filipinos.Women carry a biological physical pain we are given the moment we are born. Period, childbirth, postpartum, etc. But we also carry the pain this world and men cause. The pain men should be held accountable for. Emotional labour, cultural and religious expectations, rape, pregnancy, forms of abuse, etc. It's like our suffering is pre-written, pre-approved, and expected. And yet the world still has all the audacity to treat us as if we're lesser, fragile, dramatic, overreacting. I think I will never be able to understand the logic of a world that demands strength from women and then punishes us for being strong.Like Sunshine and Menggay, a lot of women out there don't have choices. A lot of women are already deprived of basic rights before they even learn to speak. But then again, society still keeps finding new ways to take more from them.The hypocrisy of the Filipinos in this film is also insane but couldn‚Äôt be more well depicted. (It‚Äôs actually so much worse in real life.) Filipinos will praise God with one hand and strip women of autonomy with the other. Anti-abortion because ‚ÄúGod said so,‚Äù but silent about abuse, poverty, rape cases, or the girls forced into motherhood long before they even have the chance to understand themselves. They defend unborn children better than they defend the living women who have to endure the burden of carrying them. Because if they don‚Äôt, you will judge them. You will shame them. How is that love? How is that morality? Abortion is criminalized, but sexual abuse cases get dismissed.It‚Äôs exhausting. It‚Äôs enraging.To all of the Sunshines out there, gets na gets ko kayong lahat. The world keeps underestimating and shaming us, but here we are, still standing, still surviving.To end this, I want to share that one monologue in Fleabag that came back to me after watching this film and inspired my entire review:"Women are born with pain built in. It's our physical destiny‚Äîperiod pains, sore boobs, childbirth. We carry it within ourselves throughout our lives. Men don't. They have to seek it out. They invent all these gods and demons so they can feel guilty about things, which is something we do very well on our own. And then they create wars so they can feel things and touch each other and when there aren't any wars they can play rugby. We have it all going on in here, inside. We have pain on a cycle for years and years and years, and then just when you feel you are making peace with it all, what happens? The menopause comes. The fucking menopause comes and it is the most wonderful fucking thing in the world. Yes, your entire pelvic floor crumbles and you get fucking hot and no one cares, but then you're free. No longer a slave, no longer a machine with parts. You're just a person."

It was true when they said that this was a brave film. To be one of the first films in pinoy cinema to explore a pro-choice and an unwanted pregnancy narrative is indeed brave, especially when you know the Philippines‚Äô socio-political and religious climate around topics regarding sex, female desires, pregnancy, bodily autonomy, and parenthood.There were unfortunately some parts of the film that felt like they didn‚Äôt work.I‚Äôm not sure but Sunshine‚Äôs decision to abort felt too quick. And her dream to be an Olympian felt underexplored and more of her coach‚Äôs. We‚Äôre told rather than shown that it was hers.The inclusion of Annika Co whose character can be interpreted as Sunshine‚Äôs subconscious/ego or unborn child or whatnot sometimes felt irritating to watch (sorry not sorry). But I guess to reach more towards a predominantly Filipino audience and to highlight Sunshine still being a (teen) child who‚Äôs forced to confront the consequences of her choices by a child: worked? I don‚Äôt know. Not to mention that it felt a little silly to include two other characters, where one was another pregnant teen girl, that lowkey felt like their stories were being shoved down to the audience‚Äôs throats. And in the end, felt shallow. I just think that I hoped they showed more of the technicalities of her being an athlete. Rhythmic gymnastics is considered an elite sport. And when you consider it in the Philippine context ‚Äì the film didn‚Äôt really show what was at stake of being an athlete in this sport. The film‚Äôs strong aspects are definitely on the score, cinematography (particularly to highlight the corners of Manila as this chaotic, packed, and cruel city), and of course: Maris‚Äô performance as Sunshine. There were scenes that hit hard and heavy. The irony of abortion drugs sold and found in the street outside a church. The motel scene to show Sunshine‚Äôs quiet desperation. Her final rehearsal for her routine before her ‚Äúgets ko na‚Äù scene with Annika (where I cried unfort bcz luteal phase duh).The film does show you a glimpse of the unforgiving reality of what many Filipino women go through everyday: teenage pregnancy, overcrowded and underfunded public hospitals, and the lack of comprehensive sexuality education about sexuality and sexual and reproductive health. It lacked, sure. But I guess, for pinoy cinema to start tackling difficult topics such as this: it‚Äôs a start.

Sa loob ng isa't kalahating oras, naging malapit ang pelikulang ito sa puso ko. Bilang isang babae, hindi kailanman naging madali ang mag desisyon para sa mga sitwasyong katulad nito. Marami sa atin ang walang kakayahan at kapasidad na magtaguyod ng isa pang nilalang lalo na sa mga panahon ngayon. Sa buong takbo ng pelikulang 'to, mabigat ang loob ko para sa mga katulad ni Sunshine at Mary Grace. Napakasakit isipin na maraming kababaihan ang nabubuntis nang maagang edad ang walang kakayahan o maayos na suporta kahit sa mga pampublikong ospital na gagabay sa kanila. Hindi ko lubos maisip na kailangan pang dumating sa punto na ma-compromise o mag-agaw buhay ang isang babae dahil lang hindi sila handa sa responsibilidad na katulad nito. Ang sakit-sakit lang. Sa lahat ng Sunshine at Mary Grace, napaka tapang ninyo. Sana hindi kayo sumuko sa mga pangarap niyo. Kaisa ninyo ako.

"Gets ko na."i interpreted the child as her inner conscience kasi pinakita how societal standards (ex: religion na sobrang evident sa movie) affected her decision-making. thats why gustong gusto ko yung linya na yan, kasi sunshine felt na everything was already settled for her and all noises were finally shut out. mas mahalaga parin talaga ang mga pangarap niya para sa kanya.this movie begs the watchers to Be More Understanding. ganun lang kasimple. intindi na hindi lahat ay pare-pareho; at for sunshine & menggay's cases, intindi na hindi lahat ay handang maging ina. unawa lang sa sitwasyon ng iba. tunay naman na abortion is not for all, pero may iba parin na Kailangan ito. why restrict the choices of others diba? legalizing accessible and safe abortion helps girls like sunshine and menggay. no one deserves to be go through those levels of pain. direk tonet's best work yet imo!!!! sunshine is indeed a movie that can move you + can change one's thoughts about abortion. altho i believe sobrang long way to go pa natin. malayo pa tayo sa pinaglalaban natin, ngunit walang imposible. :)

‚Äúnaiintindihan mo ba ako?‚Äùoo, gets ko na.‚Äùthis film is raw, relevant and worth seeing. it goes to show that it‚Äôs not about changing one‚Äôs political belief, but about having radical kindness. the film doesn‚Äôt intend you in changing sides, but it teaches you to be more understanding of people‚Äôs choices. i‚Äôve known sunshines in my life - a co-worker, a co-worker‚Äôs sister, close friends, and old classmates back home. and it‚Äôs just sad just how much they were under scrutiny for, for something they should have total control over. it infuriates me even further to realize that back home, abortions are not accessible, and are illegal even. oftentimes the women are frowned upon because of our country‚Äôs conservative and religious culture, they face shame and judgement first before they can even get to decide of their own autonomy. meanwhile, the men that are responsible can get to walk away from all scrutiny just because it‚Äôs not theirs to hold and carry. to all the sunshines that we know, get to know and may not know yet, they deserve to talk about these things openly, not in secret, not in shame. sunshine reminds us that we definitely have a long way to go. yet a little empathy can go a long way.

I don't remember where I first heard of it, but the idea has always stayed with me: for every abortion, miscarriage, or infertility, if a women desires to be a mother, it will come to her at the right time‚Äîin one form or another.And I think this film beautifully echoes hints of that belief.The part where Sunshine asks the little girl, "Naiintindihan mo na ba ako?" And the child replies, "Gets ko na," feels like a simple, but so profound of an exchange of words. It feels like a hand that's gently soothing a wound she's been carrying all this time. A wound that asked to be seen with the nuances that came with it, not the fantasies the society chooses to blind themselves with.Another thing that stood out to me abt this film is how it challenges the viewers to confront the expectations forced onto women simply for existing. Not with judgement, but with a silence that understands what it means to be human.I just love that this film respects women's choices. It doesn't force a message or a narrative that motherhood is the only path to walk through once it enters in a woman's life. Instead, it says that your life, dreams, and timing are all yours regardless of what everyone thinks nor says abt it.Because to be a mother means to be ready mentally, physically, and financially. Love alone isn't enough to carry a life, just a majority of its suffering.

Sunshine is on the edge of her Olympic breakthrough when she discovers she‚Äôs pregnant, sending her into a desperate search for options that won‚Äôt take her dream away. The acting is great (especially that little girl and her unfiltered mouth!). A tough story told with so much clarity and heart.

A world closing in. Excellent use of chaos and noise. The entire film is suffocation and endless running and running out of breath. No room to stretch one‚Äôs legs.Navigating malicious intents, judgments, and conversations, while your life is threatening to implode. An entanglement of choices and their repercussions plus the absolute need to deal with them. Maybe the ribbon gets loose, maybe it gets tight. I loved it to bits. The Philippines has always been against abortions due to its religious nature, so I love that this is the kind of film that will spark conversations about the said controversial yet necessary topic. I for one can never fully give my stance since I am religious but also because I am not a woman. I've always believed that the woman is the one that should decide on what to do with an unwanted pregnancy. So, to see pros and cons of wanting to abort a child as well as choosing to go through abortion was quite engaging and I understand things more now. To see the horrors of using illegal ways of abortion was eye-opening, in all honesty. The film did a fantastic job of showcasing these issues, as the message was loud, clear and perfect. I'd say that my only issue with this film is that I wish the story was more fleshed out in a way. Also, it was blatantly obvious that the mysterious (and annoying, mind you) little girl was Sunshine's supposed daughter. I would've honestly preferred it if it wasn't made obvious.

First Letterboxd essay ‚Äî I had an itch to scratch so bad with this one. Also medyo late, crammer kasi year-end na :) Right off the bat, I knew how reviews of this film would look like. At hindi naman nagkamali. This film is highly praised, receiving remarks such as masterpiece, brave, and a stepping stone.Yet to my surprise, a few share the same sentiments I had, thoughts that were brewing in me while watching Sunshine. Kaya rin ang hirap buuin ng review na ito (bukod sa hindi naman talaga ako nag-eessay sa plataporma na ito), kasi ayoko maging echo lamang.Anyways, just for the sake of sharing kahit onti:(1) I agree that the supposed personified child is, safe to say, contradictory. Kahit may explanation si Direk Jadaone, it still felt conflicting and made the film unsure of itself.(2) The introduction of some characters felt out of place. In some aspect parang chess yan, character placement and arcs matter, so the player must be aware of their moves.(3) The slap in the face commentary on religion felt overdone. Sayang ang parts and points na pwede pang mahimay.Oh diba, dami niyang sinasabi. But in all honesty, I really felt the need to essay the hell out of this review. Mahalaga sa akin ang usapang SRH at syempre mahalaga rin sa akin na maging diskurso ito.And dahil diyan, here‚Äôs a point I feel no one else has raised. Personally, it felt like under-researched ang pelikula. Bakit? Mababaw pa ang na-capture nitong realidad ng abortion at ang hirap na nadadanas ng kababaihan sa kalusugan. These are things you would know agad with one simple search on Reddit. Gets ba? (Lol) And to think na mas layered and complex pa dapat ito sa sitwasyon ni Sunshine, as a student-athlete with financial instability. Sayang lang, ano? Syempre may good points din ang Sunshine sa pananaw ko. Visually, it did its thing. Acting, no doubt, great talents, especially Maris and Jennica. The fact that I watched this with my parents and that they were genuinely interested and concerned about the film is a good point.Sa dulo naman, baka expectations ko rin ang rason kaya ko ito naisip. From here on, sana hindi laging hanggang unang bato lang. Here‚Äôs to hoping na makahakbang at makausad na tayo.

i feel like i could have empathized with her more if the film showed how her imaginary child gradually understands sunshine from her own perspective like how? How would she even know? lol aside from that, we could‚Äôve explored more of why this sport is so important to her instead of adding a subplot (that 13 yr old girl case) that makes her situation feel less serious.her feelings and reasons are all valid but that subplot makes her look careless and kinda dumb lol so it‚Äôs hard to root for her tbh ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èalso, her imaginary child looks cute, healthy, and fun to talk with... why would she think of aborting her if that‚Äôs what her imaginary child is going to look like growing up?????? the imaginary child should reflect the life she can‚Äôt give or the pressure she feels or at least something burdensome that is so much worse, not some fantasy lolz. gets na niya, hinayaan niya, tinaggap nalang niya ang fate niya kahit imaginary siya.

I‚Äôll be honest, underwhelming siya for me. Siguro tumaas lang expectations ko dahil sa dami ng reviews na nakita ko sa social media (na hindi ko binasa para iwas spoiler) at syempre dahil sa haba ng theatrical run niya. What I genuinely liked were the performances. They hired competent actors, and it shows. And since marami na rin akong napanood na Jadaone films, andun pa rin ‚Äôyun trademark angst niya‚Äîand I love that for her.Ang hindi ko kinaya ay ‚Äôyun imaginary children. Siguro kasi sobrang dami ko nang nakitang ganitong atake sa short films at full-length lalo na kapag tungkol sa abortion kaya hindi na bago sa paningin ko. I get kung bakit siya ginamit as a plot device to feel ‚Äúinnovative,‚Äù especially with a message that wants to tell the masses na okay lang piliin ang sarili at magpa-abort. Importanteng mensahe ‚Äôyun.Kaso‚Ä¶ hindi ako nadala emotionally. May mga babae akong kakilala na nagpa-abort at grabe ‚Äôyun pinagdaanan nila. Compared sa mga kwentong narinig ko, ang nipis lang ng emotional experience ni Sunshine sa film. Kaya siguro nainis ako sa imaginary children na atake. The feeling itself of learning you're pregnant tapos mag-decide to get an abortion already carries so many complex emotions. Hindi mo na kailangan idikit pa ‚Äôyun mga bata to prove a point.Hindi ko rin nagustuhan na parang ang babaw ng pagkakahandle sa kwento nung batang na-rape ng tito niya. Pakiramdam ko ibang pelikula dapat ‚Äôyun‚Äîisang pelikula na mas malalim at mas handang i-tackle ‚Äôyun bigat ng topic.Feeling ko kung lalaki ka, baka mas "oks" itong film para sayo. Pero bilang babae‚Ä¶ parang kulang pa. Hay. Miss ko ‚Äôyun docu days ni Jadaone. Can we bring her back? Charot.

I‚Äôm very grateful at this film‚Äôs attempt to keep the narrative always in favor of pro-choice.For a recent narrative on a young woman‚Äôs choice about her pregnancy, this film plays a lot of modern elements well. Social media is used several times throughout the start of the film, but none of it is clich√© or abhorrent. Each social media is used in a very relatable way, which kind of shocked me but it was a feature of the film I really appreciated. Sunshine‚Äôs panic is so realistic and grounding too, the performance is amazing. In terms of tonal shifting, the film does a really great job at keeping it‚Äôs theme and message intense and suffocating, much like Sunshine‚Äôs need to make a decision. It should ALWAYS be the woman‚Äôs choice!!

ive been waiting for this to come out on netflix and it is honestly such a GREAT commentary on anti-abortion laws in the philippines and in religious/third world countries as a whole. it truly is a privilege to have the right to our own bodies.the writing of this movie was quite interesting and i believe the children held so much significance to the development and the decision making of the main lead. i believe they are the make-believe consciousness of the ‚Äúthing‚Äù (lets stop calling them babies PLEASE) inside the main lead and the 13yo girl, and i LOVED being so confused and then realising this later on. ‚Äúdrown out the noise‚Äù something we need to tell ourselves more often than not. we shouldn‚Äôt listen to outside opinions of what to do with ourselves and our own bodies. it is the happiest way to live and love life.i hold this movie very close to my heart and living in a country where abortion is legal is a HUGE privilege and i look forward to the days where religious doctrine dont run the government and put its citizens in a chokehold. religious or not, DON‚ÄôT tell ANYONE what to do with their bodies, we are all in different circumstances and have wants/dreams/aspirations we‚Äôd like to pursue for our own happiness and that‚Äôs not selfish.

my best friend sent a message in the group chat saying ‚Äúguys please don‚Äôt ever get pregnant‚Äù fresh after watching this. i laughed in my mind thinking how is that even gonna happen. but here i am sobbing like a child and wishing that nobody ever gets pregnant against their will. what a demented, horrifying, and pathetic world we live in. this film plunged my heart deep into my guts from the very beginning. it‚Äôs already hard being a girl and then you have systems in place that form a fist around your throat. this was so well made that none of it looked fake. i mean it‚Äôs so funny to see the juxtaposition of the church and the ‚Äúpamparegla‚Äù vendors that are still there today. maybe it‚Äôs more sad really but that is the reality. i don‚Äôt know i guess it is so hard to explain the horrors of being a woman. men get to conveniently be selfish as part of their nature but putting yourself first as a girl needs an apology from god. men regard laws only when they can deny women any autonomy, but break them with ease for their own disgusting desires and freely laugh about it with their friends. i am so glad this film ended the way it did but i am also very sad and angry that girls who meet the same fate have to suffer maybe even worse than this. and that‚Äôs when i know god is not a woman.

Society claims to protect the ‚Äúunborn child,‚Äù yet the conversation often leaves out the women whose bodies, health, and futures are directly involved. It feels unsettling to watch how easily society dismisses the experiences of women, as if their lives become secondary the moment they become pregnant. I can‚Äôt ignore how deeply this connects to the patriarchal norms I‚Äôve grown up seeing. From subtle expectations to outright judgment, there is a long history of controlling women‚Äôs bodies and decisions. The shame placed on those who consider or seek abortion is not just personal; it is cultural and religious, embedded in systems that teach us to shame and question women‚Äôs choices instead of supporting them. This made us more aware of how easily society turns compassion into condemnation when it comes to reproductive health.P'wede ba pag walang matres, 'wag na bumoses?

hindi ko alam kung anong mas mabigat habang pinapanood ko Sunshine ‚Äî yung katahimikan ng mga babaeng walang mapagsabihan, o yung ingay ng mundong ang bilis humusga pero ang bagal tumulong. Jadaone films always stab softly, pero ito? Parang dahan-dahang hinihiwa yung dibdib, layer by layer, para ipakita yung takot, pangarap, at kahihiyang matagal nang nakatago sa ilalim ng ‚Äúok lang ako.‚Äùthis is the kind of film na hindi mo papanoorin para gumaan ang loob mo, papanoorin mo siya para maalala kung gaano kabigat mabuhay bilang babae sa bansang ayaw umamin na may mali sa sistemang sinasamba nito. Sunshine doesn‚Äôt preach. it just stands there, raw and trembling, asking the kind of questions we‚Äôre trained to avoid:Paano ka pipili kung lahat ng choice mo ay kasalanan sa mata ng iba?Paano ka lalaban kung mismong katawan mo ang pinaparusahan?Maris Racal is devastating in ways na hindi loud pero lumalalim. hindi siya yung tipikal na dramatic heroine ‚Äî she‚Äôs simply a girl suspended between a dream and a reality that keeps shrinking her choices. her silence says more than any monologue could. every frame feels like a confession: hesitant, trembling, pero totoo.and what struck me most wasn‚Äôt the gymnastics, or even the central issue of abortion. it was the ache between who we want to become and what our circumstances force us to be. nakakapagod maging babae sa Pilipinas ‚Äî laging may moral lesson, laging monitored, laging may takot na isang maling galaw lang, tapos na ang lahat. parang ang liit liit ng mundo mo kahit ang laki laki ng pangarap mo.Sunshine doesn‚Äôt romanticize any of this. walang sermon, walang cinematic gloss. just a raw, unfiltered look at how dreams bruise under a society na mas mabilis manghusga kaysa umintindi. the film‚Äôs imperfections ‚Äî the loose ends, the uneven metaphors, the sometimes rushed stakes ‚Äî oddly work in its favor. because real life isn‚Äôt clean. hindi linear ang trauma. hindi laging malinaw ang choice. and maybe that‚Äôs the point: that we‚Äôre all navigating a world built not on empathy, but on fear and control.in the end, Sunshine feels less like a movie and more like a mirror ‚Äî one that forces you to sit with the darkness until you finally admit na masakit talaga ang liwanag. it‚Äôs an eye-opener not because it shocks, but because it whispers truths we‚Äôve mastered the art of ignoring.a film worth watching, not because it entertains, but because it confronts. because it nudges you to look beyond the screen and into the world we built‚Ä¶ and ask, Bakit ganito?And more importantly ‚Äî hanggang kailan?

Ang hirap maging babae.Sunshine touched on some of the most sensitive and difficult struggle of being a woman... especially in the Philippines. One of which is the inaccessibility to women-friendly environments, may it be in your household, in public, at the hospital, at school. And when I say women-friendly, it's the support for the emotional and mental consequences, and physical choices for oneself. We suffer consequences that are beyond our own control but when we decide how to deal with it, our surroundings tend to vilify us for our choices. But Sunshine shows us that we are in charge of our own choices however we like it. We know our bodies, our dreams, our capacities the best. Salamat Sunshine at nagwagi pa rin tayo sa pagtatapos ng pelikula.

abortion is a topic i usually avoid because it‚Äôs morally, socially, and emotionally heavy. what i loved about this film is how it didn‚Äôt shy away from that weight, showing how complicated it really is especially in a conservative, Catholic society like ours where abortion is still illegal and pregnant teens are often judged and shamed. i liked how they showed that harsh reality here. and i also really liked Maris Racal‚Äôs performance, i think she brought so much depth and vulnerability to her role.i‚Äôm a Christian, so of course i have my own beliefs. but honestly, i don‚Äôt think life is always black and white. i do believe every woman should have a say over her own body. we shouldn't force someone into a choice they aren't ready for. if she isn't ready to be a mother, she may not be able to provide the care a child deserves. sometimes, the bravest and kindest choice a woman can make is the one who chooses the best for herself, who considers her life and circumstances. at the end of the day, it's not our body, not our life, not our consequences so we shouldn't judge. we're called to love, to show mercy, and to respect the dignity and choice of others. after all... autonomy is a lifeline.

"A woman‚Äôs body is not a vessel only to bend for a man‚Äôs morals nor a canvas for a man‚Äôs shame."Imagine a young woman who is chasing her dreams, but being struck down by laws made by patriarchal society which restricts and shames her for taking decisions for her own body. We failed our women! Antoinette jadaone‚Äôs SUNSHINE is powerful , poignant, beautiful, and yet heartbreaking which showcases the crisis of young age pregnancy, the taboo and the shame comes with it, hypocrisy of society and being resilient and standing up for yourself and for your dreams over anyone. It‚Äôs not a fairytale, but a hard hitting truth. There is no ending to this cycle of shame for women who are bred in this macho-feudal society, how religion and social taboos remain a bottleneck than a savior. But the movie overcomes those things so bravely and leads a courageous path to tell women to take their rights in their own hands. I really loved the idea of her imaginative child being with her all the time, giving her strength, and emotional support and that final moment between those two is tear jerking. What most people think it was a sad ending, but actually it was not, it was an inspiring ending which reaffirms that every woman should have the right to make a decision for herself. Abortion is actually less cruel than bringing a baby in this hell hole and making its life shitty, when its parents are not capable of taking care of it mentally, physically, financially and emotionally. You are not only ruining one life, but multiple lives.2025 Movies Ranked

Nakakalungkot lang. Basta. It brought me back to the Fangirl days when it gave me the chills about how being a delulu can bring you to your worst disappointments. But this time, Sunshine hits different. When you realize what she did to achieve her dreams, you'd be flabbergasted. It's giving The Unforgivable dilemma. Biktima lang din talaga si Sunshine ng circumstances.Sunshine is just one of the many girls in the society who still get solely blamed for the acts that should also be blamed on the boys. This movie is not just your typical feminist film; it speaks of depth, especially on the challenges of women and the dilemma they face. Isa pa sa nagustuhan ko sa film na to is yung pinadama niya yung hopelessness ni Sunshine. Di naman sa ayaw ko ng movies na binibigyan ng pag-asa ang main character sa huli, pero this served something different and it worked. It's when she was forced to choose between two things, and ended up choosing what's best for her, even if it meant‚Äîbasta. May empathy ka pa din kay Sunshine kahit labag sa iyong kalooban ang kanyang gagawin (as a Filipino Catholic).Sobrang ironic lang din ng title, which I admire. Yung nakita ni Sunshine ang liwanag ng kanyang mga pangarap, pero di man lang nasikatan ng araw ang kanyang‚ÄîAng sa akin lang, ***** Bobot yan ü§¨.

Tipong 13-years-old pinapag-initan ng mga dapat na mag-alaga sa kaniya, si Sunshine na kakatapos lang magdusa na sinermonan pa, magkakasama lahat ng may pregnancy-related cases sa isang ospital, mga babaeng ginagawa ang lahat kahit na 'ilegal' bagamat inclined ang lipunan nila sa paniniwalang espirituwal. Nakakalungkot isipin na ganito pa rin ang sistema, na mayroon pa ring mga kababaihan na nabubuhay tulad ni Sunshine at Mary Grace.

this film is a deeply realistic exploration of what it means to be a woman in the philippines‚Äîa country where patriarchy, tradition, religion, and economic pressure converge in ways that make womanhood both exhausting and precarious. Importantly, the film is not a pro-life statement, nor does it romanticize suffering or prescribe motherhood as a moral imperative. instead, it shows that the choices women face are complex, constrained, and often invisible to those who hold power.it also addresses the ways women navigate survival under these pressures. it shows that women are often responsible for both care work and emotional labor without recognition or support. the everyday reality of harassment, unsafe streets, economic vulnerability, and social judgment creates conditions in which reproductive choice becomes a deeply personal but politically fraught decision. the film does not moralize these choices; it presents them with nuance, empathy, and a refusal to simplify the stakes into a pro-life narrative.at higit sa lahat, thank you, sunshine, sa pagpukpok ng bote sa tito.

This is a blistering, gut-punching film that doesn‚Äôt just ask difficult questions about bodily autonomy and Olympic dreams; it screams them into the humid, chaotic reality of Manila. It‚Äôs a brave, essential piece of cinema that confronts the devastating consequences of living in a country where a woman‚Äôs control over her own body is perpetually under threat. The cinematography is nothing short of breathtaking and utterly visceral‚Äîit‚Äôs relentless, trapping us inside Sunshine‚Äôs suffocating anxiety. Jadaone uses the oppressive visual texture of Quiapo‚Äôs crowded, sweltering streets‚Äîa perfect, gritty backdrop‚Äîto symbolize the labyrinthine journey of a young woman navigating impossible choices in a system designed to fail her.A massive and well-deserved standing ovation goes to the central performances. Maris Racal is devastating as the titular gymnast, embodying the crushing physical and emotional burden with every strained muscle and every desperate, silent plea. Her performance is a masterclass in controlled despair, capturing the agony of a lifetime of sacrifice being threatened in an instant. She is perfectly complemented by Annika Co‚Äôs mesmerizing, eerie, and unrelenting presence as the Kid‚Äîan unsettling narrative device that functions as both Sunshine‚Äôs internal critic and her desperate conscience. But let‚Äôs be real: the film‚Äôs rawest emotional hook comes from the shocking failure and apathy of the men around her. Their irresponsibility and sheer lack of accountability form a central, infuriating symbol of the patriarchal society that traps Sunshine.Ang hirap maging babae sa Pilipinas. Every day feels like a battle against a society na paulit-ulit kang nilalagay sa kahon, insisting that your worth begins and ends with motherhood. Fuck the stigma na finoforce ang mga kababaihan into roles they never agreed to‚Äîparang automatic default na lang na dapat tahimik, dapat magtiis, dapat magpakamartir. Walang puwang para sa sariling pangarap, sariling katawan, sariling desisyon.Kaya sana mas umingay at mas mapag-usapan ang Reproductive Rights‚Äîhindi lang as a ‚Äúwomen‚Äôs issue‚Äù but as a basic human right. This is about giving women the freedom to choose, the safety to seek care without judgment, and the dignity to exist without being shamed or controlled. Hanggang hindi natin tinatalakay nang seryoso ang mga ito, paulit-ulit lang tayo sa cycle ng stigma, trauma, at kawalan ng choices.Being a woman here shouldn't feel like a punishment. It shouldn't demand silence in exchange for survival. And yet, dito sa Pilipinas, ganun pa rin ang realidad‚Äîand that‚Äôs exactly why conversations like this matter.Putangina, Miggy/Miguel na naman!

YOU DID IT AGAIN!first of all, this should be more relevant than it is. being pro choice and growing up somehow religious, I know what other people think of abortion. especially yung mga sagradong katoliko. and that scene where sunshine went to church and immediately begged for forgiveness showcased EXACTLY THAT. (religious guilt!!!) it perfectly captures how the film isn‚Äôt just telling a story, but also reflecting a very real internal conflict na ang daming pinoy women who quietly deals with‚Äîyung clash between what you personally believe is right for your body and what your religion tells you is a sin. ang bigat pakinggan at panoorin."buntis lang ako, 'di to nakakahawa"kahit sa kapwa babae natin di mapipigilan yung judgement eh. kasi ganun yung pagpapalaki satin which is honestly fucked up. and that line hits SO hard because it‚Äôs a commentary on how society treats pregnancy like a moral failure instead of a situation that needs support, empathy, and actual options. the film shows how even other women, who should‚Äôve been supporting you, end up policing each other because yun yung environment na kinalakihan natin. tangina diba?!!?also the irony of buying abortion pills at a church and you can't get a room at a motel ALONE?? the system makes it impossible for women to make decisions about their own bodies, pero at the same time they judge you for every workaround you try to do. also for young girls who get raped and still, THEY have to deal with the consequences. it exposes how the philippines forces women into shame, secrecy, and inconvenience‚Äîand then they act shocked when women feel unsafe or unsupported. it‚Äôs painfully real, and so, so on point.overall, i love this movie because it's honest in a way that most local films are too scared to be. some women don't have a choice, and it's important that WE DO HAVE A CHOICE. LET WOMEN HAVE THEIR DREAMS!!!

it‚Äôs beautiful. it‚Äôs brave. it‚Äôs heavy. it‚Äôs painful.it‚Äôs hard to be a woman. even harder to be a woman in the philippines.one of our professors once told us that our laws are deeply embedded into our culture. that‚Äôs why there‚Äôs no abortion in the philippines‚Ä¶ because of our strong religious beliefs. if you choose abortion as your option, you‚Äôre immediately seen as a murderer, a sinner, by our legal system and, of course, by god‚Äôs law. the same religious beliefs hiding under the skirt of a patriarchal culture, doing nothing but scaring women away from their own choices.sana, ngayon, gets n‚Äôyo na. gets na ng marami.that this kind of decision has never, ever been easy.and i hope that now, we finally push for comprehensive sex education, free check-ups and contraceptives as reproductive health rights, and the legalization of abortion in the philippines, so no woman ever has to resort to unsafe methods while carrying the guilt and the danger all on her own.there are so many deep-rooted problems tied to abortion that we need to confront and tear down. only then can we truly set women free.

first of all, gusto ko rin ng isang ate geleen üò£hands down to maris' restrained but deeply affecting performance. ramdam mo 'yong bawat pag-aalinlangan at takot‚Äîevery moment where the world presses a little too hard on a young girl who only wanted to chase her dream.what makes the film even more powerful is its raw, unflinching portrayal of philippine society. the story exposes how reproductive rights in the country are entangled with religion, shame, and systemic neglect. it shows how a woman's body becomes a public issue the moment it no longer fits moral expectations, and how access to safe, affordable healthcare quickly turns into a privilege instead of a right. ultimately, sunshine champions a woman's right to her body, her choices, and her future‚Äîeven in a society that constantly takes those away.

Nakalimutan ko maglagay ng mga bagay na gusto ko sa Sunshine. Habang pinapanood ko ang Sunshine, naisip ko na ganon talaga kainit, kalagkit, kausok ang Manila (3 months pa lang ako dito). Ganon ako kasweaty gaya ni Sunshine everytime naglalakad sya sa mga kalsada ng Manila. Napakahirap mabuhay sa lugar na to, at tiyak mas mahirap bumuhay ng tao rito. Ang galing mo talaga Maris!May lima akong ate, at gets ko kung gaano kahirap maging babae. At nakita ko sa kanila kung gano kahalaga magkaroon ng autonomy; at sana yon ang reality ng lahat ng kababaihan didto satin. Ang ganda ng mga pelikula gaya ng Sunshine, kasi napag-uusapan natin ang mga bagay na dapat noon pa man ay napag-uusapan na. Ang aborsyon ay karapatan ng kababaihan. Ang pagccriminalize dito ay nakakaendanger lang sa buhay ng mga babae. Thanks direk!Napaisip din ako kanina pagkatapos kong mapanood ang Sunshine, na sana in the future ay malegalize na talaga ang aborsyon, and if ito ay malelegalize man ay sana magkaroon din ako ng opportunities to train. Yon lang!

What stayed with me long after the credits rolled is how Sunshine understands the quiet corners of being young. The ones filled with fear you don‚Äôt even have language for yet, and the hope you still hold anyway. The film doesn‚Äôt chase shock value; instead, it trusts stillness, letting the soft ache of its characters speak for themselves.And then there‚Äôs that storyline about the 13-year-old girl, pregnant because of her own uncle. OH GOD. That shattered me. It‚Äôs horrifying, devastating, and the film doesn‚Äôt sanitize the truth of it. It shows how violence like that hides inside families, how children are left carrying consequences for sins that were never theirs. I felt so much grief and anger for that kid; it‚Äôs the kind of scene that makes you sit there and go quiet because it hurts in a very real way. The film‚Äôs exploration of choice, shame, and the pressure to ‚Äúgrow up correctly‚Äù hits even harder because of moments like that. It never lectures. It simply shows how heavy it is to carry circumstances shaped by adults who should‚Äôve protected you. Maris Racal delivers an immaculate kind of devastation in this role. There‚Äôs a sharpness to every look she gives, a trembling truth in every word, that feels painfully real. She breaks open the character‚Äôs longing, lets the fear spill out raw, and turns her strength into something that rises slowly from the wreckage. It‚Äôs a performance that destroys you and stays spotless in its honesty.Sunshine is the kind of film that lingers. Soft, bruising, furious when it needs to be, and quietly bright in all the places that matter.

A challenging plot to bring to the screen and a harsh and sad reality for many women. The strong hold religion has over the Philippines is especially frustrating. The hospital scene where you would expect empathy from the doctor pissed me off. The pastor and Miggy especially bothered me ‚Äî Miggy because he‚Äôs a little shit and the pastor because his reaction reminded me of my father. Other people can get away with abortion because they have the money so they can just go freely with their lives, but for younger women like Sunshine and Ariana, it‚Äôs life or death. Ariana‚Äôs situation is especially heavy, something I‚Äôve heard about from people I know. This film is going to bother me for a while.

Sunshine (2024) serves as a powerful and eye-opening film, especially for us Filipinos. As someone working in the healthcare field, I believe the movie highlights an important truth: abortion should not be treated as a taboo subject or inherently immoral. Whether we acknowledge it or not, there are women who do not wish to become pregnant or are not ready to become mothers. Criminalizing abortion does not stop it from happening; it merely drives women toward unsafe procedures that place their lives at greater risk.If one personally identifies as pro-life, then one has the choice not to pursue abortion. However, holding that belief does not grant anyone the authority to dictate or restrict what women can do with their own bodies, especially when they do not contribute to the wellbeing of the child these women may be forced to bear. The health, autonomy, and safety of women must remain our priority. It is time to end the stigma surrounding reproductive choices and to uphold the separation of religion and state in policymaking.

Ang pelikulang Sunshine ay hindi lang simpleng kwento ng isang babae‚Äîisa itong salamin sa maraming isyung matagal nang umiikot sa Pilipinas pero pilit pa ring isinasantabi. Nagawa ng pelikula ito na ilahad ang mga sakit ng sistemang kinabibilangan natin: mula sa pakikibaka ng kababaihan sa kanilang sariling katawan hanggang sa nakakalungkot na estado ng ating healthcare system.Isa sa pinakamalinaw na ipinupukol ng pelikula ay ang isyu ng aborsyon. Ipinapakita ng pelikula kung gaano kahirap ang desisyong hinaharap ng mga kababaihan‚Äîlalo na sa bansang halos bawal pag-usapan ang reproductive rights. Nakakahalit dahil hanggang ngayon, marami pa ring kababaihan ang hindi ganap na malaya sa sarili nilang katawan dahil sa malalim na kapit ng konserbatismong relihiyoso. Sa halip na suportahan, hinuhusgahan sila. Sa halip na pakinggan, pinapatahimik. At gaya ng ipinapakita sa pelikula, napipilitang harapin ng mga babae ang mga sitwasyong hindi nila pinili, wala man lang ligtas o legal na option para makaligtas..Kasunod nito, mariing binabangga ng pelikula ang realidad ng ating healthcare system. Hindi na bago ang nakikitang eksena sa ospital: siksikan, kulang sa gamit, at kapos sa espasyo. Dalawa, minsan tatlong ina sa iisang kama‚Äîhindi dahil gusto nila, kundi dahil wala talagang mapaglagyan. Ito ang reyalidad na hinaharap ng ordinaryong Pilipino araw-araw, habang ang mga pulitikong may kapangyarihan ay kayang lumipad paabroad para magpagamot sa mas kumpletong pasilidad.Sa kabuuan, nagsilbing boses ang Sunshine para sa mga isyung matagal nang dinidinig ngunit hindi pinakikinggan. Maris Racal did her best one on this. Kudos!

This movie was fun to watch in terms of its setting. I have been to the gym Sunshine was training in and also the Rizal Sports Complex because I have trained there before in 2015!Argh, teenage pregnancy in the Philippines stems from the lack of sex education and advocacy for contraceptives and abortion. The fact that we are a mostly Catholic-dominated country or population that strongly adheres to tradition makes it harder for pregnant teenagers to find support. They are made to feel ashamed and helpless because even the law says that abortion is illegal, meaning that they do not have a choice but to deliver the child. Sunshine's passion was found in gymnastics, something that she couldn't let go of. She knew that if she were to become a mother (which she isn't ready for, as she explicitly states during her conversation with Miguel and his father), she would have to surrender everything she has worked hard for. Her sister's situatio, who was a former gymnast as well, basically shows that Sunshine's life would eventually become just like hers if she were to proceed with the pregnancy. The doctor was so annoying because that's exactly how the older generation sounds like when stating their opinions about religion, abortion, and chilbirth.I also liked the fact that they tackled topics like sex, autonomy, rape, and incest. These are very real in the Philippines and the situation with Ariana and his sister (?) greatly displayed how messed up it is. These children have no choice or power over their elders and what makes it sad is that those who should be protecting them are the ones putting them in danger and ruining their lives.I read somewhere that the little girl that followed Sunshine was her unborn child. I also thought of this throughout the movie and it even made more sense when the little girl said "Gets ko na" after Sunshine practiced her piece with a passionate smile and aura that could be felt by the audience.I love that Sunshine chose herself and her dreams over being a mother. A child born into this world who would eventually live in substandard conditions just because people say they should be born won't truly experience a life that should be lived.

Ganda. A harrowing, claustrophobic, yet essential sprint across Manila streets. The craft here really shines, at just 90 or so minutes the film feels tightly-paced and confidently crafted through Jadaone's masterful direction, yet it still swings wide over several discussions and thoughts over its major theme in an arguably short amount of time. Mind you there's an element here that I'm not the biggest fan of-- I think the film could have actually eliminated it altogether as it feels inelegant especially against the overt realism of the rest of the film. But otherwise it's easy to overlook this compared to how wise the rest of the film is. It culminates in a truly lovely finale that uses simplicity to great, moving effect, especially when juxtaposed to how much noise and haste the rest of the film's heavy atmosphere is. Gets ko na why "Gets ko na" became an easily recognisable, even arguably iconic line from this film.Besides the stellar direction, the rest of the departments here really shine. The camera and production design really stand out here, painting a crowded and cramped world. The performances are simply captivating. Maris Racal truly carries this hefty narrative, but Annika Co really exudes such natural confidence that steals the scene whenever she appears. Ultimately, this really feels like important cinema from simply one of the best Filipino filmmakers out there.

Sobrang tapang ng pelikulang 'to. Sobrang tapang ni direk tonet. Sobrang tapang ni Sunshine. Sobrang tapang ng mga kababaihang nagpapatuloy, lumalaban sa mga hamon ng lipunan. Dinala ako ng pelikulang 'to sa kung anong klaseng lipunan ang kailangang harapin ng mga kababaihan araw-araw ‚Äî lahat ng husga, dikta, at pangungurakot. Wala sa kahit anong batas or salita ng diyos ang makatutulong sa mga taong kagaya ni Sunshine, kung 'di ang maayos na health care system, maayos at tapat na gobyerno, at isang mapagpalayang lipunan ‚Äî malaya sa kahit anong dikta at husga ng mga taong hindi kailanma'y namroblema sa kanilang kaligtasan kapag maglalakad mag-isa sa madilim na kalsada, sa kanilang kasuotan at pananamit, sa kung anong pananaw ng iba sa kanilang katawan, sa kakayahan makapag-luwal ng anak, sa mga tingin at pagnanasa ng mga mabababang-uri, at sa mga marami pang bagay. Napakaraming aspeto ng pelikulang Sunshine ang paulit-ulit sinasampal sa atin para lang magising sa realidad ang bulok na lipunang 'to. Isa na rito ang pagbibigay sa mga kababaihan ang kalayaang mamili, kalayaang magdesisyon, at kalayaang mangarap, kasama ang proteksyon para sa mga batang katulad ni Mary Grace.Ilang kababaihan at bata pa ba ang kinakailangang maranasan ang hirap nina Sunshine at Mary Grace bago mamulat at umusad ang lipunang sakop pa rin ng makalumang pananaw ‚Äî mga pananaw na hindi nila alam ay unti-unting ginigilitan at pinapatay ang karapatan, kalayaan, at kakayahan ng mga kababaihan. Ang mga taong tulad nina Bobot, nanay ni Mary Grace, at Miggy ang tunay na lumalabag sa sa utos ng diyos, ang tunay na gumagawa ng krimen, at ang tunay sa nagpapabulok pa sa inuuod na sistema para sa mga kababaihan at bata, hindi ang mga taong tulad ni Sunshine na pinanghahawakan ang karapatan nilang mangarap at magkaroon ng desisyon para sa kanilang sariling katawan. Tangina gaano ba kahirap isipin yon?Napakaganda ng cinematography. Lahat ng baho, usok, lagkit, at sikip ng Maynila; lahat ng mga matang mapanghusga, mga taong makasarili, mga komentong nananakal, at bigat na dala-dala araw-araw ng mga babae at bata, lahat ito ipinakita. Ibang klaseng sining ang ipinakita nina direk tonet, maris, jennica, annika, at sa lahat ng cast ng pelikula.Mahigpit na yakap para sa lahat ng Sunshine na patuloy bumabangon at lumalaban. Abante, babae!

This film really reminded me that sometimes even the most seemingly trivial decisions‚Äîlike whether to use a condom or not by relying on the excuse of pulling out‚Äîcan have huge effects on one‚Äôs life. It also shows how having no access to proper medical care for abortion (since it is illegal) is so unfair, especially for children who were taken advantage of, which leads them to use unsafe methods that put their lives at risk. I really applaud Sunshine‚Äôs determination to chase her dreams and stay strong in the face of her friends ignoring her and her boyfriend not wanting to take responsibility for their child. Aside from her, I also applaud her family for staying by her side regardless of what her decision may be. I applaud this film for showing the hardships of being a woman‚Äîspecifically, a woman in the Philippines‚Äîsurrounded by noise, distractions, and judgment.

"Naiintindihan mo na?""Gets ko na."Whenever somebody asks me why I support abortion, I will ask them to watch this film‚Äîespecially now that it is widely accessible through Netflix. The ability to choose for a woman's own welfare and decide for the future of a child is a fundamental right, it should never be a debate. Bodily autonomy is a human right. We can use religious morals as a basis to weigh the decision but NEVER force it on somebody and leverage that same bullshit to guilt-trip them. Safe-sex should be promoted not shushed by religious parties; accessible care for abortion should be a must We shouldn't demonize doctors and women who want that for themselves. Like the line, "Flush out the noise", these unneeded external noises should never be heard in the first place, all throughout the film it catches up to Sunshine. Hangang, hanga, ako sa'yo Sunshine. Dreams should never be impeded because of a mistake, she's still a teen who's transitioning to adulthood. She should be allowed to live her life not being worried about a child she never wanted in the first place. And to all the women out there, who's met with arguably stronger hostility, I hope that laws, people, the Philippines becomes more friendly to you. It should be like that. I never doubted Maris Racal's ability to act, and all I can say is they found jackpot by casting her as Sunshine and casting Annika as the little girl that appears all throughout the film. P.S. that Uncle deserved so much more than breaking a bottle on their head.

A disturbingly realistic film that tackles on the disadvantages of living in a country that criminalizes abortion‚Äîdiscouraging women‚Äôs bodily autonomy and integrity, huge risks on women‚Äôs reproductive health, and so on.It is a dark cinematic film that does not only impress one with its amazing visuals and role portrayal from the cast lineup, but also leaves you pondering on the bold message it screams throughout.

Maris Racal is ready for leading roles, and Sunshine gives her everything to work with. It helps that a stellar ensemble of women round out the supporting roles too, with Annika Co haunting her like an undeniable reality. Its plot, certainly a conversation-starter, doesn't all the way succeed with all its creative choices, but it's welcome forward motion for showing that women's choices command respect even if it doesn't fit the ones you decide for yourself. Another thing everyone should agree on is that Antoinette Jadaone has her finger on the pulse of what Filipinos, and the cinephile-going population of the country, need to discuss.

‚Äúusapang bata to!‚Äù‚Äùbakit? bata rin naman ako!‚Äùa striking detail that struck me the most is the contrast between the very first time we watch sunshine step onto the mat and the last time she ever does. at first, you hear this deep and intense noise of her drowning the music, her choach‚Äôs instructions, and even the sound of her own breathing. and the noise only goes louder and harsher each time we see her practice her routine while she quietly endures the devastating ordeal of attempting to terminate her pregnancy. what started off as a sound to describe her pressure and desperation to reach her olympic dreams, now becomes the sound of her fear, her secrecy, and her grief. this says so much about what it means to be a woman in the philippines: how suffering must be hidden, how autonomy becomes something to apologize for, and how you‚Äôre expected to quietly tend to your own wounds you never asked to carry.and sunshine carries her decision with guilt, so much that she looks at the unnamed young girl like she‚Äôs staring at every version of her future that never got the chance to choose. but she dreams. she dreams so much. and she dreams for more. and she stands firm, because what‚Äôs so wrong about wanting a life that belongs to her? what‚Äôs so wrong about refusing to be swallowed by sacrifice? what‚Äôs so wrong about refusing to become another woman she didn‚Äôt want to be?‚Äúgets ko na.‚Äùso as we see the last time she practices on the mat, we finally hear the sound of the music, not the deep sound of pressure of fear, but a rhythm that finally belongs to her. the gymnasium is dark, she‚Äôs alone and she‚Äôs pale, but this is the brightest she has ever looked in the past hour i‚Äôve watched the film. she moves with a softness that feels earnest, like this is the first time her body isn‚Äôt performing to impress or survive, only to exist. she dances gracefully, probably the most she ever has, and it‚Äôs a moment that shows us that she has unapologetically reclaimed something no one ever thought she deserved: the right to choose herself. and for the first time, she is no longer a girl she‚Äôs afraid to be‚Äîshe is a woman who has already decided.i hope more people watch sunshine (2024) not to criticize women with early and unintended pregnancies, but to meet them with grace and empathy for their fears, their confusion, and their fight to claim what should have always been theirs in the first place‚Äîtheir autonomy, dignity, and right to have access to healthcare without being made to beg for it.patuloy nating pahalagahan ang kalusugan, karapatan, at mga kwento ng kababaihan üíôminus half star kasi parang kaya pa natin i-improve yung dialogues, direk?? Philippine cinema is not dead and Sunshine is a living proof of it. this film has so much emotional depth and thought-provoking scenes that captures perfectly what it feels like to be a woman living in a patriarchal society- in a country where hypocrisy runs rampant and making decisions for yourself is often frowned upon. why is it that women are the ones always blamed, shackled and punished for choices they make- choices driven by the need to prioritize their health and safety in situations they did not fully create? Antoinette Jadaone's best film yet so far, and i'd say it because of its boldness, for addressing an elephant, a taboo topic that most of us are not ready to talk about, but eventually we must. it's already hard enough that we don't have proper access to healthcare, even worse to be scrutinized by society simply for choosing yourself.
