‚ÄùAy nako! Talaga naman ang mga kabataan ngayon hindi na makapagpigil.‚ÄùThroughout Sunshine, there are several adult figures that do not listen to Sunshine, blinded by either their convictions or Filipino societal norms. They push Sunshine on what she must do: pray, seek forgiveness, give the baby a life, be a mom, and pray. In the adults‚Äô eyes, Sunshine is not a nineteen-year-old Filipina in Manila going to school and practice. To the adults, Sunshine is already a mom.On Saturday, the Filipino noontime show It‚Äôs Showtime invited parents with 7 or more children for their game Laro, Laro, Pick. A majority of the contestants were women, and two of the mothers interviewed, Elsa and Rosalie, had 15 and 8 children respectively. Elsa, the 63-year-old woman with 12 living children and 3 deceased children recited the ages of her 12 children from the oldest, 46, to the youngest, 24. The gap between the older ones is 1-2 years apart, while the younger ones are about 2-3 years apart. Elsa confesses how difficult life is for her and her children, spouting how without God she would not be as strong as she is today, living off 300 pesos everyday. When Vice Ganda asked Elsa why she has so many children, Elsa plainly said, ‚ÄúEhhh di ako marunong mag family planning eh,‚Äù inciting some laughter in the audience. Elsa even revealed that the father was absent and had a different family, leaving the Filipina mother and her 12 living children to figure out how to live.The second woman, Rosalie, with 8 children echoed the same sentiments as Elsa. She sells sampaguita every day with no days off at the age of 60 something; her children married and had their children early; the highest level of schooling one of her children attained was high school, but never graduated; her children sell sampaguita with no days off; and she has 19 grandchildren to look after in a home with no roof above their heads.What Sunshine, Elsa, and Rosalie have in common is how the patriarchy confines them to suffocating religious ideals, a corrupt and conservative government, and poor healthcare. What Sunshine does not have in common with the two women is the ignorance in family planning. Sunshine is no one's mother! It should never be a reason to have 7 or more children at an early age, with no means of support financially and emotionally, because it is "God's gift," or because they simply want to experience having children. The favorite catchphrase, "Kase malakas ako, kaya ko to" can only thrive for so long with honesty until oppressors abuse the Filipina determination. Access to sexual education MUST be a right, not a privilege nor a taboo subject. Children do not decide when they want to be born, so there should be conscious efforts to assess if the environment people live in can secure their children's/childrens' future(s), especially in a country like the Philippines. Unfortunately, there are connections to poverty and the lack of interest and access to proper education. There is also the inability for Filipinos in poverty to seek other options, or have the real agency to pursue aspirations. While there is such thing as being irresponsible, Filipino women are a laughingstock in conversations surrounding teen pregnancy and reproductive rights‚Äîwhen realistically‚Äîthey should have the choice to protect themselves, but are instead ruthlessly flayed off by the very system that commands kindness.[Minor spoilers ahead]Annika Co manifests herself as (what I think) Sunshine's Catholic guilt. We first meet Annika after Sunshine prays outside of Quiapo Church and is about to light a cigarette. Annika appears whenever Sunshine does something that will affect the fetus, and often berates Sunshine for being "bad." At first, I was hesitant towards the idea of Annika representing Sunshine's potential child, because it can mistakenly support the pro-life argument of murder (which Annika actually yells at Sunshine), until Annika says, "ang pangarap ko ay pangarap niya." SOBRANG bigat yung line na yan! In a sense, Sunshine and Annika are the same person. Sunshine should be able to pursue her dreams successfully the same way Annika, along with other living and future children, should feel secure enough to be ambitious. The message further builds itself with Ariana, Annika's friend and the 13-year-old girl's potential child. Ariana wants to be the first gay president, but how can they do that in an environment with a r*pist, a neglectful grandmother, and a KID whose choice was stolen?If mothers like Elsa and Rosalie can somehow "get away" with no family planning, how can Sunshine and the 13-year-old girl survive in a Catholic Philippines? The Reproductive Health Law was passed in December 2012, and efforts to educate the masses and distribute contraceptives have improved, yet there is still a high percentage of unintended pregnancies, AIDS rates, and JUSKO PO‚ÄîISSUES WITH BUDGETING (source 1),(source 2) !!!!!! The Philippines will never progress as a nation if objectivity is blocked by the grip the church and the state have on one another, which ultimately and consistently harms Filipinas who give their best yesterday, today, and tomorrow.I am certain that Sunshine is not the first film to be unapologetically bold and loud for the Filipina, but it is certainly the first to make rounds among the casual movie-goers and the general Filipino. It is not a perfect film and such flawed instances are where:- the narrative of Sunshine being an Olympic-level athlete clashes with the lack of popularity shown outside of practice- the cinematography is poetic without a doubt, but the scenes of Sunshine messaging her Coach, Miggy, and Thea isn't synchronized with Sunshine typing on the phone/isn't even her actually texting. If you're going to place emphasis on the quietest scenes, I believe that something as minor as texting should be clean (this was the same quip I had with the controller scene in Anora like c'mon now....)- the cinematography can be too poetic. for example, the shot of Sunshine looking out of her hotel window with the Metro Manila noise juxtaposing her quiet turmoil contributes to Sunshine purposely not drowning out the noise (or the failure to?), but I found it unnecessary because right after she woke up in pain. the juxtaposition felt like it was purely for aesthetics- the Jojo Rabbit esque character of Annika and Ariana was VERY risky (re: pro-life arguments)- maybe it's just me but the film gives you some breathers with comedic aspects in things like "no bad words" and Annika proceeding to say "putangina" which I found myself like "damn girl ! ! !" though it makes me wonder if those who do not share the same ideals as me laughed at it the same way the audience laughed at Elsa in Laro Laro Pick. In a not long-winding way, and assuming negatively, if tonal shifts struck the audience as a serious matter and not a reactionary narrative.- the last 3 paragraphs of this review regarding how art can effectively stand by its purposeAng hirap maging isang Sunshine sa Pilipinas, at hindi pinaguusapan kahit eto ang reality ng karamihan ng babae at batang babae. Women can dream for themselves. Women can learn to protect for themselves if there are resources available by sources that make themselves available. Women are strong, but you cannot glorify them to always be strong at the expense of exploitation. Sunshine is many of the first steps in Philippine cinema that can continue the conversation. I hope the film incites action in Filipinos to call out the current and future administration, who, under the guise of a devotee to a forgiving religion, perpetuates being uncritical and whose laziness is a disservice to the Filipino people. And most importantly, may Filipinos denounce the administration's vigor in committing violence against them, and reclaim the autonomy all Filipinos are born with.

I know this movie feels heavy and complicated the first time you watch it. It‚Äôs about a girl who is struggling against the world and against herself. She loses her way, and she could lose her dreams if she doesn‚Äôt stand up to the world.From this movie, I learned one important thing in life, everyone has their own problems, different kinds of problems. But the important thing is what you choose to do when you‚Äôre going through something difficult and nobody is there to help you. Even when you feel alone, useless, or hopeless, don‚Äôt give up. You can still reach what you want and chase your dreams. Just keep going and keep fighting.As a man, I feel sorry for Sunshine, but believe me, there are many good men in this world better than selfish and stupid men and I learned from this movie how to be a better man. Use protection when you‚Äôre doing something intimate, and if you don‚Äôt, make sure you can take responsibility for your actions. Live wisely and don‚Äôt make rushed decisions. Every choice you make shapes your future. We may not regret our actions in the moment, but we regret them later.And for other men, I want to say this if you have a girlfriend, make sure she‚Äôs happy with you. Don‚Äôt be rude to her, and don‚Äôt ruin her life because of your desires. As a man, I promise myself that I'll be better. I‚Äôll treat women with respect, and I'll never raise my hand when we have problems or arguments.

This is truly one of the best Filipino films this year. It takes courage to empower abortion and women‚Äôs rights in a country that has been conservative and patriarchal for the longest time. I really really loved how the film doesn‚Äôt shy away from unraveling the realities of a Filipino woman. The crowded and unorganized public hospitals, the irony of churches and black markets, and the innate nature of self-righteous men trying to dictate a woman‚Äôs life. There should be more movies like this marketed to the mainstream media. Looking forward to Maris‚Äô future projects, galing niya as always!

i want to say a lot of things about this movie pero ang hirap niya i-form into words. pero una sa lahat, i love this film. umpisa palang, ang bigat na sa feeling manuod. siguro kasi i‚Äôve been to those places? na it felt too real. lahat ng sulok na dinaanan ni sunshine at mga lugar na tinakbuhan niya, parang nandon lang din ako. i know some will say na maling desisyon yung mga ginawa ni sunshine pero ano na bang pwede niyang gawin? sa bansang walang maayos at ligtas na healthcare para sa mga kababaihan, saan pa siya lalapit? kahit nung dinala siya sa ospital dahil sa epekto nung pampalaglag, hinusgahan pa siya. ganyan ang estado ng healthcare ng mga kababaihan dito sa bansang to. i love the ‚Äúwhat should have been her daughter‚Äù na character na sinusundan si sunshine sa bawat sulok ng maynila. alam natin sa umpisa palang na ayaw ni sunshine maging nanay at gagawa siya ng paraan para magpalaglag. pero hindi parin mawawala yung parang ‚Äúguilt‚Äù na meron ang isang babae lalo na‚Äôt lumaki tayo sa katolikong bansa. kita rin ito dun sa pagpunta ni sunshine sa simbahan tuwing dumadaan siya sa quiapo. mahirap siguro hindi isipin ang mga ‚Äúwhat ifs‚Äù pero kung hindi handa ang isang babae maging nanay, hindi siya handa. dapat ganun lang kadali. i also like how they added the side story of mary grace. kasi totoo naman. ano ang gagawin ng isang babae (at sa lagay ni mary grace na 13 palang) kapag ni-r*pe siya ng tito niya? hindi kailanman magiging handa maging ina ang labintatlong gulang na bata lalo na‚Äôt bunga ito ng abuse sa bahay. also ang galing ni maris! sobrang husay niya sa pelikulang ito. kahit yung mga mata-mata acting lang, damang dama ko. you can say anything you want about maris pero no one can say anything bad when it comes to her as an actress. ang dami ko pang naiisip and i think i need days to reflect and form my thoughts pero ang masasabi ko ay we needed a movie like this sa pinas. kailangan talaga marinig ang mga kwento gaya ni sunshine (at ni mary grace).

‚ÄúGets ko na.‚ÄùIn a country like the Philippines, where everyone has an opinion on your body except you, this film hits a nerve that‚Äôs been aching for a long time. The way the film shows her struggle, the shame, the fear, the judgment, the dreams she‚Äôs forced to postpone, feels like a mirror held up to countless Filipina girls who had to grow up too fast. You can feel how her choices are never just hers; they‚Äôre tied to religion, family, and the weight of ‚Äúdapat‚Äù at ‚Äúbawal.‚ÄùBut what makes Sunshine beautiful is how it refuses to punish her for wanting more. For wanting herself.When she finally chooses her dreams, finally chooses herself and it doesn‚Äôt feel selfish. It feels like survival. Like finally stepping out of a shadow she never asked to stand under.This is a reminder that a woman‚Äôs future shouldn‚Äôt be treated like a sin.And that the sun doesn‚Äôt ask permission to shine‚Ä¶ it just does.The best Filipino Film of 2025.

Ayokong maging nanay! Ano bang pakielam nyo?!Followed by her Ate's support is what every young woman's response to people trying to dictate what to do with her body. not when she's not ready, not whenever. In this world, we need an ate like her, Dok Helena, and ate pharmacist who completely shows support no matter what her decisions, does not have malicious mindset and judgmental tendencies. Sunshine reflects the reality all young women face, the struggles of being a woman in a religious third world country and it is so brave to create this kind of film, so kudos to Direk Antonette Jadaone, Maris Racal, and to everyone behind this. Sunshine's bravery for fighting for what she wants, her exercising her rights, and her choices are what young women of today should follow. It is important to see how women who plan to abort or did abort are NOT completely cruel nor sinners, as they also have a conscience and dilemma as they go through every consideration. Her conscience, being represented by "bata," goes to show how she considered having her, but of course it all just boils down to her body, her choices, and her future. And the rights to have access in safe abortions does NOT only applies to rape victims but all WOMEN. ABORTION IS HEALTH CARE. AND ACCESS TO HEALTHCARE IS HUMAN RIGHTS. Sunshine showed how hard it is to receive health care in the philippines; that we resort to what is accessible even if it meant danger for herself. This is sad but this is reality. do i love this movie because i relate to it the most or because it is beautifully written and perfectly carved for this generation? either way, hands down to everyone who took part in this film. a solid watch. people often says that our society has become "pro women"‚Äîfrom the laws created to protect and empower us to the countless celebrations of women‚Äôs lives. pero, matatawag mo bang pro women ang isang lipunan kung babae lang ang naipapako sa tuwing nagbubunga ang isang bagay na hindi lang sya ang gumawa? sunshine had to go through everything‚Äîbuying the pregnancy test kits on her own, enduring the crippling anxiety while waiting for the result, desperately seeking help in terminating a pregnancy she wasn‚Äôt ready for, and then facing judgment from almost everyone around her. and ano yung na-experience ng boyfriend nya? napagalitan, siguro, pero he had the fucking audacity to chill while the girl he knocked up had gone through all phases of desperation and grief. and he thought one conversation with her, plus his dad, and he really thought that would fix everything? bffr. this is our society. despite the progressive movements, women are still seen as an object that can be controlled, blamed, and burdened with responsibilities others refuse to share.i am proud of sunshine for choosing herself.

Not much to be "gained" from watching this movie even though the topic is considered taboo in the PH. Watching it reminded of "Anora" but with much less nuance and entertainment. Felt like a wasted opportunity to have Maris Racal be the lead but without a real plot to actually steer. Was it a censorship issue?? I don't understand why they would choose such a topic and not really have a stance on it. Maybe the creators themselves are also confused as to being pro-choice or pro-life, as are most Filipinos due to their religious beliefs (I'm assuming). I'm just saying, if you didn't want to get "too" political by having a clearer opinion in the film, then it's probably best to take more time and do more research about the topic, or just make another kind of movie.

it's no surprise to me that a lot of filipinos will misunderstand the whole point and premise of this movie. ang pagb-buntis ng maaga ay madalas nakikita lamang bilang topic ng chismis ng marami kaya di na ko nagulat na madami ang di nakakaintindi sa istorya ni sunshine. i love the inclusion of mary grace in the story, it's a bleak reminder that the women who want and need to get abortions aren't always the stereotyped madonna who's into casual sex,(granted women shouldn't have to fit into a "perfect victim" image just to be granted bodily autonomy) but they are also minors who were victims of rape from family members. mary grace's story adds so much to how deeply the film tackles the conversation around abortion as well as making it known to the audience that abortion is not a black and white subject. additionally, it also does a good job in portraying the role of men in these women's lives as well as how little guilt they shoulder from something they also took part in. sobrang little ng guilt at remorse na nararamdaman nila miggy at yung tito ni mary grace. the fact that miggy was only able to help and apologize to sunshine when his father was involved was so putangina. if male audacity had a poster child it would be him. never fucking trust a man (period) who says his "pull out" game is strong, especially if that motherfucker is named miggy and talks like he consumes red pill content on the daily.

what hit me the most was how the film shows society‚Äôs pressure without ever yelling at you. the judgement, the shame, the rules you‚Äôre supposed to follow ‚Äî it‚Äôs all there, always in the background, shaping every choice she makes. but then there are these tiny moments of kindness, little glimmers of hope, and it‚Äôs those moments that make the sadness bearableyou really feel her pain, her confusion, her stubborn spark to survive and keep dreaming, even when everything seems against her. and the story doesn‚Äôt give you easy answers ‚Äî it just lets you sit with the reality of what it‚Äôs like to be a girl in a world that doesn‚Äôt make it easypero na-realize ko na the girl who follows sunshine and calls her ‚Äúmurderer‚Äù is not a real person. she represents the harsh judgment sunshine feels from others and the guilt she carries inside herself. the girl is basically the voice of society telling sunshine she did something wrong, even when the situation is more complicated. she‚Äôs also sunshine‚Äôs own fear and self-blame turned into a person. in short, the girl is the symbol of the guilt and pressure that keep haunting sunshineyung nasa jeep scene fav ko kasi pinakita na how overwhelmed sunshine is without her having to say a word. while she‚Äôs sitting in the jeep, everything around her feels loud, messy, and fast‚Äîparang tuloy-tuloy yung mundo habang siya, nakastuck. when she starts crying quietly, it shows how much she‚Äôs been holding in for so long

‚Äúpangarap ko rin ang mga pangarap mo, sunshine‚ÄùUGHHHHH ugly crying right now bc it‚Äôs all too real. tangina. ang ganda. kuhang kuha ang lagay ng maynila‚Äîang madidilim na eskinita, run-down motels, yung lagkit, yung dumi, at yung mga pangarap na hindi man lang makapigtas sa kanilang kamalayan. i started this movie with my mom and my sister and i kept on going wt my furious commentary; bakit ko pa daw pinapanood kung nakakatakot? nakakatakot kasi totoo. kung magiging babae, bakit sa pilipinas pa? sa bawat sulok may mga umaalingawngaw na tigang, ang pagtangkklik sayo kasi ika nga ‚Äúhorny‚Äù sila, pag-ostracize at pag-iskandalo, yung preachy tangents nila para lang itemper ang karamdaman mo, the misogny, the commodification, the devastating __ of it all. yung paglagay ng bag sa harap kasi baka manakawan, yung pagtago ng pampalaglag sa mga imahen ni mama mary, at yung desperasyon (mula sa labas ng simbahan kasi ikaw ay naging ‚Äúmakasalanan) sa musmos at awa ng diyos. sa kinaingay at sulasok ng siyudad, nariyan ang mga pusong may kinakapitang mga pangarap; at kung kailan andyan na ang pinakaninanais mo, wala ka nga palang karapatan sa iyong katawan. mas alam pa ng mga doktor at gagong hindi mo kilala ang gagawin sa sinapupunan mo. ‚Äòyan si sunshine. at ‚Äòyan rin kamigrowing up in a devout catholic household in a predominantly catholic-practicing country, mahirap ang maging progressive. there are days na makikipagdebate ako sa parents ko at matatapos sa mga dabog at pagkulong sa mga kwarto. bilang pro-choice, bilang babae, at bilang isang tao, wala talagang ikakukumpara yung mental process of choosing between your dream and something that wasn‚Äôt even in your control (kasi nga sabi hindi ipuputok sa loob)‚Äîthis movie has it all: the catholic guilt, yung mga minuto ng katahimikang naaaning dahil sa kakaisip, yung lito at pagkamatigas sa iyong desisyon. i‚Äôd like to imagine sunshine lived the ribbon kasi nakokontrol niya ito: na sa bawat pitik ng kamay sumusunod ang ribbon na kahit anong gawin ay maganda tignan at delikadesa mahulog, kahit anong buhol, kaya pa ring mahulas, kahit anong gulo sa galaw, maganda pa ring ang kinalalabasan. GRABE. sunshine, with her ribbon, was able to be free on the mat. now, clad in her shimmering pink and purple bedazzled spandex, she walks out with the brightest smile in her force and, like the ribbon she‚Äôs been acquainted with since childhood, is finally able to take control of her own life. Putangina, hanggang ngayon, ang daming lalaking nag-aakalang may karapatan silang magpasya para sa katawan ng babae. What stays with you long after Sunshine ends is how the film treats every moment as something pulled straight from real Filipino girlhood. You see it in the small, mundane ways Sunshine tries to keep herself together like the way she tightens her jaw during training to hide the panic creeping up her spine, how she forces a neutral expression when adults around her throw judgment disguised as concern and the humiliation of realizing everyone expects her to handle a crisis she never chose.Girls grow up by being punished for becoming women. Sunshine is still a teenager, but the moment her pregnancy becomes known, people start talking to her like she owes them maturity, penance, and accountability she was never taught to carry.When Pastor Jaime steps in, offering moral pressure, you can feel the room closing in on her again. Everyone wants her to be a mother. Everyone thinks they have the right to her future. Despite all that pressure, Sunshine‚Äôs refusal hits like a rupture in a system built to control her.

[ system log : 001 ]user : haziah | age : 23status : active // processingI liked Sunshine because it speaks volumes about the lack of real sex education among teenagers‚Äîhow so many are left to navigate consequences without ever being given proper knowledge, guidance, or protection. It shows how quickly people are forced into rigid sides‚Äîpro-choice or pro-life‚Äîwithout being allowed the space to exist as confused, scared, and human first. I didn‚Äôt like it only because Maris Racal‚Äôs acting was phenomenal‚Äîraw, restrained, and painfully real‚Äîbut because the film chose to center understanding instead of judgment. It didn‚Äôt sensationalize the situation; it made you sit with it.I liked it because it treated the experience as what it truly is: a life-altering moment that cannot be simplified into slogans, morals, or online arguments. It showed how heavy one decision can feel when the world is already crashing down on you. I liked it because it refuses to make the audience comfortable. It doesn‚Äôt beg for sympathy, it doesn‚Äôt chase approval, and it doesn‚Äôt try to make itself digestible for everyone.And most of all, I liked it because it never tells you what the ‚Äúright‚Äù answer is. It simply lays everything bare and lets you face it on your own. It allows you to choose what to feel, what to believe, and what to carry after the credits roll.Some people say it lacked something‚Äîespecially in its length‚Äîthat it should‚Äôve been longer, that it ended too soon. But I don‚Äôt agree. I think it had to end exactly where it did. Because some stories aren‚Äôt meant to be over-explained. Some experiences don‚Äôt offer neat closures. The ending didn‚Äôt feel incomplete to me‚Äîit felt honest.

"naiintindihan mo ba ako?"Sunshine, at its core, is a film that aims to make the people who watch truly understand. hopefully to also change minds but for that to happen, dapat maintindihan muna kung bakit. and in the spectrum of making films that want to make people listen, Sunshine sits perfectly in the middle. hindi masyadong dinikta yung mensahe to the point that it may be a bit too "preachy" kahit walang substance, pero hindi rin nasobrahan sa spectacle at drama at kinulang sa tapang to the point that the message gets blurred. this was a very well executed show and not tell, and show it did.plus everyone was just soooo good. ang husay ng pag arte ng lahat. maris, jennica, annika???? ang husay. no acting to take you out of the scene, no lines to remind you that you're watching a film aiming to be a commercial success (which is a pinoy movie disease, the infamous hugot line syndrome)simple lang. the story was straightforward. it knew what it wanted to tell and it delivered. the topic was handled with care without shying away from the heaviness of it. visually stunning, i love seeing manila filmed as it is and have it be a setting that adds to the storytelling. technically admirable, without losing the heart to tell the story. ms tonet jadaone you've won me over once again. balik nanaman ako sa good side mo po ms jadaone po. please don't stop making pinoy movies tnx po

Women are born with pain built-in. It's our physical destiny: period pains, sore boobs, childbirth, you know. We carry it within ourselves throughout our lives; men don‚Äôt. They have to seek it out. They invent all these gods and demons and things, just so they can feel guilty about things, which is something we do very well on our own. And then they create wars, so they can feel things and touch each other. And when there aren‚Äôt any wars, they can play rugby. We have it all going on in here inside. We have pain on a cycle for years and years and years and then just when you feel you are making peace with it all, what happens? The menopause comes. The fucking menopause comes, and it is the most wonderful fucking thing in the world. And yes, your entire pelvic floor crumbles and you get fucking hot and no one cares, but then you‚Äôre free, no longer a slave, no longer a machine with parts. You‚Äôre just a person.
Alam kong ang pelikulang ito ay more than just about dreams, pero sinulat ito sa mga dreamers na gusto mag succeed. Kaya gets kita, Sunshine

This movie would have been a 5/5 for me if not for the scene with Rhed Bustamante, which weakens its claim of being genuinely ‚Äúpro-choice.‚Äù Some devout viewers might frame abortion as acceptable only in cases like rape or other extreme circumstances. Abortion is a woman‚Äôs right because she has full authority over her own body. Women are autonomous humans. Reproductive rights should not depend on how tragic the story is. Abortion should not be portrayed as acceptable only for rape survivors or under certain conditions, but as a fundamental expression of bodily autonomy for all women, regardless of their reasons.

apaka hirap maging babae.sunshine did the right thing. she wasn‚Äôt being selfish; she was being honest. she knew, deep within herself, that she wasn‚Äôt ready to be a mother, and because of that self-awareness, she understood that ending the pregnancy was the most responsible choice she could make.i genuinely love this film. it exposes the harsh reality of living in a country dominated by catholic doctrine‚Äîwhere the people around us can be relentlessly cruel, judgmental, and unforgiving. the film tackles abortion with remarkable depth, showing how society instinctively treats it as a sin, a crime, even a form of murder‚Äîwithout ever pausing to consider the woman‚Äôs circumstances, pain, or autonomy.sana mapanood ‚Äòto ng lahat, para maintindihan nila na hindi masama ang pagpapalaglag. people forget that there are reasons‚Äîreal, painful, and valid reasons‚Äîwhy someone would choose it.the storyline of the thirteen-year-old child, impregnated by her uncle, shattered me. it happens in real life. children‚Äîliteral children‚Äîforced to carry pregnancies at the cost of their own safety and future. it‚Äôs heartbreaking that instead of being allowed to end the pregnancy for their well-being, many are forced to keep it simply because abortion is illegal. the kid didn‚Äôt even know she was pregnant‚Äîshe only realized when her stomach started to swell. that level of innocence being burdened with trauma feels monstrous.i truly hope our country stops clinging to extreme conservatism and learns to be more open-minded‚Äîto understand that these things do happen outside the walls of their moral fantasies. legalize abortion. educate children about sex. there is nothing lewd or obscene about knowledge‚Äîmalisyoso lang ang mga utak ng mga ayaw magturo.at tangina si miggy. walang kuwenta.

loveee the solidarity of women in the film. especially jeannica's character (sunshine's sister) üòîwhat stood out to me abt ‚ÄúSunshine‚Äù is how it handles abortion without turning it into shock value or moral debate. the film treats it the way real life does, quietly, privately, and w a kind of heaviness that doesn‚Äôt need big explanations. it shows how a situation like this doesn‚Äôt happen in a vacuum; it‚Äôs shaped by family, religion, money, expectations, fear, and the silence surrounding women‚Äôs choices, seeing how, in the film, women were denied healthcare even in life or death situations bc of the values and systems upheld in this country.motherhood demands so much, money, energy, time, and an immeasurable amount of emotional labor. once u step into it, there's no turning back. that's why becoming a mother should never be forced, it's not something anyone should bepushed into. it's not easy to be one.being a mother is a beautiful, yet deeply complex role. it should be intentional, it should be a choice.at the same time, every person brought into this world deserves to be born out of intention, love, and readiness. if someone doesn't want to become a mother, that's OKAY. it's only fair, both to her, and to the life she could've been expected to bring into the world.the movie doesn‚Äôt try to justify anything or convince u what is right. instead, it shows the reality of how young people end up dealing w choices they were never prepared for. it‚Äôs not dramatic, not preachy, just painfully honest. the long pauses, the still shots, the way conversations trail off‚Ä¶ it all reflects how hard it is to say something out loud when yk u‚Äôll be judged before u‚Äôre understood.it‚Äôs thoughtful, grounded, and uncomfortable in a necessary way. a reminder that behind every headline or opinion is someone trying to figure out how to move forward when every option hurts.

"naiintindihan mo ba ako?""gets ko na."See Greatest Filipino Films Of All TimeSee Jom‚Äôs Greatest Films Of All TimeOnce in a while, movies like this will remind us how great Philippine Cinema could be with proper production and marketing.Let's be honest, there are many films like Sunshine out there, produced and marketed independently. The talent of our Filipino directors, writers, and actors is flourishing; it just needs the right hand managing them. Studios surrounding Sunshine took a huge gamble promoting and marketing this movie, because they know how good it is. And it's that fcking good!Sunshine beautifully captures Sunshine, our protagonist, as she battles her way out of an unwanted pregnancy set in the cold city of Manila. This journey was documented with captivating visuals of Sunshine in the gym, in Quiapo, in a motel, etc. On top of this, this is unlike any other dialogue in mainstream Pinoy. The dialogue often has witty layers, purposeful intentions, and emotional punches.Maris Racal delivered a career-defining performance. This is not the same Maris Racal we often see in teleseryes or some other romcom movie. Her performance is an incredible take on such a complex and relatable character.I could nitpick some off details here and there which really bugged me, but I won't talk about it here as I believe that further magnifying this movie's success is what we should do.Sunshine represents every woman, every female, every girl, every lady of any shape or form. It brings up socially relevant topics and issues worthy of discussion. I am most impressed by its bravery to speak all about these, coming from a conservative country. Sunshine, the protagonist, showed bravery in confronting the stigma and the conservative norms. Sunshine, the movie, showed the bravery of promoting and marketing this despite the stigma and the conservative norms.

Antoinette Jadaone's "Sunshine" is anchored by a stellar lead performance from Maris Racal and a neo-realist perspective on the lack of reproductive rights in the Philippines. The film follows a rhythmic gymnast who dreams of participating in the Olympics, only to find out that she is pregnant. The film explores the difficulties of finding the right medical care for abortion. Racal's performance is impressive, and she is solidly supported by Annika Co, Jennica Garcia, and Meryll Soriano. Jadaone is able to capture the dirt and grime of Manila's urban areas, as well as the outdated beliefs in the country.Reproductive rights for all!

Kapag nabuntis ka, disgrasyada.Kapag nagpalaglag, mamamatay tao. Not the type to do long reviews for a film, but I love Sunshine so much. Biggest fear na ata ang maging teenage mom ka dito sa Pilipinas; hindi dahil may nakakahiya, kundi dahil doon na lang irereduce ng lahat ng tao ang buong pagkatao mo. Kung tutuusin, mas cinocondemn pa nga nang iba ‚Äòyung pagpapa-abort kesa sa pagnanakaw o pag-ddrugs na makakalimutan na makalipas ilang araw at babansagang ‚Äúnormal‚Äù lang. Sa bawat sulok ng Pilipinas, there would always be a Sunshine or a Mary Grace na aping-api na nga ng patriyarkiya, ilulugmok pa ng mga maka-relihiyon. Just shows how difficult it is to be a woman, especially a woman living in the country of so-called saints. Lysm Direk Tonet, Sunshine truly embodied the hell is a teenage girl spirit‚Äî raw, bold, and unapologetically ambitious.

The movie did not contain any surprise elements whatsoever ‚Äî rather, it depicted the realities that Filipino women endure, especially when it comes to pregnancy and abortion. Seeing individuals like Sunshine and Mary Grace deal with the outcomes they did not choose is devastating. It's awful that they had to put their own lives in danger to reclaim their lives. In addition, I detest the notion that women are blamed and criticized while the majority of males who participated in the incident roam free from the consequences. It's horrible how obviously apparent the double standards are. Most of us are aware of the worst-case situations if abortion isn't legalized, and this film accurately depicts the gravity of the situation. If watching this doesn't change your mind about being anti-abortion, I don't know what will. Not everyone is ready to be a mother. Not everyone is capable of being a mother. Is protecting your child's future and safety truly a sin? I truly hope that this movie will continue to inspire empathy and provide better facilities for safe and regulated practices in the country. Let's do better, Philippines.

‚ÄúGets ko na.‚ÄùAng dami kong gustong sabihin na feeling ko, hindi ko kayang masulat in a movie review. Literal na daramdamin mo lang yung pelikula and your emotions will be enough for people to understand.Gets na gets ko si Sunshine‚Äîfrom thinking you‚Äôre an adult yet feeling like a child; an ambitious girl to a woman on a tightrope; from being alone and criticized by society as a whole to finding your space, your people, your support system despite what people have to say‚Ä¶ and ultimately choosing your own peace and happiness‚Äîsomething that is deemed a privilege for women. Hindi naging madali ang pinagdaanan ni Sunshine at ng milyong-milyong babae sa Pilipinas, sa mundo. May mga babaeng katulad niya na hindi sinasadyang mabuntis, may mga babae namang katulad ni Menggay na posibleng ginahasa at pinagsamantalahan. Hindi ko masikmura kung gaano karaming babae ang dumadaan sa ganitong hirap araw-araw at nakakaramdam na wala na silang mapanghahawakan pa. At dadagdag pa sa pasakit ang ang mga lalaki, ang simbahan, gobyerno at mga sarado ang isip sa ganitong sitwasyon. Why is it that women have to suffer the consequences alone, with the whole world‚Äîheaven and hell‚Äîblaming them for what happened. A world that continues to place heavy pressure on a woman‚Äôs shoulders yet crucify them the moment they make a mistake. Society needs to be more forgiving to women who are trying their best to make and take up space without making them sacrifice their whole life and identity. Every woman is a Sunshine of their own, and I hope that they realize that their happiness, their life, their voices and choices matter.

I genuinely loved how the movie made sure to show all of the things that make unwanted pregnancy and abortion hard for women: the loss of opportunities, the potential absence of the father, the lack of support from society, the scrutiny, all on top of the idea of "killing" your child; an idea heavily imposed on us from the day we were born. Maris' acting showed how difficult it is to be thinking of all of that and more.IMO the story takes into account the ethics of the topic while making sure to portray the most important part: how the woman feels. SAGOT SA PELIKULANG ‚ÄúSUNSHINE‚Äù: HINDI GUGUSTUHIN NG BATA ANG MAMATAY SA ABORSYON KONTRA SA PINAKITA SA PELIKULA----------------------------Paalala: Ito ay dati naming Facebook post na muli naming inilabas dahil nasa Netflix na ang pelikulang "Sunshine." Para sa nagnanais na malaman kung sino ang "unlikely guide" sa caption, basahin ang post dito. ----------------------------Matapos maibalita ang pelikulang ‚ÄúSunshine‚Äù ni Maris Racal, inaasahan ko na ang pagsuporta nito sa aborsyon o ang pagkitil sa anak na nasa sinapupunan ng kanyang ina. Ngunit, ang hindi ko inasahan ay ang huling parte ng pelikula. Hindi ko pinanood ang pelikulang ito ngunit nagbase ako sa buod nito upang malaman kung ano ang naganap [1].Si Sunshine (Maris Racal) ay naghahanda na sumali sa ‚Äúgymnastics team‚Äù para sa Olympics ngunit nalaman niya na buntis pala siya. Dahil dito, pumunta siya sa Quiapo upang bumili ng pampalaglag. Matapos ng eksenang ito ay makikita na sinusundan siya ng isang batang babae. Iyon pala, ang babaeng ito, na nasa larawan sa post na ito, ay isang ‚Äúimaginary friend‚Äù ni Sunshine. Hindi ko na babanggitin ang gitna ng buod ng kwento ngunit sa huling parte ng pelikula, makikita na si Sunshine ay naghahanda para sa Olympics. Nagpakita muli ang ‚Äúimaginary friend‚Äù na batang babae kay Sunshine. Tinanong ni Sunshine kung nauunawaan ba ng batang babae ang desisyon niya. Matapos nito, pinakita ng batang babae na tinatanggap niya at niyakap niya na may luha sa mata si Sunshine. Ang ‚Äúplot twist‚Äù dito ay ang ‚Äúimaginary friend‚Äù na ito ay ang anak ni Sunshine na namatay dahil sa aborsyon. Sa imahinasyon ni Sunshine, tinanggap ng kanyang anak ang desisyon ni Sunshine na patayin siya sa sinapupunan. Tila ba tinuturo ng pelikulang ito, hindi lang na dapat gawing ligal ang pagpili ng tao na patayin ang anak sa sinapupunan ng ina, kundi gugustuhin ng isang bata na mamatay na lamang sa aborsyon kaysa ang mabuhay dahil sa benepisyo na matatanggap ng nanay kung pinatay na lang ang kanyang anak. Nakakalungkot dahil sobrang sama ng moralidad na ipinapalaganap ng pelikulang ito. Dahil dito, nais ko lang ipakita kung ano ang sinabi ng mga taong nakaligtas sa tangkang aborsyon. Hindi sa lahat ng pagkakataon ay namamatay ang mga anak na pinapalaglag. Dahil dito, mahalaga na makita ang kanilang perspektibo sa usapin ng aborsyon matapos silang makaligtas dito. Sabi ni Linda Swayn na nakaligtas sa aborsyon ngunit nagkaroon ng problema sa kanyang bungo dahil sa bawal na gamot na ginamit sa pampalaglag,"The greatest gift I have received is life. God has given me the greatest gift of life [2]."Ito naman ang mababasa sa buhay ni Charlie Rousseau, isang tagapagsalita sa radyo sa Canada, na nakaligtas ng aborsyon na nagdulot upang mabuhay siyang putol ang braso at dalawang binti,‚ÄúShe wants to continue with her dream to work and live remotely, and see the world [3]."Makikita naman natin na lagi nanaginip ng masama si Kimberly na maaaring parte ng kanyang masamang alaala sa tangkang pagpatay sa kanya,‚ÄúFor as long as I can remember, I would have a recurring nightmare. I could feel it coming, as if someone was coming to kill me... Somehow I knew it was going to kill me! It was terrifying! When I was 15 years old, I woke from the nightmare screaming and crying [4]."Ngayon, huwag muna natin isipin ang aborsyon kundi ang bagong silang na sanggol. Tama ba na patayin sila para hindi maapektuhan ang pangarap ng kanyang nanay? Sa tingin ba natin, sasabihin ng sanggol na tama ang desisyon ng kanyang ina na patayin siya? Malamang ay hindi. Ito rin ang ating rason sa pagtanggol sa buhay ng lahat, lalo na ng mga bata na walang kakayahan ipagtanggol ang kanilang sarili. Galing mismo sa boses ng mga nakaligtas ng aborsyon na alam nila kung gaano ito kasama at gaano kaganda ang buhay. Walang bata ang gugustuhin na sila ay patayin. Itigil na sana nila ang kasinungalingang ipinapalaganap sa pelikulang ito.

Bring back more filipino movies like this, gets ko sunshineSunshine really hits the mark in portraying toxic filipino culture (since we‚Äôre a largely catholic country, abortion is looked as ‚Äúsinful‚Äù and ‚Äúimmoral‚Äù) and Filipino women struggles. We don‚Äôt even have access to safe abortion, even if the baby is born off of violence since it‚Äôs illegal. And it STILL is. Why is the concern of safety regarded for the unborn baby,, not the woman carrying it? Why are we shaming women for not wanting to keep it even if they didn‚Äôt ask for it? Kakainis. No more words other than thank you to Antoinette Jadaone for making a movie that tackles the pro-life/pro-choice conflict so well and shows awareness respectfully. Nailed it so hard. It‚Äôs uncomfortable to watch, but I can‚Äôt imagine the reality of living it.The movie leaving us with the question, are these beliefs that can be challenged more important to uphold than the safety of our Filipino women? How many more women must suffer until it gets through their thick skull that these beliefs and the anti-abortion law actively does more harm than good?Extra: I reco you read Nutribun review of this movie after you‚Äôve watched it, explains it much better than me and i agreed with SO many points.

Abortion has been a pressing issue in a predominantly Christianised nation like the Philippines. Albeit some of the points raised are quite incisive, what Sunshine lacks is an original insight on how we ought to discuss ‚Äúabortion‚Äù that Hinugot sa Langit (poverty & morality) and Bendor (folk & speculative realism) have not articulated yet. Maris Racal and Jennica Garcia are two of this generation‚Äôs finest actresses, in my opinion.

this isn‚Äôt really a film about mistakes. well, at least for me. it‚Äôs a film about the quiet burdens women carry‚Äîthose moments when the world expects you to stay composed while everything inside you is breaking apart. what stayed with me wasn‚Äôt the plot itself, but the feeling of watching a girl stand at the edge of her dreams while life keeps pulling her in directions she never asked for.there is a particular kind of loneliness here that Filipinas know too well: the pressure to be strong, the fear of being judged, the lack of safe spaces to fall apart... The film captures that ache, the way society can be quick to moralize but slow to understand.For me, it felt like looking at a reflection of a system we‚Äôve all quietly learned to navigate: the whispers, the shame, the institutions that pretend to help but rarely do. Yet in those heavy moments, you still see a girl trying to choose herself, even when the world insists she shouldn‚Äôt.it‚Äôs messy, raw, and painfully familiar‚Ä¶ and that‚Äôs why it felt less like watching a film and more like remembering something you wish you could forget.

just had to rewatch once more. ito, seryoso na at skl ko lang din this anecdote of mine. i remember being a transferee in sixth grade when i was suddenly forced into an intra-school debate tournament. one of the motions i had was about the legalization of abortion and i was placed in the opposing team. i vividly remember kung paano ako naging mulat sa topic na ‚Äòto and i thought to myself, ‚Äúoo nga, ‚Äòno? bakit nga ba bawal?‚Äù i honestly had a hard time countering the government side‚Äôs points, so i just ended up focusing on my own arguments (without saying any rebuttals) instead ‚Äî buti leader of the opp. lang ako no‚Äôn, lol. our debate teacher, or the madam chair, was very strict about not using the church as a basis when making an argument. but all i could think of then was the bible, i couldn‚Äôt think of any other countering argument na pwede kong maibato.and so, if a small-scale school debate tournament prohibits using the church as an argument, why can‚Äôt we demand the same from our government? bakit patuloy na iginigiit ang impluwensya ng simbahan sa batas if we supposedly live in a secular state?sunshine and all filipino (women) do not deserve this bullshit. free and accessible (reproductive) healthcare for filipinos!on the side note, this film is incredibly well-made and fearless. salamat, direk tonet and to everyone involved. give maris racal her flowers juseyo! i‚Äôm sooo glad i finally got to watch this kasi i missed the local screening months ago. i really hope na maging mulat ang bawat manonood kung bakit napaka-timely at mahalaga ang mga pelikulang tulad nito.

Sunshine offers a quiet yet affecting exploration of teenage pregnancy and abortion‚Äîtwo issues deeply intertwined with the social and economic realities of our country. What makes the film striking is its simplicity: it doesn‚Äôt rely on heavy dramatics, but instead allows its heartfelt moments and grounded storytelling to speak for themselves.I particularly appreciated how the film subtly incorporated supernatural elements. Rather than distracting from the story, these touches added depth and symbolism, making the film feel both intimate and introspective. It‚Äôs a creative choice that gives Sunshine a unique emotional texture.As someone who grew up Catholic, I‚Äôve never taken a firm stance on abortion; I‚Äôve mostly remained indifferent or unsure. But this film pushed me to reflect on the bigger picture. It gently raises a painful yet necessary question: Why bring a child into a country that struggles to provide a dignified, nurturing environment for its people? Without forcing a specific viewpoint, Sunshine invites viewers to confront the harsh realities that many young Filipinos face‚Äîstories that are often ignored or oversimplified.Overall, Sunshine succeeds not just as a piece of cinema, but as a conversation starter. It lingers with you, urging you to think about compassion, choice, and the societal conditions that shape both. It‚Äôs a simple film, but one with a resonance that‚Äôs hard to forget.

Mga uri ng tao na hinihiling kong masunog sa impyerno:1. Mga lalaki sa mundo2. Overly religious people3. PRO-LIFERS.WOMEN'S RIGHTS SHOULDN‚ÄôT BE SOMETHING TO BE DEBATED!‚ÄúHindi pa ako ready maging nanay‚Äù is already a valid reason for abortion. It‚Äôs her choice, not a moral issue for everyone to judge. Nakakalungkot noong ipinakita sa movie na ito kung gaano kalala ang situation sa public hospitals‚Äîkulang sa resources, walang safe at stigma-free options, mayroon pa ngang nanganganak na lang sa sahig dahil sa kakulangan sa mga tao at kagamitan. Kaya hindi nakapagtataka na for many women, the ‚Äúsafest‚Äù choice ends up being underground options, kahit sobrang risky. Mas ironic pa, kasi nasa paligid lang ng simbahan ang mga nagbebenta ng pamparegla, hilot, at kung anu-ano, tapos ang narrative ng church: ‚Äúkung natukso ka, talo ka.‚Äù Kaya understandable that the ‚Äútukso‚Äù becomes sometimes the only lifeline for someone desperate. Women bear the brunt of the hypocrisy. That‚Äôs literally the only way a woman could access it. Hindi ko alam kung bakit kapag babae ka, ang daming bawal sa‚Äôyo. Pero hindi ka naman bibigyan ng reliable options. Napaka eye-opening nito sa atin, lalo na‚Äôt ipinakita sa atin na wala tayong karapatan husgahan ang batang ina kasi hindi natin alam ang pinagdadaanan nila. Rape victim man o hindi, a woman should always have the right to decide for herself‚Äîher body is never up for debate.

finally a film with good dialogue and actually filmed within manila!! u can already tell the movie was bound to touch on heavy topics but there were still moments where i thought, ‚Äúholy shit, they really went there‚Äù O_O live for the gay ariana grande kid, he‚Äôs lowk me. i gen would not have expected him to be the 13 y/o‚Äôs son LIKE i knew alr that the girl was supposedly sunshine‚Äôs child but it did not hit me that ariana‚Ä¶

‚ÄúDrown out the noise. You are Sunshine.‚Äùit‚Äôs heartbreaking how many young women are going through this right now. abortion in the Philippines is not only illegal, but also so deeply stigmatized that many are forced to carry this burden alone, sometimes risking their own lives through unsafe procedures. the film portrays this reality with such quiet honesty that it sticks with you. the symbolism throughout was also so striking, like the ‚ÄúGift of God‚Äù sign in the jeepney Sunshine rode, or her so-called imaginary friend who could represent her unborn child or her inner child.it was honestly so satisfying watching her stand up for herself against miggy and his father, who‚Äôs a pastor. then of course, her breaking the bottle on tito bobot‚Äôs head? deserved. every mf like him deserves that.the final sequence felt incredibly freeing as well. it was like she was finally free, almost like a release of everything she had been carrying ‚Äî fear, shame, pressure, expectation. her imaginary friend disappearing can be interpreted that she did push through with the abortion (which parallels the 13 y/o kid and ariana), or as her finally finding peace with whatever choice she made. hopefully, this film gives conservatives some perspective on the immense weight placed on women in these situations, and they‚Äôll finally be able to say, ‚ÄúGets ko na.‚Äù not everyone has the means to raise a child, especially when society is quick to judge. and even if you do have the means, you might simply not be ready because you might still have dreams you want to chase. it‚Äôs really tough, and that‚Äôs why kindness matters so much.at the end of the day, we shouldn‚Äôt be the ones deciding what women should do with their bodies. and yeah, practice safe sex!!

crazy movie to watch with your boyfriend for the first time (no regrets)- says a lot that i already knew the realities the movie was meant to expose because it's a very real possibility for me (and i've experienced some parts firsthand) (XD) (i am never going back to reddit that had me believing in some bs) (which is based on truth naman but still you could never fully trust these sites)- some aspects of teenage pregnancy and abortion might be new to some people because these things wouldn't concern them in the first place (men) (conservatives)- which is why the characters feel very planted. as in, their role is In Your Face (to name a few: the kids, piolo pascal*, miggy**, ate, her kid, unhelpful little brother that shares a room with her lol, whole tito boyet sideplot)- but i think the best thing this movie does is spark conversation, especially since it covers those unsaid aspects (e.g., the role of the church & ses, feelings of dread & anxiety when faced with the possibility of being pregnant, again: reddit, the actual pain & danger of an abortion) and makes it Palatable for d general ph audience!!!!!!!- again, since this is a taboo topic, people wouldn't want something too extreme and radical, so this movie is a good first step towards talking about it- still tho, the palatability made the ending so ass for me personally like. everything just started coming together a lil too smoothly for sunshine and honestly... for me ha...... Meh..........- anyway, props to maris racal for executing the choreo holy shit. so impressive and so cleanalso, Wow this movie hit so close to home, even outside of the content mismo1) towers2) i have never seen a movie with so many familiar landmarks like vito cruz (hello what other "mainstream" media's been filmed here), recto, avenida, quiapo. plus the lrt and the fact that they commuted everywhere!! i loved that3) all girls (cliques) and all boys school aspect. plus the fact that they were in a relationship coz partner school ata lol4) the fact she basically had no one but herself at one point oh my god made me So grateful for my support systemtbh the only thing that made me cry from this movie was the ate coming to bed with sunshine Ough... and the very hard conversation i had with aldy after coz wow we did not process that pala (o diba sparks conversation) but yes good movieside notes* i'm so sorry nathrow off aq sa mukha nya like the movie has pretty new faces for me so seeing him was like Woah. what are u doing here** casting for him was actually spot on. straight from a private school

'Yung pangarap ko, kung ano ang pangarap niya.Ang hirap maging babae sa bansang 'to.Gusto ko lang sabihin na napakagaling ng mga gumanap sa mga karakter sa pelikulang 'to, hindi ako usually umiiyak sa mga pinapanood ko, pero dito, nagawa ko. Para sa'kin, purong-puro 'yung mga scenes, naipakita talaga 'yung reyalidad ng buhay pagdating sa mga taong katulad ni Sunshine, mga pangyayari na katulad ng sa kanya. Pati 'yung sitwasyon na nangyayari sa mga public hospitals, 'yung mga facilities na binabayaran natin gamit ang tax natin, ay hindi nila magawang maayos. May mga doktor pang kung umasta ay hindi sila propesyonal at napaka-condescending. It is the reality of life here in the Philippines. Napansin ko rin that hatred for abortion is rooted from patriarchy and religion, napakahirap maging babae kapag ito ang mga kalaban mo, 'no? Sa babae ang sisi, sa babae ang lahat ng kasalanan habang ang mga lalaki ay may tinatawag na "free pass." Sabi pa nga nila, "Ba't ka kasi bumubukaka," o kaya naman, "Kung sino-sino na lang kasi ang kinakalantari mo." Those things are the representation of the mindset of those who deem themselves as religious, but for me, they are just a bunch of hypocrites. Men can even be erased from the picture, and women will continue being condemned. Fuck people with double standards. Our society is so hypocrite that 'yung mga tinatawag na "pamparegla" ay natatagpuan malapit sa labas ng simbahan. Gaano sila kamapanghusga sa mga babaeng may karapatan sa kanilang sariling katawan, ipinapakita 'yan sa paniniwala nilang biased at outdated. It is sad to think na kailangan pa ng mga kababaihan na mag-lean towards these illegal means just to afford being free, when in the first place, it is their right to have a legal, safer, and non-demoralizing way to abort when it means taking care of their body, preventing the unborn from having a miserable life, and just letting women have their right to bodily autonomy. It just shows na napaka-patriarchal ng batas, sumabay pa 'yang pagiging misogynistic ng lipunang ginagalawan natin. These force women into motherhood and to have a life they do not want, and guess what happens after that? The cycle continues. Sa mga katulad ni Sunshine, at sa mga kababaihan, I'm proud of you. Sana'y buhay pa ako kapag nawala na 'yang ganyang kabobohang mindset na laganap ngayon.

I hesitated to write a review that delves into the realities women in our country face, because I‚Äôm not the person who should be speaking for them.But SUNSHINE is a deeply powerful film.It would‚Äôve been easy for a story like this to sink into pure despair from beginning to end. Yet somehow, the film manages to confront its darkest truths while still carving out a sliver of hope. The performances are extraordinary‚Äîraw, fearless, and honest‚Äîbut they make the film difficult to watch in the best possible way. It exposes how our country refuses to grow, medicine needed for the operation coming from black markets, how it continues to force women into roles far smaller than what they‚Äôre capable of, and how it avoids addressing issues that desperately need to be talked about. Women deserve choice. They deserve agency. They deserve that right without question.This film places you in the shoes of a woman who believes her life has been shattered by one reckless decision made by someone she trusted‚Äîand then shows, unflinchingly, how our society treats victims.Hopefully, the success of this film reignites the conversation around the importance of being pro-choice and pushes us toward building a better, more humane system.All we hope for is a little sunshine to finally break through.

this film doesn't just tell a story; it exposes a system. for that reason, it stands as one of the most important films ever made in the philippines. honestly, it deserves far more attention, discussion, and recognition. include it in school curriculums too if possible.you don't need tearful monologues, or dramatic breakdowns (not that there's anything wrong with them) to understand the full weight of sunshine's situation. the film uses restraint as its sharpest tool. the dim, muted visuals; the overwhelming noise of her environment; the way the camera locks her in the centre of the frame.. always boxed in, always between lines.. all emphasise how trapped she is by the social and religious stigma, and by a society that refuses to recognise abortion as a woman's right. the blurred backgrounds aren't just aesthetic; they reinforce her disconnection from the world around her. she doesn't have the luxury to care about anything beyond her immediate reality: herself, her dreams, and the looming consequences of every decision she faces.and that is the tragedy, sunshine is a young woman with ambition, yet she navigates a world that is unforgiving. she is asked to seek god's forgiveness for attempting to abort the baby, yet if god is understanding, wouldn't he understand that she is not ready, and that she acted out of necessity? with abortion vilified and access almost impossible, the film illustrates how society corners, isolates, and silences young mothers.. not with loud condemnation, but with quiet, crushing inevitability. it is a devastating portrait of how systemic and cultural forces conspire to limit women's autonomy, and a reminder of the human cost of denying choice.one of the most striking elements of the film, for me, is its gendered power dynamic. every character, without exception, imposes his own beliefs onto sunshine. urging her to keep the baby, citing legality, morality, or personal conviction. their "advice" is never about her well-being, it's about controlling her choices. the absence of a single moment where a man asks what she wants is not accidental, it reflects a broader social structure where women's autonomy is secondary to male authority.the women in the film, however, present a more nuanced spectrum. some internalise patriarchal norms and unintentionally reinforce them, but many others recognise sunshine's struggle immediately. they empathise not because they have the answers, but because they understand the emotional, economic, and social burden that falls disproportionately on women. their solidarity is quiet but powerful. a direct contrast to the coercive, dismissive tone of the male characters. the film ultimately critiques how systems built and upheld by men deny women agency, especially around reproductive choices. in a society where institutional and cultural norms consistently silence women, the film shows that women often became each other's only source of validation, understanding, and empowerment. no scene is waster. nothing is filler. every character is intentionally placed, each one shaping or limiting sunshine's decisions in ways that feel painfully real.

Yes! This is the type of films the Philippines should make more! Finally a movie with substance, relevance, and courage to tell a story despite cultural taboo. This is required and essential.I thought an hour and a half wouldn‚Äôt be enough to dig deeper into the journey of Sunshine but it was actually just enough to see all of it. Although, there were unnecessary choices made in the film that I disliked and that I wish were done differently and I wish saw more of Sunshine‚Äôs character in the lowest of lows or maybe I‚Äôm just greedy. However,Maris Racal is a revelation. And for the Philippines to have such a film like this one that speaks to so many women, even men, in the country. I hope this is a step forward for the country to move progressively and this be a force for politicians to pass that bill. Because after all, films are made to speak out, protest, and to implement change. Lastly, Sunshine is such a huge step towards good filmmaking in the Philippines. We need more films that speak of truth and of society. Stories that need to be heard and not rely too much on fake romance. Though Sunshine isn‚Äôt perfect as a film itself, the courage and the amount of truth revealed in an hour and a half are enough to have the voices of so many women be heard. Sobrang raw and realistic from the familiar ‚Äújeje‚Äù song playing sa jeep pagsakay ni Sunshine, to the 13 yr old na nakaranas ng pang aabuso mula sa kanyang tito (talamak ang kaso ng incest sa pinas, thank u direk for highlighting that). Sa sobrang realistic pati ang inis ko kuhang kuha ng conservative doctor. Literally had to pause and say ‚ÄúPutangina‚Äù pag sabing ‚ÄúBaka yan pala ang magiging future presidente ng Pilipinas or ang makakagamot sa AIDS.‚ÄùAng pelikulang ito ay napakatapang. It had the guts to shine a spotlight on a longstanding issue sa bansa na lagi na lang inooverlook. It dare call out and address what Filipinos considered as taboo. And as someone who had a debate with her mom over dinner about abortion, this film is so special to me. ‚ÄúHindi ka ba kinikilabutan?‚Äù were my moms‚Äô exact words but I cannot blame her. Being a country deeply rooted in Christianity, where morals and teachings of the church are deeply ingrained in you ever since you were young, it is actually hard to speak freely about this things without the catholic guilt creeping up on you. Kaya ang laki rin ng significance ng pagdasal muna ni Sunshine before nya gawin. To ask the lord for forgiveness.Plus it doesn‚Äôt shy away from showing the state of the country‚Äôs public healthcare system. Nakakaputangina lang. Putangina ng gobyerno. Putangina ng sistema kung saan kailangan maging life-threatening situation ang pagpapalaglag. Banning abortion does not end it, it only makes it unsafe for women since it causes them to resort to underground means. And what an irony that one of those means can be found tucked under the shadows of the church (mga ale na nagbebenta ng pamparegla, u carry so much hope for these women). The very church that condemns it and shuns women who will even consider it. This film is a big step in understanding women‚Äôs bodily autonomy. Mas mahalaga pa rin ang buhay ng nagdadalang-tao. Lastly, Annika (the child symbolizing Sunshine‚Äôs future child) saying ‚ÄúGets ko na‚Äù at the end is so so dear huhu. Bata pa ang bata para magkabata. She has her whole life ahead of her and god forbid a woman chooses herself and her dreams. Gets ko na, Sunshine. Gets ko na.

this film is so close to my heart and i don't think there's a word in any dictionary that can explain how much value i put in this movie. sunshine is the representation of many young girls in the philippines and the cultural violence that filipino women have to face every single day. manila is home, but what home turns away its daughters? what home is so noisy that it becomes hard to hear the plea for change? it's hard to drown out the noise when manila is nothing but the howl of traffic and trains grinding along rusty tracks. it's hard to drown out the noise when every corner of the city carries the weight of other people's opinions about you. it's hard to drown out the noise when people love nothing more than the echo of their own voices. it's hard to drown out the noise when the government chooses to not help. it's hard to drown out the noise when the hospitals meant to care for you are bursting in the seams. it's hard to drown out the noise when you're a woman in manila. besides, why are we expected to keep drowning out the noise? why can't the noise just stop. i am tired of seeing women seek help from the narrow and noisy streets of quiapo to get unsafe abortion simply because there's no other choice available to them. women should be able to walk into a hospital and feel protected in their own decisions, in their own bodies, without a doctor insisting they ‚Äúthank God‚Äù for something that has broken them. sunshine, i dream the same dreams you have. gets na gets kita

drown out the noise.kung iisipin, malaya ba maging isang babae?mapagpalaya ba ang manirahan sa ganitong klase ng bansa bilang isang babae? kailan darating yung panahon na hindi na kinakailangang kumilos ng babae sa isang lugar kung saan malayang malaya siyang husgahan dahil sa kaniyang mga desisyon? tuwing kailan mo masasabing malaya ka sa sarili mong bansa; kung nakakulong ka pa rin sa gate ng simbahan, sa ingay ng dyip at tren sa kalsada, sa konsensya mo, sa sarili mo? paano mo aasahang gumalaw ang isang babaeng hindi lang isa o dalawang tao ang "masasagasaan" sa pagtindig sa kaniyang nga karapatan bilang babae‚Äîkundi isang buong relehiyon at batas ang haharapin mo na dapat sana ay nangunguna sa pagbibigay sekuridad at protekta sayo. malinaw sa pelikulang ito ang mga problemang nagpahirap kay sunshine, pero higit na mas malinaw ang mga dahilan kung bakit mas lalo itong nahirapan. hindi sana kinakailangang mag-alala ni sunshine sa mga posibilidad na maaaring may maging sagabal sa natatangi nitong pangarap. dito ipinakita na kahit nakatira si sunshine sa lugar kung saan madilim, madumi, maingay, at dikit-dikit ang mga marurupok na bahay ay mayroon pa rin itong isang ate‚Äîisang babae, na lagi't lagi niyang ipapaalala na may kakampi pa rin siya sa hinagpis ng buhay. dito ipinakita kung paanong sa kabila ng mga taong maaari mong lapitan sa gitna ng problema ay mapipilitan ka na lamang maglakad nang mabilis at balisa sa quiapo sa takot na may makakita sayo, o di kaya'y mag check in sa isang motel sa pag-asang sa madilim na kwarto ring iyon matatapos lahat ng problema mo. para sa akin, sapat na ang mga eksena sa simbahan at mga rebulto sa harap ng mga pampareglang itinitinda patago upang malinaw na maihatid ang mensaheng nais maparating ng pelikula; na isang malaking sagabal ang mga aspetong isa tayong bansa na karamihan ay mga katoliko, at lahat ng pilipino'y mga hipokritong deboto, at mas may pakielam pa ang mga ito sa mga desisyon ng mga babae para sa kaniyang sarili, kaysa sa kani-kanilang mga buhay. ang pahayag na hindi handa si sunshine maging isang ina ang siyang dapat na tumapos sa lahat ng mga opinyong wala namang maitutulong sa kaniya. ganoon lang sana kasimple ang lahat. pero higit sa mga eksenang nakaangkla sa ating pagiging katoliko ay ang mga doktor, mga propesyonal na edukado, sa pelikula kung saan mas narinig ko pa silang nanghusga kay sunshine kaysa sa sarili nitong konsensya. paano ka nga naman hihiling na sana'y gawin nang legal ang aborsyon sa bansa, kung yung mismong mga pribilehiyo at edukado na mismo ang nagbibigay rason sayo upang mas lalong matakot at panghinaan ng loob? sa mundo na kagaya ng kay sunshine, sino nga ba ang maaari nitong kapitan? hindi ba't mapipilitan ka na lamang tahakin ang landas ng mga naging desisyon ni sunshine? nakakagalit isipin na sa pagtagal ng panahon ay mas lalo lamang dumadami ang mga kaso ng mga babaeng gumagawa ng sariling diskarte para mailaglag ang kanilang mga dinadala; na higit pa sa nagbibigay kapahamakan sa kanila. napakagaling ng eksena niya sa motel; naghihikahos sa pag-asa na mamamatay din yung reyalidad na nagdadalang-tao siya. mistula ko ring personal na nararamdaman yung pisikal na sakit na nagpapadugo sa kaniya. pero tumulo talaga ang mga luha ko nang napagtanto ko yung papel ng karakter dito ni rhed bustamante. hindi matatawaran yung dating ng kuwento niya, dahil nirerepresenta niya ang bawat batang babae na dumanas ng karahasan sa sarili nitong tahanan, mula sa sarili nitong kadugo. sa bawat katagang pagsambit ni coach na "drown out the noise." ay ang reyalidad na hindi lahat ay katulad ni sunshine‚Äîsa bawat pitik ng mga kamay at lambot ng kaniyang katawan ay may kakayahan itong lunurin ang isip sa katahimikan. hindi lahat ng dumanas sa teenage pregnancy ay may kakayahang isarado ang isip sa bawat panghuhusga at pagsabi ng mga tao na, mali iyan, kasalanan iyan, malay pa natin at balang araw ang laman na gusto mong ipalaglag ay ang magiging presidente ng pilipinas. higit sa katotohanang dapat ay nasa lalake ang lahat ng sisi, malaking parte rin ang simbahan, gobyerno, at ang mga taong nakapaligid sayo, kung bakit hindi mo magawan ng desisyon ang sarili mong katawan at kinabukasan. pangarap ko rin ang lahat ng pangarap ng mga sunshine.

This is tough to watch as a woman. I was already crying halfway through the film. I usually comment on the techniques used by the production but I honestly don't feel like it with this film because the story and the themes tackled carries so much weight. I just hope this film could shine a light to everybody, especially the PH Government. The topic shown, specifically, is more than cultural, it is systemic. It is not just a medical issue or a mere moral dilemma in our belief systems considering that it significantly affects all Filipino women. The more we shy away from these issues, the more we increase mortality rates, creating dysfunctional families and dysfunctional communities as a whole, it also contributes to the poverty problem that has prevailed since forever. Safe abortion is a necessity, especially in this godforsaken country.

Hands down, wala akong masabi sa palabas na ‚Äòto. This film reveals everything about the Philippines that we don‚Äôt often talk about. Many Filipinos have no choice kasi illegal ang abortion dito, and young women are forced into situations THEY NEVER REALLY WANTED. It shows the harsh reality of how society constantly pressures women into motherhood, ignoring their dreams, their health, and their right to make decisions about their own bodies. The film doesn‚Äôt sugarcoat the pain physical, emotional, and mental‚Äîthat comes with being trapped in a system that refuses to acknowledge their autonomy.What hits the hardest is how normalized this struggle has become, and how many are suffering in silence. Especially the story of rhed bustamante‚Äôs character. Grabe. 13 years old nag cacarry na ng baby ‚òπÔ∏è a child carrying a child. This is a message to all the people to talk more openly about abortion, to stop victim-blaming, and to hold those useless shitty ass irresponsible men accountable. It‚Äôs more than a movie‚Äîit‚Äôs a wake-up call, a plea for empathy, and a DEMAND for change. Sobrang gets kita, sunshine.

SUCH AN IMPORTANT FILM!!!!During these times, we genuinely need more films like this. First, not only does it touch on the struggles of a young woman faced with an unwanted pregnancy. It also shows how easy it is for the men to rid themselves of the responsibility. Miggy DID NOT give a fuck about Sunshine. He wanted her to deal with it herself; he wasn't even going to give her money if she didn't threaten him. It was his fault that she got pregnant, and yet she has to suffer the consequences of their unprotected sex, which he insisted upon. Second, it is very important how this film shows that early/childhood pregnancies are not just because of young people's 'kapabayaan.' More often than not, young girls' pregnancies are results of sexual assault and rape by predators. I cried when I saw Mary Grace, even more when we were told she's just 13. JUST 13!!!!! She wasn't "wreckless," she wasn't out there having sex with anyone; she was raped by her own uncle. And she's just expected to mother the child born out of such a horrific thing done to her?Third, it shows you just how important legalizing abortion is. It's already happening out there. People are selling abortive pills or concoctions. People are doing basement abortions, in unsafe conditions, without licensed doctors. It's happening and it's dangerous. Sunshine was hospitalized. Mary Grace almost died. If abortion was legal, none of this would've happened. These girls would've been safe and cared for.Again, what an important film! It also shows how abysmal the healthcare system is in the Philippines. Overcrowded hospitals, little to no financial support, etc.On top of that, phenomenal performances all around. Maris Racal was great. Jennica Garcia was, as usual, brilliant. Rhed Bustamante, you will always be a star.This might be the longest entry in my letterboxd rn. I'll end it with: COMPREHENSIVE SEX EDUCATION NOW!! LEGALIZE ABORTION!!!

One thing I like about Sunshine is its brazen risk to center the story on a 19-year old who's made consequentially irresponsible choices. It's a gambit that can easily be -- and, judging by discussions surrounding this movie, has already been -- misconstrued as a lesson on the importance of hammering down our society's puritanical views on sex and reproductive health to set teenage girls straight. That, somehow, Sunshine is a lesson in, as the elders say, "opening your legs for just about anybody"; that she did not listen to the adage is an absolute failing on her part, and its consequences fall rightfully on her shoulders. But here's the tricky bit: Sunshine could very well have been about a mother who could no longer give birth to another, and it would have still been met with the same logic-defying resistance that still places the blame squarely on the woman. Minor gripes include a finicky plot device that, at times, feels jarring and slightly questionable in terms of messaging. But it all feels egregious to say because the urgency of its existence really dwarfs over whatever minor flaws it may have. It also helps that Sunshine carried is so deftly by Maris Racal's and Jennica Garcia's career-defining performances, and a score by Rico Blanco that knows how to restrain and reintroduce itself in all the right moments.Sunshine cracks open a conversation on an obstinately immovable subject, and unflinchingly exposes the grim reality on how our women and girls move about our society, bearing the problems that we could easily find solutions to but which our religious guilt and intolerance constantly shame us into denying.

gets na gets na yung hype for Sunshine, naiyak akothis film really opened up a lot of heavy conversations regarding controversial topics that, up to this day, are still very hard to be tackled in our country where most minds are still enveloped by conservative ideologies that have been long influenced by religious policies.the message is straightforward and clear. it showed us the reality of women alike that had to endure the consequences of the patriarchal oppression and the dominance of Catholicism in the country, which is something that the rightists would undoubtedly refuse to accept because they'd still believe their presumed "norms" are what they think what's "best" for everyone and in the country ‚Äî which is so out of touch from reality and it's very frustrating.however, i just had a bit of a problem with the film's inclusion of imaginary children; which i think somehow holds it back from letting the main message have its full weight. i get that they were used as some kind of a metaphor or a device for the plot, but something with it troubles me for reasons i can't quite best explain yet.but all in all, i really commend the bold attempts they did for this film. still a solid gem for Philippine contemporary cinema that's deserving to be watched by so many

the premise alone is enough for me to give it a full rating. to come up with a movie about one of the most taboo topics in this predominantly catholic country‚Äîgiven how conservative almost everyone is about it, how it‚Äôs actively vilified and condemned, how those who seek it are treated as no better than murderers, and how women are left to fend for themselves and look for alternative ways, whether through an underground clinic, safe or unsafe, or a seller‚Äôs comforting words when you don‚Äôt even know if the medicine will work‚Äîis a huge feat. it has been long overdue, but this is already a big step for everyone. abortion is, and will always be, healthcare.film-wise though, i absolutely LOVE the color grading. i usually hate SOME filipino movies (omg i‚Äôm sorryyyy) because the coloring pisses me off (like ik we can do better). idk how to pinpoint what gives me the ick but,,, yeah. sunshine‚Äôs though was nice. and it was a delight to see bits of manila‚Äôs vibe. always shady, dirty, BUT well, that‚Äôs our country and i loved the actual showcase of it. there were some symbolism and stills of how ironic some scenes can be too!! nice touch :) from the pills next to the statues to the jeepney signs. the plot is predictable for me (re: what those kids are), but not in a bad way. it just shows that it‚Äôs working, and i feel seen. a lot of women will feel seen. not saying we went through the exact same thing, but generally, the gist of thinking your life is over, or will be if it does happen, because we don‚Äôt have a choice in the first place, and are expected to just live with it, is familiar. the amount of mental gymnastics people will spew about ‚Äúthe future of the children,‚Äù how they could be ‚Äúthe next inventor of a cure,‚Äù while never considering the mother, who has her own ambitions, who has to give birth, raise the child, and provide the system and support for their hypothesis to even happen‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs all broken-record arguments. these are the usual lines they‚Äôll say, and some of their reactions (doctors, friends, ‚Äúpartners‚Äù) really DO HAPPEN irl and it‚Äôs proof that the film is heavily based from real experiences, and well researched enough about the actual process people will go through (and went through) for this. here‚Äôs to shed light, to inform, and hopefully, to make people more open, thoughtful, and willing to give women the autonomy they deserve.mic drop
