ok‚Ä¶ two things: ang ganda at ang tapangang ganda kasi kuhang kuha yung manila as in!!! yung opm rap sa jeep, yung kabusyhan ng quiapo, yung juxtaposition na sa tabi ng simbahan mo pa makikita mga nagbebenta ng abortion pills, yung vibe ng recto (tangina heavy on this)accordingly, kuhang kuha din nito yung Pilipino ‚Äî kung paano tayo nasshape ng religious ideals, kung paano pineperceive ng karamihan yung mga babaeng gustong magpa-abort, even kung ano yung tingin natin sa teenage pregnancykaya ang tapang ng movie na to for delving into sunshine's inner struggles - bilang isang teenage Filipina na working class, na nagkaroon ng unexpected pregnancy, na nakatira sa isang bansa na hindi accessible ang reproductive healthcare at sobrang religious lang ng mga tao (intersectionality af) oo, first choice niya talagang ipa-abort ang bata, pero makikita na hindi to naging madali for her - eto ang crux ng movie. pinakita nito na hindi madali ang daan sa abortion - sa kalooban ng babae at sa mga methods na available sa kanya (esp sa bansa natin). pinakita ng Sunshine kung gaano ka-ingrained sa kababaihan na makaramdam ng guilt kapag cinoconsider nilang magpa-abort. HINDI SIYA MADALI, lalo na if may iba pang circumstances na kailangan tignan. sana magets ng mga close-minded people yung point pag pinanood nila.kung iisipin, buhay ng isang babae in real life ang buhay ni sunshine sa pelikula. pero kahit nakikita natin si sunshine sa ordinaryong Pilipina, napakahirap pa rin ng conversation surrounding abortion. kaya ang tapang talaga ng movie for inviting discussion on this topic.hindi ko nagets at first pero i appreciate how the kid represented her unborn child. ang ganda nung "yung pangarap ko, kung ano ang pangarap niya" nakakaiyak...ang galing galing galing ni maris racal!!!!!gets ko na :)

if there is light, kahit konting-konti lang, we chase it‚Äîbecause sometimes that‚Äôs the only thing left for women to hold.sunshine (2025) is the kind of film na hindi ka pinapa-wow sa effects or spectacle. instead, it sits beside you quietly, like a friend na alam lahat ng pagod mo kahit hindi mo sinabi. it‚Äôs woman-centered in the most unsettling, honest way‚Äîwalang sugarcoating, walang mythologizing, just the raw truth of being a girl in a country that asks you to endure more than it ever protects.the film strips away the usual softness associated with its title. sunshine isn‚Äôt light; she‚Äôs a girl trying to survive a world that keeps dimming her. and when the story touches the issue of abortion not being legalized in the Philippines, it doesn‚Äôt sensationalize it‚Äîpinapakita lang niya ‚Äòyung totoo: na in this country, women are expected to carry consequences alone. that reproductive rights become moral battles instead of health and safety; na the system treats our pain like an inconvenience, our choices like crimes.‚Äòyung internal struggle ni Sunshine‚Äî‚Äòyung fear, guilt, confusion, desperation‚Äîhindi dahil ‚Äúmahina siya,‚Äù but because society makes women feel cornered by circumstances we never chose. and the film doesn‚Äôt villainize her for thinking about her future; it villainizes the world that forces her to justify wanting one.and then there‚Äôs Miggy.Miggy is‚Ä¶ familiar. not evil, not abusive, just painfully typical. he represents the kind of boyfriend most girls in the philippines know too well‚Äîthe one who ‚Äúcares,‚Äù but only until it requires accountability. the boy who says ‚ÄúI‚Äôm here for you‚Äù pero umiilag sa big conversations. the boy who loves you but doesn‚Äôt understand the weight you carry because he‚Äôs never had to carry anything like it.Miggy is the embodiment of how boys in this country are raised: may freedom without consequence, may opinion without knowledge, may presence without responsibility. his reactions, his avoidance, even his attempts to comfort‚Äîthey feel real because they‚Äôre exactly what so many girls have lived through. boys who think support is just saying ‚Äúkaya natin ‚Äôto‚Äù while leaving the actual pain to us.sunshine 2025 becomes a commentary on how women are taught to be accountable for everything‚Äîincluding mistakes that weren‚Äôt only theirs‚Äîwhile men are taught to be forgiven for everything. the movie doesn‚Äôt hate Miggy; it exposes him. it shows the casualness of male privilege, the way it slips into daily life unnoticed but heavy‚Äîalways heavy‚Äîon our side.and that‚Äôs what makes the film hit: it‚Äôs not loud, not preachy, not dramatic. it just shows the truth‚Äîand the truth is already loud enough.sunshine isn‚Äôt a story about brightness; it‚Äôs a story about women trying to navigate a world that refuses to make space for their choices, their fears, their bodies, their futures. it‚Äôs a film that says:the pain wasn‚Äôt yours alone, but somehow, you were the only one expected to carry it.and long after the credits, you‚Äôre left with that hurt‚Äîthe kind that reminds you why we keep fighting for a world where women don‚Äôt have to beg for the right to their own lives.

"Gets ko na."to be honest i don't know what to say, i just love this film so bad!!! i just want to hug all the women who have been suffering for a very long time.this film actually made me think of that college chit-chat from my class last semester that i remember when we were talking about bioethics and the law here in the philippines, my professor told us "alam kong marami sainyo dito ang pro-choice pero as part ng medical healthworkers, we need to be pro-life kasi we need to be rational and to save lives, kasi that's what we'rs here for: what we're aiming to do as part of our jobs." and at that time i was so devastated and upset at the same time, like i don't know what to feel at that moment. syempre as pro-choice i believe in the "your body your choice" but hearing that makes me feel like "hanggang dito ba naman sa healthcare, may pakielam pa rin kayo sa gusto namin gawin? can't you just support us with less risk of dying?" again, i added this to my 2025 favorite top 10 films. tangina ng mga lalake at abante babae!

Ang hirap mangarap sa pilipinas, at mas lalong mahirap maging babaeng nangangarap sa pilipinas. Here, our dreams can be taken away in just one snap. The hardship every woman face in this country was shown in this movie ‚Äî everything in every angle. From the lack of support from the government, the inequalities women face, how fucked up the mentalities of most of the Filipinos, struggles in the face of poverty, to the fragility of our dreams. "Libre lang mangarap" they say, but it's not really free when you live in this country. It costs you your dignity, and even your life.---- I just know na I chose Humanities and Social Sciences to broaden up my understanding, perspective, and empathy like how this movie exposed and depicted our reality. We all need exposure to learn, since parang hindi sapat yung everyday witnessed struggles nating mga Pilipino, let this movie open your eyes on how f-ed up our system in this country really is. Mahirap i romanticize ang mga ganto, at hindi dapat i romanticize ang mga ganto.

Sunshine (2024) is the most needed Filipino film of our generation and the generations to come. Beyond the excellent storytelling and technicalities, the message it conveys in a predominantly Catholic & conservative country is a long-overdue revelation of the reality of women.The film opens conversations for the uncomfortable truth of human nature. This is not just Sunshine's story. This is also the story of every woman and every young girl who face the challenges of being silenced and whose rights are being dictated and stepped on by our society.Maris perfectly portrayed Sunshine as a woman who knows what she wants and realizes the power that she and every other woman should have.The rest of the cast realistically depicted the Filipino society that reflects their morals on the teachings of Christianity. Moreover, the two "imaginary" characters brought life to the film by displaying the faces behind the masked moralities our society tells us.As a child of unwanted birth and as an adoptee, I know deep in my heart how much I advocate for abortion. I will always side with what is just and right; the ability of women to have access to reproductive health and the power of women to make decisions for their own life.Maraming salamat sa tapang at galing mo, Direk Tonet.

I watched this film with my very religious family. I didn't say a word the whole duration of the film‚Äî yet every few minutes, without fail, at least one of my family members would nag me about teenage pregnancy and promiscuity. I heard countless demeaning phrases like "kita mo yan? alam mo na ha, pag ikaw" and "san ka pupulutin kung di namin sinasabi sayo 'to?". I'm 15, they don't even let me watch movies with sex scenes on the family tv. (but obviously i still do watch movies beyond my age rating) The overbearing nature of religion is truly a problem in the philippines; and among our people, the vast majority of our country is made up of catholics, and it seems like the state is sometimes one with the church because of that fact. I commend this movie for being a step in the right direction. It's showing the true nature of these things to our often ignorant and close-minded society. I know it's still a long way to a progressive philippines, but atleast i know there are still measures being made to ensure that we will get there. Someday, somehow.

It is terrifying and undeniably demeaning that many, if not all, do not have access to these basic rights and thus continue to endanger the lives of many women out there. Bonus na rin appearance ni Piolo Pascual.ü§ûI could yap about this film but for the sake of my fingers typing this review, I‚Äôll leave this as it is for now.All in all, this one is a great watch.

Nadama ko sa pelikula na mag-isa si Sunshine sa kanyang tinatahak ngunit nadama ko din na may iilang sumoporta sa kanya at ito ay mga kapwa kababaihan.Ito ang mga babae sa istorya na tumatak para sa akin: Sa eksena kung saan tinanggihan ng isang lalaking doctor i-attend ang batang nag pahilot sa takot na mawalan siya ng lisensiya at isang babaeng doctor ang nag lakas loob na tulungan ang bata. Ito ay realidad na ang batas sa bansang ito ay nakaka apekto sa pag lilingkod kapwa. Ang ate ni Sunshine na inintindi at sinuportohan hindi lamang ang desisyon kundi ang pangarap ni Sunshine. Malaking aspeto ang pagkakaroon ng kapamilya na hindi ka i-guiguilt trip o susumbatan ka sa nagawa mo, bagkus nag tiwala siya na alam ni Sunshine kung ano ang makakabuti para sa sarili niya. Ang imaginary child na nag boses na gets niya ang alab sa puso na makamit ang pangarap ni Sunshine. Sa tanong na who will protect women? Ang sagot ay tayo. Tayong kapwa kababaihan ang palaging tumutulong sa isa't isa dahil alam natin ang bigat ng mundong pasan pasan natin. Sa bansang hindi prayoridad ang kalusugan ng kababaihan, napakita ng pelikulang ito ang realidad ng isang babae kakapit sa kung anong meron sa paligid niya na paraan para mag palaglag dahil pinag kakait sa atin ang accessible healthcare. Ang pelikulang ito ay para sa lahat ng kababaihan na tahimik lumalaban sa ingay ng paligid na palaging may kuda sa kung anong daan ang dapat nating tahakin.

Grabe napaiyak naman ako nito. Although I have personal reservations about Maris Racal due to past issues, her performance in this film was undeniably amazing. Sunshine is a definite eye-opener regarding religion, stigma, and the taboo surrounding abortion matters here in the Philippines.I genuinely feel for all the women represented by the characters of Sunshine and Rhed. They may have different names, but they share a rough, unfair path: being stigmatized and pressured to conform to religious and misogynistic beliefs about motherhood. They are forced into the role of nurturing a child, often without considering their own agency.I particularly noticed the scene when Miggy and his father confronted Sunshine about her situation. They never once asked her what she wanted. Their "plans" were simply laid out for her to accept without a word, effectively depriving her of choice. This lack of genuine care is what hurts. Furthermore, the film shows how these women are forced to go through dangerous and unhygienic lengths just to pursue their personal dreams, highlighting how their rights as human beings are limited solely because of their CHOICE.I appreciate this film immensely, and it should be talked about more. The tragic reality of Rhed‚Äôs character, a 13-year-old victim raped and impregnated by her own uncle, is a situation faced by many. Yet, victims like her are still discriminated against for wanting an abortion. The movie effectively represents this toxicity, such as the scene where the OB-GYN cruelly orders a literally pale and blue Sunshine to "repent" while she is struggling in a hospital bed.This film is beautifully made. I sincerely hope that someday, people will truly receive the message: Every woman should have a choice. Depriving them of that fundamental choice does NOT make one a saint.

This kind of shit is barbaric and has no place in the current state of the world. The ending was very powerful. However, I feel like final final scene was unnecessary, it could have ended with the "gets ko na" scene.Jesus, Pilipinas. Do fucking better. Protect your citizens. Protect women.

Gets ko si Sunshine.This film really captures me the most. As a woman who grew up in a most conservative country and a religious family, I feel the comfort of the movie. I know that tackling this kind of topic would raise brows to the people especially the one who‚Äôs spirituality believes that a women shouldn‚Äôt undergo abortion even if she really didn‚Äôt want to bear the child. Actually, it‚Äôs even funnier that this country preach that abortion should ban but the truth is there is a lack of education about sex, abortion, and contraceptives. Additionally, it‚Äôs so hypocrisy and misogynistic that people really blame woman for getting pregnant but NOT THE MAN?! In fact, they are the ones who put babies inside the woman‚Äôs womb. I really learned so many lessons in the movie which open my mind to the struggles of a woman. It‚Äôs disappointing that people keep preaching what‚Äôs right or wrong but THEY NEVER HELP AND UNDERSTAND THESE WOMEN. The movie open my mind that abortion SHOULD BE LEGALIZE. Abortion ISN‚ÄôT a sin, murder, nor crime. IT‚ÄôS A HEALTH CARE. It‚Äôs NOT selfish. It‚Äôs okay.But it is just sad that the Philippines is not yet ready to understand and tackle this kind of topic. I get Sunshine. The guilt-tripping, shame, and misogyny are tackled in a best possible way to give the viewers assurance and comfort. Also, it gives reminder that Filipinos should really open their minds and change their mindset. Women didn‚Äôt deserve the shame, the hate, and mostly the expectations that have been throwing to them just because THEY ARE WOMEN. For fucking sake. WOMEN NEED SUPPORT NOT A FUCKING JUDGEMENT FROM THE PEOPLE WHO‚ÄôS CLAIMING TO BE A SPIRITUALLY ACTIVE BUT CANNOT OPEN THEIR MINDS AND THINK RIGHT.I hope and wish that the government legalize abortion. It is not a shameful thing to do. It is not killing. It is a self-care ‚Äî A HEALTH CARE. People should know and understand that.Overall, I really love the movie and it will have a special place in my heart. I hope, Filipino directors would produce many movies like this to promote woman and to educate people that abortion is a health care.

kudos kay dir. jadaone kasi bihira lang ‚Äòyung ganitong ingay sa filipino cinema, buti na lang walang twitter mga matatanda baka ma-cancel pa ‚Äòyan siya lolanyway, kahit baliktarin mo man ang mundo, walang mawawala sa lalaki when he engages in coitus‚Äîkahit pa makabuntis ito. and, the film gave us this statement as it is. moreover, it exactly depicts how our society reacts when a woman participtes in sexual intercourse: bawal, nakakahiya, nakakawala ng dignidad. that our society reinforces this same tired belief: kapag babae ang nagkamali, pangalan at pangarap niya ang nakataya.nakakairita kasi napakatotoo, ‚Äúmag-iingat ka,‚Äù ‚Äúisipin mo lagi ‚Äòyung future mo‚Äî‚Äòyung pamilya mo,‚Äù ‚Äútandaan mo na ‚Äòyang virginity mo ang pinakamagandang maireregalo mo sa asawa mo,‚Äù mga katagang palagi mo maririnig kapag babae ka pero ni isang beses hindi ibubulong sa isang lalaki. nakakainis kasi hindi siya exaggerated, it‚Äôs not melodramatic, it‚Äôs reality. the silent judgment, the unsolicited advice of people, and the casual sexism na parang background noise ng buhay ng babae. it makes the audience uncomfortable, distressed, and painfully aware of how familiar everything is.ang ganda lang kasi it‚Äôs not about regret, rather it‚Äôs reclamation. it gives you this dichotomy between burden and freedom, as well as give you the raw and aching truth na nakakagalit, nakakaiyak, nakakaputangina kasi bakit hanggang ngayon ganito pa rin?ay, putangina rin ng mga lalaki, putangina ng mga hindi naniniwala na virginity is a social construct that‚Äôs used as a tool for the patriarchy to label a woman‚Äôs dignity, putangina ng mga hindi hinahayaang magkaroon ng bodily autonomy ang mga babae. legalize abortion at sorry papa god sa bad wordssana gets

From the very beginning, the film doesn‚Äôt sugarcoat anything. It throws you straight into the raw, unfiltered reality of the city. You feel the noise, the chaos, the sense of being overwhelmed, like you‚Äôre standing right in the middle of it all.Pero beyond the city‚Äôs noise, Sunshine digs into something heavier. It shows the weight of Sunshine‚Äôs struggle, the clash between personal pain, religious expectations, and society‚Äôs harsh judgment. The movie doesn‚Äôt shy away from the reality na hanggang ngayon, ang hirap mag-access ng abortion services sa Pilipinas dahil illegal pa rin ito. It captures how isolating it is to face a problem this heavy, and how hard it is to seek help in a system that refuses to understand.Overall, I like it.

A young aspiring teenage Filipino gymnast who everyone looks up to has been selected in the National team to participate in Olympics. Her nightmare begins when she finds out she is pregnant. Her boyfriend wants her to abort. Her best friend disowns her. She hallucinates a small girl chasing her around trying to make her feel guilty. Desperate to pursue her gymnastics career, she buys a product from the local black market. She rents a room in a shady inn, inserts the product and ends up bleeding profusely. She wakes up in an anti abortion clinic to learn that the fetus is still alive. ‚ÄòSunshine‚Äô plays out like a horror movie as the characters try to come to terms with their reality. The tension, fear and desperation is palpable. Sunshine‚Äôs journey from numb helplessness to a woman who wants to pursue her dreams is truly remarkable.Abortion is illegal in the Philippines under all circumstances, including rape, incest, or when the mother's life is at risk. Black markets of abortifacients thrive near places of worship and street side shops. Hospitals refuse admission and doctors perform secret illegal procedures. Antoinette Jadone‚Äôs writing and direction is raw and brutal. The narrative is neither preachy nor claims to know a solution to a complex problem that leaves women without agency. It simply critiques the situation and demands that viewers confront it along with women who are left helpless in front of politics and religion. Maris Racal pours her heart into the titular character and you would feel nothing but compassion and empathy for Sunshine Francisco.

There‚Äôs always a thin, trembling line between a patriarchal society and the relentless social construct that insists women still can‚Äôt decide for themselves‚Äîleast of all when it comes to their own bodies. And even if we try to drown out the noise, this film refuses to stay quiet. It hits too hard. It shows the very realities women go through in today‚Äôs world.What makes it even bolder is its willingness to be raw, relevant, and unapologetically confrontational in a country where abortion remains illegal. It doesn‚Äôt tiptoe. It doesn‚Äôt soften its edges. Instead, it stares straight into the contradictions of a culture that claims to protect life while silencing the ones who live it.

Visceral, gut-wrenching, and politically relevant. Sunshine is not only a film about resilience, it‚Äôs a commentary on the disparity between human systems and human persons. When a system is run by patriarchal standards, women live life isolated or alienated by how she is defined. Religious psychosis, misogyny, and the ramifications of a paranoid society are the bigger forces that shape the circumstances of our protagonist, Sunshine. I love how the movie doesn‚Äôt attempt to glorify, demean, or misrepresent any of‚Ä¶

this is someone‚Äôs life right now. put yourself in their place.you can understand sunshine even if you‚Äôre not pregnant. even if you‚Äôre not a gymnast. even if you‚Äôre not joining the olympics. she‚Äôs a woman filled with rage, ambition, and dreams. in a place that reeks from layers of sweat, the stench of alcohol, noise, spit, and smoke‚Äîunder the blazing sun and along filthy streets, sunshine keeps shining. she can carry herself even when only a few stand behind her. it‚Äôs hard to be a woman. it‚Äôs hard to live on your own. it‚Äôs hard to bear problems you never wanted in the first place. it‚Äôs hard to live comfortably when you don‚Äôt have the privilege to attain that right away. but if no one reaches for her hand, she‚Äôll take her own. because her story isn‚Äôt about waiting for someone else to save her‚Äîit‚Äôs about uncovering the strength that has always been inside her.

jadaone never fails to deliver a movie that starts strong but falls flat and chokes on the message it‚Äôs attempting to tell, whatever that may be. every story she writes is abysmal and surface level and almost always advocates for shallow feminism, hanggang doon nalang ba tayo? spouting for women‚Äôs rights without actually understanding the nuance of what you‚Äôre actually advocating for?maliban sa poverty porn na kinatutuwaan ipakita palagi ni jadaone, from fan girl to sunshine, she also likes showcasing sexual assault as a plot device, only this time it wasn‚Äôt shown to us explicitly‚Äîwow, how she‚Äôs advanced in her writing noh? (sarcasm meant)while i appreciate the gritty and emotional moments of the film especially when the focus is entirely on the movie‚Äôs protagonist who it‚Äôs named after (maris carried this entire film along with the supporting cast‚Äôs acting) it‚Äôs overshadowed by it‚Äôs dogshit abysmal surface level performative writing, its inclusion of imaginary children that is either a representation of the characters and their inner child or their unborn children which confuses and irritates me as they‚Äôre shown way too much, the on the nose messaging of conservatism in the philippines, the lack of detail on how important sunshine‚Äôs dream actually is because it focuses on another separate character that rids sunshine a chunk of her story and conflict, and the abstract, hollow message they‚Äôre trying to advocate for.genuinely, can we take the pen away from this grown ass woman? not only does she exploit the masa to serve her story but women as well, nakakabastos sa totoo lang, not very feminist and not very for the masa also‚Äîadd to the fact that jadaone probably thinks that her audience is stupid and can‚Äôt read in between the lines for how she chooses to write the story. more actions, less words sana, more time spent in the writer‚Äôs room, less color-grading and filming quiapo‚Äôs slums for your poverty porn sana.i could say more but i‚Äôd have to give half a star at least for the cast‚Äôs amazing performances, they carried this film, and they deserve the recognition especially maris racal. also nagulat ako andito pala si piolo pascual haha.

Hands down. One of the best filipino films I have ever seen.This deserves more than what I‚Äôll write. More than the stars I‚Äôve given. More than a mere category of ‚Äòfavorites‚Äô.This is worth talking about. The film I should see when tackling feminism. The film that shows how the Philippines lack support for its beautiful and brave women.Una sa lahat, fuck quiapo air. Quiapo‚Äîang baho, ang sikip, ang init! Pero Quiapo‚Ä¶ a place where you‚Äôll find even the tiniest bit of hope, a place where even an ounce of solution can be found, a place where help exists, even if only through a few people.i also loved how fuckass men were portrayed in this movie. walang kwentang jowa, walang kwentang kapatid, walang kwentang tatay, walang kwentang tito, walang kwentang doktor. Tangina ang may kwentang lalaki lang ata rito is yung tricycle driver eh. Tangina ng mga lalaking ganyan. Patriarchy at its finest! Also, fuck women who let themselves be abused by this power. Yes, I‚Äôm talking about YOU nanay ni Mary Grace.as it progressed, onti-onti kong nararamdaman yung emotional sincerity ng film. yung dilemmas of decisions ni sunshine and yung heartbreaking truth about Mary Grace‚Äôs pregnancy. 13 years old pa lang siya? Yes, 13 years old pa lang siya. The movie refuses to romanticize their situation. instead, it leans into the uncomfortable truths of being a young woman in a society that praises discipline, resilience, and sacrifice yet offers little support when life derails. Director Jadaone shapes the film with a raw, documentary-like honesty: tight shots of silent breakdowns, stripped-down scenes with no dramatic score, and a narrative that mirrors the suffocating pressure placed on young Filipinas navigating taboo choices.Lastly, ang nagustuhan ko talaga sa film na to is the fact na the film didn‚Äôt fail to show and acknowledge the other women surrounding sunshine. women who, though not always in the spotlight, embody the many forms of pressure, expectation, and silent resilience that shape the world she moves in. they all carry their own versions of sacrifice: women praised for being disciplined, nurturing, and endlessly strong, yet rarely offered the same support they tirelessly give. like seriously? the maternity ward scene broke my heart so much üíî seeing allthe women sharing the same beds also shows how fucked up our healthcare system really is. Tayo-tayo lang rin nagtutulungan. Tayo lang ang sumusuporta sa isa‚Äôt isa. Tayo lang mga babae. Kudos to that tindera. Ironic lang na sa harap pa talaga ng mga rebulto ni santo ni√±o nagtinda ng pampalaglag ü§ç these kinds of religious beliefs shouldn‚Äôt really hinder us from doing what‚Äôs right and best for ourselves. and in showing these women‚Äôs quiet struggles, the film expands its emotional weight, reminding us that the story isn‚Äôt just about one girl‚Äôs burden but about an entire generation of women expected to endure everything while being thanked for it in silence. kulang pa tayo sa pansin, sa pagmamahal, at sa suporta. i hope that someday, all of us can finally feel how to live as a woman and be loved as a woman.

Rewatched it and still felt underwhelmed. The trailer was so promising and I expected a lot. I‚Äôm all for it from what they‚Äôre trying to convey but the storytelling wasn‚Äôt it. Execution is realistic tho. I believe most of us relates in jeepney scene when you‚Äôre in the verge of breaking down and you don‚Äôt know what to do but to breathe slowly and comfort yourself, hoping no one would notice. Love the irony, the symbolism, and the heats.But then again, they be trying to highlight everything all at once but failed to deliver why we‚Äôre here in the first place. It was moving, as a woman. BUT AS A WOMAN I was hoping for a more impactful message since it opened a lot of discourse. Women are far more complex and I was looking for chaos in what a woman feels in a society where everyone are so entitled to decide on how a woman should act and carry themselves. The movie could‚Äôve gone deeper, one that touches diff range of emotions. It just doesn‚Äôt feel genuine, yk.Overall, Im giving it 4 stars. Such a brave movie for a conservative country.

Kudos to Direk Tonet, Maris Racal, and the whole team responsible for creating this film, thank you for being brave and casting a light on our nation‚Äôs issues often overlooked in fear of the cultural taboo it carries. I would have rated it 5 stars, but the choice to represent Sunshine‚Äôs internal conflict with herself through a hallucinated child character doesn‚Äôt sit right with me. Jadaone‚Äôs direction results in jarring tonal shifts that muddle the film‚Äôs emotional center. What was perhaps intended as a bold attempt at cinematic expression to illustrate inner turmoil instead dilutes the stakes, softening the thorniness of the subject matter with a cartoonish detour. It‚Äôs an interesting idea but one that never quite coheres with the rest of the film‚Äôs pro-choice sensibility. In fact, by personifying an unborn child as a character which speaks and thinks, then Sunshine unintentionally reinforces the very moral framing that anti-abortion rhetoric thrives on. It circles back into the age-old ‚Äúwhen does life begin?‚Äù debate‚Äîa question that continues to paralyze policymaking in the country, even when the conversation should be about autonomy, access, and proper healthcare. The film doesn‚Äôt just inherit this moral hang-up; it stages it, frames it, and in doing so, muddies the clarity of its own politics. Though, I will still give my flowers to this movie. It helped brought upon a conversation in our country long overdue and for that I am grateful. I hope it inspires other filmmakers to be bold in the face of a country that chooses to be blind to issues that continue to grow with no solutions in sight.

people often judge teenage pregnancy as the result of ‚Äúgiving in to temptation,‚Äù but this film shows the other side‚Äînot all teenage pregnancies are wanted or chosen. what i love about the film is how powerful it is; it resonates deeply with viewers and delivers a clear message consistently from start to finish.maraming sunshine sa lipunan‚Äîna biglaan, takot, at walang lakas ng loob na harapin ang pagiging ina‚Äîpero hindi ito usapin na masama ng tao si sunshine kaagad nang dahil lamang sa hindi pa siya handa. a moment of temptation is not enough reason to demand she accept her situation, as forcing a woman into parenthood before she is ready is a far greater mistake.i hope this film opens more eyes and highlights the need to strengthen reproductive rights in our country, recognizing that abortion is a right for all women. men who cause pregnancies rarely face the same scrutiny or shame; women, on the other hand, bear society‚Äôs judgment alone.abortion is not always chosen for pleasure‚Äîoften it is the result of abuse or exploitation.it is heartbreaking that in the philippines, a case of violence against women is reported every 57 minutes. globally, over 30% of women‚Äîmore than 737 million‚Äîexperience abuse from partners or non-partners. many feel trapped, unable to leave because they are pregnant and have no right to terminate.in february 2024, save the children urged stronger reproductive rights in the philippines, noting that 35% of filipino girls under 15 became pregnant from 2021 to 2022‚Äîclear victims of abuse and exploitation. this is a critical issue that the government must address.women have the right to control their own bodies and make their own choices‚Äîregardless of religion, culture, or social pressure. they are often the most vulnerable and left behind in such situations.thank you to sunshine for her courage in standing up for herself and pursuing her dreams, and thank you to the film for portraying these realities.as i read somewhere, ‚Äúmarami ang hindi mapapatawad si sunshine dahil sa ginawa niya, pero sapat naman nang napatawad ni sunshine ang sarili niya.‚Äù
‚Äú‚Äòyung pangarap ko, kung ano‚Äông pangarap niya.‚Äù

hurt to watch, but also necessary. we definitely need more easily-accessible movies that stir up discourse on important issues like this. by easily accessible i obviously mean the price and the length of the runtime they had in cinemas, but also the straightforwardness of the story with just one metaphorical element, the little girl. knowing filipino audiences it‚Äôs almost better not to hide in metaphors or hard-to-get undertones, else they misinterpret because this country needs so much more improvement in media literacy, comprehension, and just plain empathy for others who have different beliefs. not to say a lot of filipinos are stupid‚Ä¶ that stupidity is also, unfortunately, engineered by the system we‚Äôve been stuck in since forever. but anyway. solid movie for sure!

And then there‚Äôs being realist at the end na it‚Äôs just okay dahil‚Ä¶hindi natin alam ang pinagdadaanan ng bawat isa. kudos.

lahat ng tao ay may sariling ingay na tinatahak. sa pelikula, hindi lang ito ingay ng traffic o tambutso. ito yung ingay ng moralidad, ng tsismis, ng relihiyong mabilis magturo pero mabagal magmahal. ito yung ingay ng mga taong hindi naman mabubuhay sa katawan mo pero sila ang pinakamalakas magdikta kung ano ang dapat mong maramdaman, gawin, at piliin. at sa lahat ng ito, isang nineteen-year-old girl ang pasan ang mundo‚Äîa girl who should‚Äôve been allowed to dream freely, pero sinasakal na ng lipunang takot sa kababaihang may sariling isip.isang bagay na ramdam mo agad sa pelikula: magkakampi ang mga babae. halos lahat ng karakter ay babae, at karamihan sa kanila may dalang munting piraso ng simpatya. isang kolektibong danas. isang unspoken sisterhood built on the multiple burdens that women carry: being caregivers, dreamers, breadwinners, shock absorbers of society‚Äôs cruelty. pero hindi rin romantisado ang pelikula‚Äîmay mga babaeng kakampi, at may mga babaeng hindi. katulad ng doktor na ultraconservative, na nagpapaalala sa atin ng painful truth: hindi lahat ng babae ay mapagpalaya, at hindi lahat ng babae ay kakampi sa kapwa babae. minsan, ang mismong sistemang umaapi ay umiiral din sa mga babaeng natutong ipasa-pasa ang sakit.pinaka-mahalaga sa lahat: hindi totoong pagiging makasarili ang pagdedesisyon ng babae para sa sarili niyang katawan. kung may isang ‚Äúgets ko na‚Äù moment ang sunshine, ito ‚Äòyon. kung sarili lang niya ang iniisip niya, wala sana tayong ganitong pelikula. wala sana tayong ganitong lalim. pero ang totoo, bawat desisyon niya ay puno ng takot, pagmamahal, at pag-asa‚Äîlahat ng bagay na kinalimutan ng lipunan kapag babae ang may kailangan pumili.dito rin pumapasok ang simbolismo ng batang babae‚Äîang unborn child, ang personified conscience. ariana is 13 y/o's own past self, her own fear, her own what-if. lahat ng interaction nila ay nangyayari ‚Äúsa loob,‚Äù sa pinakatahimik na sulok ng isip ng babaeng hinahati ng daigdig. at nung ending, it‚Äôs for herself. the hug is acceptance. ang yakap na iyon ay tahimik na paglaya.pero kahit sa mundong pilit nagpapatahimik sa kababaihan, may irony na hindi kayang itago ang pelikula: sa isang konserbatibong lipunan, ang nagbebenta ng religious figures ay siya ring nagbebenta ng abortion pill. ang ob ay bigot. ang bahay ay hindi laging ligtas. ang simbahan ay humuhusga. at ang babae? wala man lang tunay na espasyo para huminga. bakit ang mga lalaki, may opsyon? bakit ang kababaihan, pilit pinapapili pero hindi ginagawaran ng tunay na choice?dito nagiging mas malakas si sunshine. hindi siya martyr. hindi siya sainted victim. she doesn‚Äôt just endure‚Äîshe decides. she chooses herself kahit alam niyang bawat galaw niya may kasamang kurot ng panibagong judgment. she‚Äôs not fearless, but she moves anyway. at minsan, iyon na ang pinaka-matapang na pwedeng gawin ng babae sa bansang sobrang hilig kontrolin ang katawan at kinabukasan niya. dedma sa ingay. dedma sa prejudice. kung may pangarap ka, hawakan mo, kahit pa buong mundo pa ang naka abang na magkamali ka. ang sabi ni direk jadaone, ang pagbubuntis ay magbabago sa katawan ni sunshine, sa career niya, sa buong trajectory niya bilang atleta. at totoo‚Äîpara kay sunshine, ang pregnancy ay literal career suicide. at dito umaalingawngaw ang tanong na gusto talagang ipukpok ng pelikula: bakit ba laging kababaihan ang kinakailangang magsakripisyo ng pangarap? bakit ang freedom ng babae ay laging conditional?kaya oo‚Äîdecriminalize abortion. kasi ang autonomy ay hindi dapat ipinaglalaban, dapat innate. ang katawan ng babae ay hindi battleground para sa moralidad ng iba.in the end, sunshine reminds you that sometimes the bravest thing a girl can do is to choose herself, quietly, consistently, even when the world says she shouldn‚Äôt.

‚Äòyong pangarap ko, kung ano'ng pangarap niya. ‚ãÜÀö‡øîEspecially in the Philippines, society is stacked against women. From secretive clinic visits to hushed conversations with unsympathetic adults‚Äî with Sunshine‚Äôs journey, you can feel the judgement of a society that constantly polices women‚Äôs bodies and their choices. Patriarchy is relentless : they leave it up to the women to pick up the pieces that the men shattered‚Äî "Bahala ka na diyan, just get rid of it". Maris Racal‚Äôs performance was exquisite, ramdam mo yung pagod, sakit, and overwhelming suffocation that Sunshine faces as she navigates through making a choice that is supposed to be hers and hers alone. Every flip, every landing, every stretch was a step towards her dreams‚Äî the stage, the recognition, the life she has ever envisioned for so long. Sunshine‚Äôs journey is not just about survival; it‚Äôs about the courage to continue dreaming in a world determined to limit her. Gymnastics wasn‚Äôt more than a sport, it was her identity, her sanctuary, the place that gave her hope to keep believing. At the end, pinili niya pangarap niya, despite the fear, the sadness, and the guilt, her decision was a refusal to let anyone dictate her future, to let her stop that dream.

Sobrang gets lang talaga ng palabas na ‚Äòto, sana napanood ko siya on a bigger screen. Ang galing ni Maris Racal, totoo nga na the moment na alam niyang buntis siya, naka-autopilot na siya at alam niya na kung ano yung gusto niyang mangyari kahit na hindi niya alam kung paano. Sa totoo lang, isa sa scene na napatanong na lang talaga ako kung ano bang silbi talaga ng mga lalaki ay yung nasa hospital si Sunshine kasi dinala niya si Menggay doon, tapos ipinakita yung mga kama na kaunti lang ang espasyo sa isa‚Äôt isa, yung mga manganganak pa lang at nakapanganak ng mga babae na nag-uusap at nag-abutan ng gamit ng bata. Ewan ko, ang hirap manganak, ang hirap maging nanay, at ang hirap ng estado ng healthcare sa Pilipinas. Bukod pa roon, nandoon yung bigat tsaka ingay sa kabuuan ng palabas. Bigat nung dinadala ni Sunshine bilang babae na hindi suportado ng karamihan ang pagpapalaglag dahil tayo ay nasa isang relihiyosong bansa. Yung ingay sa paligid, yung mga dasal, yung desperasyon, yung konsensya habang paikot-ikot siya para lang makahanap ng solusyon. Ayun, sana naman mas mapag-usapan pa ang reproductive health ng mga kababaihan sa Pilipinas, and yes decriminalize abortion.

First of all, I know that this movie premiered at the 49th Toronto International Film Festival in 2024 and arrived in Philippine cinemas 4 months ago. And now that it finally dropped on Netflix‚Ä¶ I hope I‚Äôm not too late to say it finally: This movie is powerful üò≠üíØAntoinette Jadaone delivers one of her most fearless films yet with ‚Äòùó¶ùòÇùóªùòÄùóµùó∂ùóªùó≤‚Äô ‚Äî a coming-of-age sports drama that hits with quiet power and emotional honesty.Maris Racal plays the titular character, a young gymnast on the road to the Olympics. Her world revolves around discipline, repetition, and the dream of making it to the competition she‚Äôs trained her whole life for. But when she discovers she‚Äôs pregnant, her perfectly controlled world cracks open.What I loved about the film is how it never sensationalizes her situation. Sunshine‚Äôs fear is treated with quiet realism. The movie acknowledges how complicated teenage pregnancy is, especially in a society where abortion, reproductive rights, and bodily autonomy remain heavily stigmatized and often misunderstood.These themes are controversial. And yes, the movie will divide people. But ‚Äòùó¶ùòÇùóªùòÄùóµùó∂ùóªùó≤‚Äô refuses to look away from the truth: ùòîùò¢ùòØùò∫ ùò∫ùò∞ùò∂ùòØùò® ùòçùò™ùò≠ùò™ùò±ùò™ùòØùò¢ùò¥ ùòßùò¢ùò§ùò¶ ùò¥ùòµùò≥ùò∂ùò®ùò®ùò≠ùò¶ùò¥ ùò≠ùò™ùò¨ùò¶ ùòµùò©ùò™ùò¥ ùò™ùòØ ùò¥ùò™ùò≠ùò¶ùòØùò§ùò¶. ùòàùòØùò• ùòµùò©ùò¶ùò∫ ùò•ùò¶ùò¥ùò¶ùò≥ùò∑ùò¶ ùò¶ùòÆùò±ùò¢ùòµùò©ùò∫, ùòØùò∞ùòµ ùò´ùò∂ùò•ùò®ùòÆùò¶ùòØùòµ.Maris is phenomenal here. She carries the entire emotional weight of the story with a performance that feels painfully real. She rarely breaks down on screen, but you think her internal collapse in the smallest expressions ‚Äî the breath she holds, the way she avoids eye contact, the way she pushes her dream forward while everything else is falling apart.ùóßùóµùó∂ùòÄ ùó∂ùòÄ ùó≤ùóÆùòÄùó∂ùóπùòÜ ùóºùóªùó≤ ùóºùó≥ ùóµùó≤ùóø ùóØùó≤ùòÄùòÅ ùóΩùó≤ùóøùó≥ùóºùóøùó∫ùóÆùóªùó∞ùó≤ùòÄ ùòÅùóº ùó±ùóÆùòÅùó≤.The supporting cast ‚Äî particularly Jennica Garcia, Meryll Soriano, Rhed Bustamante, and Xyriel Manabat ‚Äî also elevate the film, each representing a different kind of pressure or support Sunshine faces. And yeah, some male characters in the movie definitely got what they deserved. üòÖJadaone‚Äôs direction is quiet, patient, and uncomfortably close ‚Äî exactly how it should be. The movie lets us follow Sunshine‚Äôs anxiety and feel the suffocating pressure she‚Äôs under.One of the film‚Äôs boldest artistic choices is the recurring appearance of a mysterious girl who seems to follow Sunshine. At first it‚Äôs confusing, then a bit eerie, then surprisingly emotional. I won‚Äôt spoil anything, but when the film finally reveals who she represents‚Ä¶ üò≠. It‚Äôs symbolic, heartbreaking, and adds a deeper emotional layer to Sunshine‚Äôs arc.Beyond the gymnastics, beyond the controversy, Sunshine is really about choice ‚Äî and how young women often aren‚Äôt given the space to empower themselves to make their own choices.The movie conveys important messages: your body is your own; silence can mask the deepest struggles; the pressure to be perfect is harmful; pursuing dreams matters, but so is ensuring one's survival; kindness fosters safety, while judgment breeds fear; and young women need safe spaces. The movie doesn‚Äôt push a specific viewpoint ‚Äî it drives for humanity.Overall, ‚Äòùó¶ùòÇùóªùòÄùóµùó∂ùóªùó≤‚Äô is brave, heartbreaking, and painfully relevant. It does not shout ‚Äî it whispers truths that hit even harder. Indeed, it‚Äôs a film that mirrors reality for many young women today, and one that our society needs to see, even if the conversations it starts are uncomfortable.With that being said, I‚Äôm going to give this movie‚Ä¶9/10! ‚≠êÔ∏è (Woooo!)

Where Filipino films trend to historic dramas and at times big explosive bursts of emotion, Sunshine reflects the good and the ugly of Filipino society in the modern times. It is within the same type as the classics like Maynila sa Mga Kuko ng Liwanag, but where it could've easily just copied that same old formula of poverty, crime, and the ugliness that lies beneath the city, the film chooses to explore controversial topics at its heart and anchors it toward really good character dynamics, not to mention where other films center around a male character from the rural side or from the slums, we instead focus on a lady who is faced with a great moral dilemma (in the Filipino perspective, you'll get it) when her dreams are on the verge of being stripped away from her. While watching, I sometimes forget that it is a Filipino film (not to sound derogatory or self-hating btw) because it strays away from tired old cliches other Filipino films do, and while the blueprints of those tropes are present, they are presented in a light that feels more subdued than its usual contemporaries. Also, I do love how the film does respect the audience in choosing not to explain certain things, letting us fill in the gaps.It's a great watch, in my opinion. And I feel that this film should be at the helm of some sort of renaissance for Philippine cinema, where we aren't afraid to speak out and be bold while also making great art out of it.

GANDA WTHit cuts deep, revealing the brutal realities of being a woman in a society na hanggang ngayon ay kinakadena pa rin ng patriarchy; mahirap maging babae, lalo na sa pilipinas, at ramdam mo ‚Äòyan sa bawat eksena. its raw honesty, feminist gaze, and unflinching portrayal expose how our culture endlessly polices women‚Äôs bodies, choices, and dreams, lalo na when the world expects them to sacrifice habang ang iba ay malayang nakakalakad palayo. by the end, the film leaves you holding both galit and pag-asa, reminding us that kahit ilang bagyo pa, women will still rise ‚Äî mabagal man, pero matatag, like sunshine breaking through the darkest clouds.

Maganda ang Sunshine, napakita ang pagiging taboo ng abortion, teen pregnancy, at kung gaano kakonti ang kontrol ng babae sa sarili nilang katawan sa Pilipinas.Sobrang totoo ng pag-arte ni Maris Racal, kaya ramdam mo lahat ng pinagdadaanan ni Sunshine. Medyo bitin lang sa pagpapakita kung gaano siya kagaling bilang atleta, at may ilang plot, lalo na yung parallel story ng isang buntis na biktima ng pang-aabuso, na kahit malakas, medyo rushed at overwhelming.Pero kahit ganun, malakas pa rin ang dating ng pelikula sa social issues at sa pagpapakita ng totoong buhay sa Maynila.

this film stayed with me. raw, quiet, tapang na hindi sumisigaw pero tumatagos.unang-una: Maris Racal. hindi lang nag-portray ‚Äî she became Sunshine. yung pagod, yung takot, yung pagka-desperate pero umaasa pa rin‚Ä¶ ramdam mo hanggang buto. this is the face of so many young women na araw-araw lumalaban in a country that tells them what to be, what to do, and what to carry.ang ganda ng pagkakahuli sa Manila ‚Äî yung sikip, yung init, yung ingay, pati yung bigat na hindi mo maipaliwanag. hindi siya romanticized; totoo lang. yung Quiapo scenes? sobrang accurate na parang naamoy mo na yung alinsangan at dasal at pag-asa ng mga taong dumadaan dito para humanap ng solusyon sa problema na hindi sila binibigyan ng choice.and that‚Äôs the heart of the film: choice. or the lack of it. bilang kababaihan, ang hirap pag-usapan ng reproductive rights dito sa Pilipinas kasi every conversation is haunted by guilt, religion, and judgment. pero Sunshine manages to hold that tension ‚Äî yung guilt, yung fear, yung what-if ‚Äî without punishing the woman at the center of it.this isn‚Äôt just a film ‚Äî it‚Äôs a mirror. it asks questions na hindi madali, and refuses to hold your hand para bigyan ka ng sagot. it lets you sit with discomfort. it lets you ask yourself: kung hindi ikaw ang nasa sitwasyon, bakit ikaw ang magdedesisyon?

What will you do if your dream is at stake because of one mistake?Sunshine delivers a powerful message about reproductive rights and the need for access to safe and legal abortion.The film shows the current state of healthcare in the Philippines and how this basic necessity has become inaccessible, especially to those living below the poverty line.I like how the film does not romanticize the societal issue of unwanted pregnancy. Instead, it highlights how stigma deeply affects women‚Äôs decision-making about their own bodies. It shows how the main character struggles with an internal conflict and debates with her own conscience.While the film clearly presents why abortion should be legalized and recognized as part of healthcare in the Philippines, it also portrays how religion and health often clash. It is true that our country is still in the process of accepting that abortion is a right that should be available to all women.Some might argue that safe sex is the only way to avoid these situations, but we cannot ignore the fact that many women experience sexual abuse, rape, or non-consensual ejaculation during intercourse.Sunshine is not just a film that explains why safe abortion should be legalized; it calls our attention to consider the issue without guilt-tripping women through religion or societal pressure.Women should have the freedom to decide what to do with their own bodies. Marriage or co-parenting should not be treated as a band-aid solution to a lifelong responsibility. These solutions do not apply to everyone, especially to those who do not have the means to support a child.I know we all have different perspectives on this issue, but thinking long-term about the future of our children depends on how ready we truly are to take on this responsibility.

Hindi talaga ako binibigo ni direk Jadaone kapag usapang isyu, pakikipagsapalaran, at boses ng kababaihan. Kuhang-kuha rin ang realidad ng Maynila (bigla kong naalala ang Maynila sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag [1975]).Mabuhay ka direk Jadaone!

Love how the film depicts the harsh reality of what women have to go through just to be able to decide for themselves and their BODIES!! This movie really goes to show how making abortion illegal makes it so much harder and dangerous for women. It does not sanctify the value of life since in the first place the life of the woman is endangered. Moreover, I love how Manila gets depicted in this light, it shows the good and bad that comes with the city. It is bad for obvious reasons, the normalized chaos that is happening around it, how every night Sunshine is there, a mayhem ensues. However, I appreciate how Manila became a sanctuary place for her, where we can see how despite the chaos that happens every night, there are bits of humanity that saves her. The girl dun sa hotel, yung tricycle driver, and the 13-year-old girl that she met.Furthermore, I would like to commend the addition of having childrens act as her conscience or the "what if child of hers". It's a great addition because we can see how in the beginning of the film the girl was literally shouting "murderer" over and over again because in her perspective, her mother is harming her. But in the end when she said "gets ko na", it became a cathartic scene as it finally hits us that it isn't about being irresponsible and selfish ---- rather it is something more than that. The whole line of the girl saying to her friend Ariana that her dream is the same as Sunshine's is a great addition because I think it rings true with reality. As every now and then, when a child hears about the dreams of their parents and how they had to stop it to take care of their children, especially when it comes to Mothers, the child often feels bad and just wished that thier Mom was able to live out their dream first.Lastly, I love the relationship of sunshine and her older sister, the fact that never once pinagalitan o diniktahan ng ate nya sa kung paano nya haharapin yung sitwasyon niya goes to show how much she trusts and love Sunshine. I also love the contrast that all throughout the film there were different sides of the story whether labelling her as a "murderer" o miggy telling her to do what you got to do that once you reached the end scene when her sister just told her "kahit ano maging desisyon mo kampi lang ako sayo" made it soo impactful. Kase in the end yun lang naman ang kailangan niyang marinig, we have seen her face through that circumstance alone with nothing but her conscience, that the moment na sinabi sa kanya yun, it became a relief to her as well as allowed her to finally tell someone or at least cried it out to them na natatakot din siya kase nga bata din siyaa and hindi pa siya ready maging nanay. All in all, the film was a 10 out of 10, and I appreciate how the film wasn't all in the face about what you should believe in and what you shouldn't. It just presents Sunshine's story and her decision which should be acknowledged because hindi dapat humantong sa isang sitwasyon na mas uunahin pa ng isang doktor ang kaniyang lisensya kesa sa buhay ng isang tao dahil lang "nagpalaglag" siya. If you really value life in its essence then we should also acknowledge the life of the person carrying the baby so bakit niyo papabayaan lang na mamatay yung batang 13-year-old???????? so in conclusion:TANGINAA NG MGA LALAKETANGINA MO MIGGYTANGINA NUNG DOKTORATANGINA NUNG LALAKING DOKTORTANGINA NUNG TITO TANGNIA NUNG WALANG KWENTANG NANAY (?) - di nya deserve matawag na nanay

Holy shit, this film had me in tears. Not only is it extremely well made, the cinematography and the characters were so raw that it had me stressing over them. I have never rooted for anyone so much to get rid of that damn baby. The movie also shows the darkest sides of the healthcare system in the Philippines, religion, and most of all, fucking men. It is unfortunate that us Filipina women have it the fucking worst. Not only are we in a third world country where it is illegal to abort, but we are guilt tripped over and over again by society to not choose ourselves. We are literal machines for them to procreate and forget ourselves in the process. We are not human to them.Right from the get-go it is shown how unprepared (who I assumed is 20) 20 year old Sunshine is. Even when she is cleaning up her sister‚Äôs child, she raises her hand as if to scare the child, when the child clearly does not understand this gesture. The men in this film are shown to be no help at all, may it be sibling, the boyfriend, the men in the streets, every. single. man. The concept of birthing a child will never be their problem, it will never even cross their minds. I love how realistic the scenes were when all the pregnant were all together, aiding each other and comforting each other; that is the harsh truth‚Äî men will never know the connection us women have with one another. Even if they are strangers.Rhed (Mary Grace) is the exact reason why abortion should be legalized in the Philippines. Young women subject themselves to improper medical procedures because that‚Äôs all they have access to (and hardly)‚Äî they do not know the severity of what their bodies will go through. In the first place, sex education is still frowned upon in the Philippines. God, I really hate, HATE how religion proves time and time again that they are the main reason why we cannot progress as a society. This film is beautifully filmed, I loved every bit of it. My heart sank deeper whenever she struggles, but the weight lifts whenever she chooses herself. Ladies, please choose yourself, above everyone else.

Gets na gets ko‚Äîand I hope many more people will get it, too. This film struck a deep chord with me. Nearly every scene felt like it could happen in real life‚Äîand in many cases, it truly does.Abortion is treated like a sin in this godforsaken conservative and dominantly Catholic country. Many people disagree, but it really doesn‚Äôt matter whether you agree or not. In the end, the decision should be up to the woman who‚Äôs pregnant. We shouldn‚Äôt have an opinion‚Äîjust understanding is enough. After all, it's her body, her life, her future, her choice. That's why I'll always firmly believe that abortion should be legal and safe. There are women‚Äîand even girls‚Äîwho are far too young, forced into pregnancy, still unstable, still trying to build their own lives, and completely unprepared to raise a child while chasing their dreams. Abortion is healthcare, and access to it is a basic reproductive right.This film captures that reality so loudly. It‚Äôs loud with the streets of Manila, with people‚Äôs judgment, with hypocrisy. You can hear it all so clearly‚Äîthe way society pushes women toward unreliable and dangerous methods like pamparegla in Quiapo or hilot, simply because abortion is condemned and proper reproductive healthcare is lacking. It‚Äôs so fucked up and heartbreaking. Tangina, ang hirap-hirap maging babae sa bansang ‚Äôto‚Äîsa mundong ‚Äôto.'Yung scene na walang filter na ipinakita ang estado ng public hospitals‚Äîmga serbisyong galing sa buwis ng tao pero hindi nila kayang ayusin‚Äîsobrang sakit panoorin. Sobrang bulok ng sistema natin. And there‚Äôs probably something even worse behind it‚Äîwe are so fucked.So when Sunshine finally went through with the abortion, I felt relieved. For a moment, I was scared she might keep the baby. Bringing a child into the world when you‚Äôre not ready‚Äîand being forced to give up your own dreams because of it‚Äîis one of the most cruel things you can do to yourself and to that child. And that‚Äôs exactly why choice matters.Gets ko na.

Ang ganda!Isa sa mga kagandahan ng Sunshine ay ang pagiging tapat nito sa katotohanan. Pinakikita ang katotohanan kung anong meron sa Maynila; masikip, maingay, maputik, at maalikabok. Pamilyar.Pamilyar ang ingay.Pamilyar ang tsismisan.Pamilyar ang katolisismo.Pamilyar ang sikip at mahabang pila sa pampublikong ospital.Pamilyar ang sistemang mabagal at madalas walang pakialam.Pamilyar‚Äîdahil ipinanganak at lumaki rin ako sa pinakasiksik na bahagi ng Maynila.Pero bilang lalaki, iba ang mundo na ginagalawan ko. Sa gitna ng pelikula, naisip ko: hindi ako pamilyar kung paano ba talaga maging isang babae.Hindi pamilyar ang takot.'Yung takot na hindi ko kailanman mararanasan, pero ramdam ko habang pinapanood si Sunshine.Para sa akin, Sunshine works because it feels lived-in.Alam mong ganito talaga ang Pilipinas. Bansang puno ng pangarap, pero puno rin ng hadlang.At sa gitna ng lahat, nando'n si Sunshine: takot at desperado, pero matapang.Hindi melodrama ang dating. Hindi rin lecture.Mas parang paalala: hindi dapat ganito kabigat ang mundo para sa mga kababaihan.

Through Sunshine‚Äôs story, the film becomes a quiet yet devastating reflection of how our society‚Äîand deeply, its systems‚Äîcontinue to fail women. Gets.I was gonna leave it there but I have thoughts so full steam ahead‚ÄîManila is a staple in almost every Filipino film, being the capital and all, but rather than the large city itself‚Äî Sunshine specifically captures the essence of Quiapo so well. The bustling markets, the overcrowd and kids begging for alms, and religion is embedded everywhere‚Äî whether it be its churches, the posters within the buildings, street stalls selling rebultos and rosaries, or the people themselves. I don't usually care for the setting of the story but I always think it's smart when it actually helps drive the narrative forward, so I find this neat little aspect of the film amusing (also, while we're at it, props to whoever the prod designer is wow). I watched this at 3AM during a vigil so I had all the time to read other reviews and can I just say, while I understand how it could be viewed as such‚Äî I don't think this film was didactic or propaganda. I love films that open conversations and Sunshine opened a lot, but more than the conversations it opened, I love how the center of it has always been women. The heart of Sunshine is Sunshine herself, and Maris Racal definitely gave the performance of a lifetime in this one. The fact that she filmed this the same time as Can't Buy Me Love is insane, talk about range.Also, props to Direk Tonet 'cause I have only watched this film a day before, but it is so dear to my heart. Pangarap ko ang pangarap mo, Sunshine <333PS.Also, whoever decided to cast Piolo Pascual and Elijah Canlas sa father and son deserves a raise.

Drown out the noise.The double meaning behind this line in the film holds so much meaning. Both in the sense that Sunshine needs to drown out the noise to chase her goal and that she needs to drown out the noises that judge and try to influence her decision regarding her pregnancy. This film reveals the very ugly truth about abortion: that criminalizing it will not make it go away, but only make it more dangerous for women like Sunshine to go through it.

Two can tango, but only one makes it out of the dancefloor.The hard truth of women and children being the ones to bear the consequences. May this film be an eye opener. The underlying issues on mental health, socioeconomic burden, and lack of education are directly implied in this film. To bravely put it out on Philippine media is a start of a more aware perspective. The cinematography and script are well combined and well thought of. The metaphors hit the spot and Maris' performance not only represented a lot of young girls out there, but also those who are mentally struggling. Seeing someone doing everything alone and bear the burden of something that isn't normative is heartbreaking. Children must not be guilt tripped into doing things just to survive. Proper education and guidance is what we always hope and pray for. May this film pave the way to a more open and safe space for all that are struggling.

‚ÄúGets ko na. Gets ko na.‚Äùit feels incredibly realistic... so real that it‚Äôs as if Sunshine herself is my best friend, opening up to me and sharing her deepest thoughts. you can truly feel every line she delivers; each word carries weight, sincerity, and emotion.the film truly stands out in the way it portrays raw, human moments. sunshine‚Äôs character is written with such honesty that her struggles and triumphs feel personal.hands down to you, direk tonet üëè your vision and heart made this film shine in the most genuine way.

beautiful, just absolutely beautiful ü•πthis has got to be one of the best filo movies i have ever watched, like EVER. i honestly cannot find the words right now but i have never felt so affected, like i was the one experiencing it. from sunshine drowning out the noise, to her practicing the last time (we see) before the olympics. all of this was just so beautiful, i felt her struggles and everything that happened to her.this movie made me tear up atleast 3 times. it was just so sad seeing the reality, and thinking that someone might be experiencing this - that this IS someones life. its sad, really to think about just how many women have to suffer and give up their lives, their DREAMS just because of this stupid anti abortion law. and its crazy how so much women have to go through suck risky procedures just to get rid of a baby. its not helping either that the philippines is a catholic/ christian heavy country. meaning that in their eyes, abortion is evil and murder. we see this in the film, and the film executed and protrayed it perfectly. we see how sunshine is slowly becomes confuse because why should sunshine apologize? if god is so forgiving, couldnt he forgive her for fighting for her dream? i am catholic but people who think that god wouldnt forgive women for aborting their children confuse me. also, i forgot to mention that we also see how sunshine prays before doing anything bad, just shows that she has some catholic guilt/ conscience.sunshine didnt even want a baby, was it her fault miguel didnt pull out? why should she be pressured to give birth when she never wanted it? think about it, why should women pay for mens incompetence? its crazy how so much men think that just because women carry the baby means that they have to carry all the burdens and troubles too, like hello? ure also a part of this too LOL. speaking of men, FUCK that bobot guy üñï sunshine was so right for what she did to him and i will forever defend her for that. but, lets not forget that this is the reality of some women. its just gross and inhumane. FUCK YOU BOBOT!! now lets talk about the people who supported sunshine along the way, starting with her sister. Honestly, with how close they were i was really surprised that sunshine never told her. all of their scenes were just so heart warming and it really just felt so comforting. i feel like she was someone that sunshine really needed at the time and yknow those words probably meant so much to sunshine. i got a little teary eyed during that scene cuz it was just so ü•πnext, the doctora. notice how it was a woman who risked her lisence and did everything to save the pregnant girl? yeah, thats what i call girlhood üòé but yeah, i was just so happy that someone, an actual stranger, reached out a helping hand. even though she had very little screentime, i really enjoyed her character and it really just showed that there are still some good people out there.moving on, we have the pregnant girl. her hug with sunshine absolutely made me cry. idk, maybe seeing someone going through the same things as her just brought some comfort like atleast theyre both in this together. her almost dying made me feel something, it was either goosebumps or just deadass misery.. i guess a HM would be the coach. (no i am not mentioning the kid cry about it üòí)overall, this was such a beautiful movie. i felt everything and it just captured the life of a filipina so well. just shows how much one person could be going through and how much a woman has to do to simply get rid of her baby. def watch this if you have time!!

this was so realistic. and also so realistic in showing how fucked up the system in our country really is.people say things like "paano kung 'yan yung maging susunod na president?", "paano kung 'yan yung makahanap ng cure sa ganito gan'yan?" when talking about a fetus that might be aborted, when those questions should honestly be applied more about kids who were forced to live a messed up system that was also because of adults, just like yung kay mary grace. her case happens a lot in real life. many children as young as 13 are forced to be pregnant and become mothers. like imagine, a 13 year old?? that's a kid. anddd hindi ko rin talaga magegets (and never will, honestly) yung mga tao na hindi pro-choice who doesn't care if pregnancy happened because of rape. tangina niyo. another thing, dahil nga illegal pa ang abortion in the philippines, a lot of kababaihan would resort to "pangpa-regla" and other unsafe procedures para lang makapag-abort. if the healthcare system truly cares about the people, why prioritize the "life" of a fetus, imbis na sa taong buhay and humihinga na? bakit kailangan pa silang maghirap? and i like annika's character here also symbolizing sunshine's guilt. kahit na parang desidido na talaga si sunshine noong una pa na she wouldn't keep the baby, there still lingers a feeling of guilt inside her, yunv parehong religious and personal guilt. and yung sa last part, her saying na "gets ko na"... ay, putangina, i love it.i really hope this movie would serve as an eye opener sa bansang 'to rsgarding abortion, and i also hope that people become more open-minded. sana maging legal na ang abortion. hay, tangina kayo

If your moral values believe that no child should be aborted, sana kasama rin sa values nyo na walang babaeng deserved na mahirapan dahil sa unwanted pregnancy. Women needs to have choice, if we always shame women na nabuntis, bakit hindi natin ibaling sa mga nakabuntis ang sisi? Sa buong panonood ko, nainis ako kay Elijah Canlas, sa nanay ni xyril, kay Piolo Pascual, dun sa nagtitinda ng pampalaglag, dun sa doctor na ayaw mag-admit ng batang naghihingalo dahil gumawa daw ng ilegal (mind you, narape yan kaya sya buntis), at sa ospital na hindi kayang i-cater ang pangangalaga sa mga kababaihan. Sana imbes na ijudge si sunshine sa choices nya, sana namulat tayong lahat na we should be free of our choices. Na hindi tayo selfish dahil lang ayaw natin ng anak. And that we are entitled to be taken care of kahit ano pang desisyon natin when it comes to our pregnancy. Sobrang lupit ng mundo natin, na patuloy na nagtataas ng kilay kapag tungkol sa SOGIE pero wala ring ginagawang hakbang kapag nagkakaroon ng unwanted pregnancy ang mga kababaihan. ‚ÄúGets ko na, gets ko na.‚ÄùSobrang tumatak sakin yung line na yun.Sunshine is the kind of film that hits quietly but deeply. It shows how hard it is for women in the Philippines to ask for help, and how scary it can be, pero kahit ganun, it reminds us na may karapatan pa rin tayong mangarap.I also liked how it showed the reality of our Olympians here. You can give everything, train like crazy, be so talented, pero minsan hirap ka pa rin mabuhay. Ang bigat pero ang totoo.Sunshine‚Äôs character feels real and strong. Hindi perfect, pero may tapang pumili ng sarili niyang future. Even when she had an easier option, pinili pa rin niya yung pangarap niya. I respect that so much.Sana mas maraming babae ang makapili ng sarili nilang path, dreams, and life.

waited so long na maging available on digital 'yung movie na 'to and needless to say it was worth the wait because wtf ilang beses ako naiyaküò≠ from the depiction pa lang ng daily life sa pinas, the customs and norms we have, to the imaginary children representing the "could-have-beens", and also in a way, the girls' own guilt following them with every decision they try to make for a common situation that girls‚Äîespecially the young ones‚Äîsuffer through here sa bansa na 'to (not just the pregnancy itself but also the internal battles that come with religious guilt and having dreams beyond what other people would call as "a gift from God").na-bother lang ako sa texting scenes because ang random ng pag-type sa keyboard, but hindi mo na talaga maiisip 'yon at present sa sobrang daming na-tackle for such a short film. and yet it was done so beautifully. the pacing was SO GOOD and i couldn't help but fall in love with the cinematography, the WRITING, the ACTINGGG because of how natural the lines were delivered. kudos kay direk at pang top 4 films na ata 'to !!two takeaways for me dito: there's really no hate like christian love and seeing female solidarity in films will always make me cry. (pwede na 'to i-add sa films about girlhood bcs it would be my fav on the list).
